1005229_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	We are a leading global designer, manufacturer and marketer of hoists, rigging tools, cranes, actuators, and other material handling products serving a wide variety of commercial and industrial end-user markets.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	Our products are used to efficiently and ergonomically move, lift, position or secure objects and loads.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P0_S2	We are the U.S. market leader in hoists, our principal line of products, as well as certain chain, forged attachment, and actuator products which we believe provides us with a strategic advantage in selling our other products.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P0_S3	We have achieved this leadership position through strategic acquisitions, our extensive, diverse and well-established distribution channels and our commitment to product innovation and quality.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P0_S4	We have one of the most comprehensive product offerings in the industry and we believe we have more overhead hoists in use in North America than all of our competitors combined.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P0_S5	Additionally, we believe we are the market leader of manual hoist and actuator products in Europe, which provides us further opportunity to sell our other products through our existing distribution channels in that region.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P0_S6	Our products are sold globally and our brand names, including CM, Coffing, Chester, Duff-Norton, Pfaff, Shaw-Box and Yale, are among the most recognized and well-respected in the marketplace.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our business is cyclical in nature and sensitive to changes in general economic conditions, including changes in the manufacturing industry capacity utilization, industrial production and the general economic activity indicators, like GDP.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P1_S1	Both U.S. and Eurozone capacity utilization are leading market indicators for the Company.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P1_S2	US industrial capacity utilization increased to 74.9% in April 2011, trending up from 70.9% in April 2010.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P1_S3	Eurozone capacity utilization has also been trending higher for the last seven quarters, reaching 77.6% in March 2011 compared with the trough of 69.6% in June 2009.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	In response to the negative economic climate we experienced in Fiscal 2010 and consistent with our manufacturing strategy, we rationalized our North American hoist and rigging operations to improve efficiency, control costs and facilitate future growth.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P2_S1	This included ceasing welded chain production in our Mexico facility and closure of one of our forge and one of our hoist facilities in the U.S.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P2_S2	This entire facility consolidation initiative resulted in a reduction of 500,000 square feet of manufacturing space.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P2_S3	We estimate that we will generate annual cost savings of approximately $15,000,000 as a result of the rationalization.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P2_S4	We have realized approximately half of those savings during fiscal 2011.

1005229_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	The breadth of our products and services enables us to participate in most of these sectors.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P4_S1	This diversification, together with our extensive and varied distribution channels, minimizes our dependence on any particular product, market or customer.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P4_S2	We believe that none of our competitors offers the variety of products or services in the markets we serve.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	We believe that the demand for our products and services will be aided by several macro-economic growth drivers.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	Productivity Enhancement - We believe employers respond to competitive pressures by seeking to maximize productivity and efficiency, among other actions.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P6_S1	Our hoists and other lifting and positioning products allow loads to be lifted and placed quickly, precisely, with little effort and fewer people, thereby increasing productivity and reducing cycle time.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P6_S2	Further, emphasis on Lean techniques by many companies increases demand for our lifting and positioning products for use in single-piece flow workstation applications.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	Safety Regulations - Driven by workplace safety regulations such as the Occupational Safety and Health Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act in the U.S. and other safety regulations around the world, and by the general competitive need to reduce costs such as health insurance premiums and workers compensation expenses, employers seek safer ways to lift and position loads.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	Our lifting and positioning products enable these tasks to be performed with reduced risk of personal injury.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	Consolidation of Suppliers - In an effort to reduce costs and increase productivity, our channel partners and end-user customers are increasingly consolidating their suppliers.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	We believe that our broad product offering combined with our well established brand names will enable us to benefit from this consolidation and enhance our market share.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	Leading North American Market Positions - We are a leading manufacturer and marketer of hoists, alloy and high strength carbon steel chain and attachments, and actuators in North America.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P9_S1	We have developed our leading market positions over our 136-year history by emphasizing technological innovation, manufacturing excellence and superior service.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P9_S2	Approximately 61% of our U.S. net sales for the year ended March 31, 2011 were from product categories in which we believe we hold the number one market share.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P9_S3	We believe that the strength of our established products and brands and our leading market positions provide us with significant competitive advantages, including preferred supplier status with a majority of our largest channel partners and end user customers.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P9_S4	Our large installed base of products also provides us with a significant competitive advantage in selling our products to existing customers as well as providing repair and replacement parts.

1005229_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	We believe we offer the most comprehensive product lines in the markets we serve.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	Most of our products work in conjunction with each other to create a lifting system.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P16_S2	We offer engineering and design services to help channel partners and end users solve material handling problems.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P16_S3	We are the only major supplier of material handling equipment offering full lines of hoists, rigging and lifting tools as well as actuators.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P16_S4	Most of our products are maintenance, repair and operating tools which work in conjunction with each other to create a complete lifting system.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P16_S5	We complement our product offerings with engineering and design services to assist our channel partners and end-users in finding the optimal solution for their material handling needs.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P16_S6	Our capability as a full-line supplier has allowed us to (i) provide our customers with one-stop shopping for material handling equipment, which meets some customers desires to reduce the number of their supply relationships in order to lower their costs, (ii) leverage our engineering, product development and marketing costs over a larger sales base and (iii) achieve purchasing efficiencies on common materials used across our product lines.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P16_S7	No single SKU comprises more than 1% of our sales, a testament to our broad and diversified product offering.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	In addition, our brand names, including Budgit, Chester, CM, Coffing, Duff-Norton, Little Mule, Pfaff, Shaw-Box and Yale, are among the most recognized and respected in the industry.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	The CM and Yale names have been synonymous with powered hoists and manual hoists and were first developed and marketed under these brand names in the early 1900s.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P17_S2	We believe that our strong brand name recognition has created customer loyalty and helps us maintain existing business, as well as capture additional business.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P17_S3	We are at the forefront of innovation in our industry and continually introduce new products to meet our changing customer needs.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P17_S4	Products introduced during the three fiscal years ended March 31, 2011 account for approximately 17% of our net sales; our goal is to increase this to 20%.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	Distribution Channel Diversity and Strength - Our products are sold to over 15,000 general and specialty distributors, end users and OEMs globally.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P18_S1	We enjoy long-standing relationships with, and are a preferred provider to, the majority of our largest distributors and industrial buying groups.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P18_S2	There has been consolidation among distributors of material handling equipment and we have benefited from this consolidation by maintaining and enhancing our relationships with our leading distributors, as well as forming new relationships.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P18_S3	We believe our extensive distribution channels provide a significant competitive advantage and allow us to effectively market new product line extensions and promote cross-selling.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P18_S4	Our largest distributor represents only approximately 4% of our total net sales and our top 10 customers present less than 15% of our total net sales.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	Expanding Non-U.S. Markets - We have significantly grown our non-U.S. sales since becoming a public company in 1996.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P19_S1	Our non-U.S. sales have grown from $34,300,000 (representing 16% of total sales) in fiscal 1996 to $241,970,000 (representing 46% of our total sales) during the year ended March 31, 2011.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P19_S2	This growth has occurred primarily in Europe, Latin America and Asia-Pacific.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P19_S3	The Pfaff acquisition in October 2008 has enhanced our non-U.S. revenue growth, particularly in Europe.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P19_S4	Additionally, we have recently opened four sales offices in Shanghai, Guangzhou, Wunan, and Shenyang, China to sell into this growing industrial market, with more planned in the coming year.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P19_S5	Our non-U.S. business has provided us, and we believe will continue to provide us, with significant growth opportunities and new markets for our products.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	"Non-U.S. sales" as expressed throughout Items 1 and 7 of this Form 10-K, are defined as sales to customers located outside of the United States.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	We are extremely focused on optimizing our cost structure and have taken a number of steps towards reducing our costs, including: consolidating facilities, promoting a Lean culture, manufacturing in low cost jurisdictions, coordinating purchasing activities across the organization and selectively outsourcing non-critical functions.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P21_S1	The actions we have taken to date have eliminated fixed costs from our operations and will provide us with significant operating leverage as the economic conditions in our markets continue to improve.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P21_S2	Our operating leverage goal is for each incremental sales dollar to generate 20%-30% of additional operating income, in addition to the fixed cost savings realized from our facility consolidation activities.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	Rationalization and Consolidation - We have a history of consolidating manufacturing facilities and optimizing warehouse utilization, resulting in lower annual operating costs and improving our fixed-variable cost relationship.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P22_S1	During our fiscal year ended March 31, 2010, we initiated further consolidation of our North American hoist and rigging operations in accordance with our strategy.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P22_S2	We completed the closure of one of our manufacturing facilities in Cedar Rapids, Iowa and significantly downsized manufacturing at a second facility in Mexico in the third quarter of the fiscal year ended March 31, 2010.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P22_S3	Additionally, we completed the closure of a third facility in Muskegon, Michigan in the first quarter of the fiscal year ended March 31, 2011.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P22_S4	These projects have resulted in an aggregate reduction of approximately 500,000 square feet of manufacturing space and are expected to generate annual savings estimated at approximately $15,000,000.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	Lean Culture - We have been applying Lean techniques since 2001 and our efforts have resulted in a meaningful reduction in inventory levels, a significant decline in required manufacturing floor space, a decrease in product lead time and an improvement in productivity and on-time deliveries.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P23_S1	We have witnessed the benefits of Lean principles in our manufacturing operations and are now working to develop a Lean culture throughout our organization improving our processes and reducing waste in all forms in all of our business activities.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	Expansion Outside the U.S. - Our continued expansion of our manufacturing facilities in China and Hungary provides us with a cost efficient platform to manufacture and distribute certain of our products and components.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	We now operate 12 major manufacturing facilities in six countries, with 39 stand-alone sales and service offices in 17 countries and 10 warehouse facilities in five countries.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	Consolidated Purchasing Activities - We continue to leverage our company-wide purchasing power through our Purchasing Council to reduce our costs and manage fluctuations in commodity pricing, including steel.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	Selective Integration and Outsourcing - We manufacture many of the critical parts and components used in the manufacture of our hoists and lifting systems, resulting in reduced costs.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	We also evaluate outsourcing opportunities for non-critical operations and components.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	Strong After-Market Sales and Support - We believe that we retain customers and attract new customers due to our ongoing commitment to customer service and ultimate satisfaction.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P27_S1	We have a large installed base of hoists and rigging tools that drives our after-market sales for replacement units and components and repair parts.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P27_S2	We maintain strong relationships with our distribution channel partners and provide prompt service to end-users of our products through our authorized network of 14 chain repair stations and approximately 340 hoist service and repair stations.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P27_S3	We also work closely with end users to design the appropriate lifting systems using our products to help them solve their material handling problems.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	We also provide a wide variety of training and certification programs to the users of our products.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P28_S1	These training and certification programs include crane inspection and operation training and certification, hoist inspection and repair training and certification, various rigging training courses, load securement training, and CM entertainment technology equipment training and certification classes.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	We have consistently generated positive free cash flow (which we define as net cash provided by operating activities less capital expenditures) through periods of economic uncertainty by continually controlling our costs, improving our working capital management and reducing the capital intensity of our manufacturing operations.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P29_S1	In the past five years, despite the economic downturn, we have reduced total net debt by $36,400,000, from $110,700,000 to $74,300,000 at March 31, 2011, and we continue to improve our cash balance.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P29_S2	We manage our capital structure conservatively while maintaining flexibility to pursue attractive strategic growth opportunities.

1005229_11_ITEM1_P30_S1	This diverse experience has been critical to our success to date and will be instrumental to our long-term growth.

1005229_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	We design, manufacture and distribute a broad range of material handling products for various applications.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P41_S1	Products include a wide variety of electric, lever, hand and air-powered hoists, hoist trolleys, winches, industrial crane systems such as bridge, gantry and jib cranes; alloy and carbon steel chain; closed-die forged attachments, such as hooks, shackles, textile slings, clamps, logging tools and load binders; industrial components, such as mechanical and electromechanical actuators and rotary unions; below-the-hook special purpose lifters; tire shredders; and light-rail systems.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P41_S2	These products are typically manufactured for stock or assembled to order from standard components and are sold primarily through a variety of commercial distributors and to a lesser extent, directly to end-users.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P41_S3	The diverse end-users of our products are in a variety of industries including: manufacturing, power generation and distribution, utilities, wind power, warehouses, commercial construction, oil exploration and refining, petrochemical, marine, ship building, transportation and heavy duty trucking, agriculture, logging and mining.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P41_S4	We also serve a niche market for the entertainment industry including permanent and traveling concerts, live theater and sporting venues.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	In excess of 80% of our net sales are derived from the sale of products that we sell at a unit price of less than $5,000.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P42_S1	Of our fiscal 2011 sales, $282,095,000 or 54% were U.S. and $241,970,000, or 46% were international.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P42_S2	The following table sets forth certain sales data for our products, expressed as a percentage of net sales for fiscal 2011 and 2010:
1005229_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	Hoists - We manufacture a wide variety of electric chain hoists, electric wire rope hoists, hand-operated hoists, winches, lever tools and air-powered hoists.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P43_S1	Load capacities for our hoist product lines range from one-eighth of a ton to 100 tons.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P43_S2	These products are sold under our Budgit, Chester, CM, Coffing, Little Mule, Pfaff, Shaw-Box, Yale and other recognized brands.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	Our hoists are sold for use in numerous general industrial applications, as well as for use in the construction, energy, mining, food services, entertainment and other markets.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P44_S1	We also supply hoist trolleys, driven manually or by electric motors, for the industrial, consumer and OEM markets.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	We also offer several lines of standard and custom-designed, below-the-hook tooling, clamps, and textile strappings.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	Below-the-hook tooling, textile and chain slings and associated forgings, and clamps are specialized lifting apparatus used in a variety of lifting activities performed in conjunction with hoisting or lifting applications.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	Rigging Tools - We manufacture alloy and carbon steel chain for various industrial and consumer applications.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P47_S1	U.S. federal regulations require the use of alloy chain, which we first developed, for overhead lifting applications because of its strength and wear characteristics.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P47_S2	A line of our alloy chain is sold under the Herc-Alloy brand name for use in overhead lifting, pulling and restraining applications.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P47_S3	In addition, we also sell specialized load chain for use in hoists, as well as three grades and multiple sizes of carbon steel welded-link chain for various load securing and other non-overhead lifting applications.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P47_S4	We also manufacture kiln chain sold primarily to the cement manufacturing market.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	We produce a broad line of alloy and carbon steel closed-die forged attachments, including hooks, shackles, hitch pins and master links.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P48_S1	These forged attachments are used in chain, wire rope and textile rigging applications in a variety of industries, including transportation, mining, construction, marine, logging, petrochemical and agriculture.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	In addition, we manufacture carbon steel forged and stamped products, such as load binders, logging tools and other securing devices, for sale to the industrial, consumer and logging markets through industrial distributors, hardware distributors, mass merchandiser outlets and OEMs.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	Industrial Cranes - We participate in the U.S. crane manufacturing and servicing markets through our offering of overhead bridge, jib and gantry cranes.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	Our products are sold under the CES, Abell-Howe, Gaffey and Washington Equipment brands.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	Crane builders represent a specific distribution channel for electric wire rope hoists, chain hoists and other crane components.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	Actuators and Rotary Unions - Through our Duff-Norton and Pfaff divisions, we design and manufacture industrial components such as mechanical and electromechanical actuators and rotary unions.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	Actuators are linear motion devices used in a variety of industries, including the transportation, paper, steel, energy, aerospace and many other commercial industries.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	Rotary unions are devices that transfer a liquid or gas from a fixed pipe or hose to a rotating drum, cylinder or other device.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P54_S1	Rotary unions are used in a variety of industries including pulp and paper, printing, textile and fabric manufacturing, rubber and plastic.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P55_S0	Other - This category includes tire shredders and light-rail systems.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P56_S0	We have developed and patented a line of heavy equipment that shreds whole tires, for use in recycling the various components of a tire including: rubber and steel.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P56_S1	These recycled products also can be used as aggregate, playgrounds, sports surfaces, landscaping and other such applications, as well as scrap steel.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P57_S0	Light-rail systems are portable steel overhead beam configurations used at workstations, from which hoists are an integral component.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P58_S0	Our sales and marketing efforts consist of the following programs:

1005229_11_ITEM1_P60_S1	We run targeted advertisements for hoists, chain, forged attachments, actuators, and cranes.

1005229_11_ITEM1_P61_S1	This literature displays our broad product offering applicable to those sectors to enhance awareness at the end-user level within those sectors.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P61_S2	We also employ vertical market specialists to support our field sales force to assist our customers with solving their material handling application needs.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P62_S0	Trade Show Participation - Trade shows are central to the promotion of our products, and we participate in more than 30 regional, national and international trade shows each year.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P62_S1	Shows in which we participate range from global events held in Germany to local markets and open houses organized by individual hardware and industrial distributors.

1005229_11_ITEM1_P63_S0	Industry Association Membership and Participation - As a recognized industry leader, we have a long history of work and participation in a variety of industry associations.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P63_S1	(Specialty Carriers and Riggers Association), WSTDA (Web Sling and Tie Down Association), MHI (Material Handling Institute), HMI (Hoist Manufacturers Institute), CMAA (Crane Manufacturers Association of America), ESTA (Entertainment Services and Technology Association), NACM (National Association of Chain Manufacturers) and ARA (American Rental Association).

1005229_11_ITEM1_P64_S1	These training and certification programs include crane inspection and operation training and certification, hoist inspection and repair training and certification, various rigging training courses, load securement training, and entertainment technology equipment training and certification classes.

1005229_11_ITEM1_P65_S1	The site also provides detailed search and simultaneous product comparisons, the ability to submit Requests for Quotations and allow users to be able chat live with a member of our customer service department.

1005229_11_ITEM1_P66_S0	Our distribution channels include a variety of commercial distributors.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P66_S1	In addition, we sell overhead bridge, jib and gantry cranes as well as certain Pfaff products directly to end-users.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P67_S0	The following describes our global distribution channels:
1005229_11_ITEM1_P68_S0	General Distribution Channels - Our global general distribution channels consist of:
1005229_11_ITEM1_P69_S0	Industrial distributors that serve local or regional industrial markets and sell a variety of products for maintenance repair, operating and production, or MROP, applications through their own direct sales force.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P70_S0	Rigging shops that are distributors with expertise in rigging, lifting, positioning and load securing.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P70_S1	Most rigging shops assemble and distribute chain, wire rope and synthetic slings and distribute manual hoists and attachments, chain slings and other products.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P71_S0	Independent crane builders that design, build, install and service overhead crane and light-rail systems for general industry and also distribute a wide variety of hoists and crane components.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P71_S1	We sell electric wire rope hoists and chain hoists as well as crane components, such as end trucks, trolleys, drives and electrification systems to crane builders.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P72_S0	Specialty Distribution Channels - Our global specialty distribution channels consist of:
1005229_11_ITEM1_P73_S0	National distributors that market a variety of MROP supplies, including material handling products, either exclusively through large, nationally distributed catalogs, or through a combination of catalog, internet and branch sales and a field sales force.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P73_S1	The customer base served by national distributors such as W. W. Grainger, which traditionally included smaller industrial companies and consumers, has grown to include large industrial accounts and integrated suppliers.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P74_S0	Material handling specialists and integrators that design and assemble systems incorporating hoists, overhead rail systems, trolleys, scissor lift tables, manipulators, air balancers, jib arms and other material handling products to provide end-users with solutions to their material handling problems.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P75_S0	Entertainment equipment distributors that design, supply and install a variety of material handling and rigging equipment for concerts, theaters, ice shows, sporting events, convention centers and night clubs.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P76_S0	Pfaff International Direct - Our German-based Pfaff business markets and sells most of its actuators and certain of its hoist products direct to end-users, providing an additional method to market for us in the European region.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P77_S0	Crane End-Users - We market and sell overhead bridge, jib and gantry cranes, parts and service to end-users through our wholly owned crane builder, Crane Equipment Service, Inc. ( CES ).
1005229_11_ITEM1_P77_S1	CES which includes Abell-Howe, Gaffey and Washington Equipment brands designs, manufactures, installs and services a variety of cranes with capacities up to 100 tons.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P78_S0	Service-After-Sale Distribution Channel - Service-after-sale distributors include our authorized network of 14 chain repair service stations and approximately 340 hoist service and repair stations throughout North America.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P78_S1	This service network is designed for easy parts and service access for our large installed base of hoists and related equipment in that region.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P79_S0	OEMs that supply various component parts directly to other industrial manufacturers as well as private branding and packaging of our traditional products for material handling, lifting, positioning and special purpose applications.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P80_S0	Government agencies, including the U.S. and Canadian Navies and Coast Guards, that purchase primarily load securing chain and forged attachments.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P80_S1	We also provide our products to the U.S government for a variety of military applications.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P81_S0	We maintain customer service departments staffed by trained personnel for all of our sales divisions, and regularly schedule product and service training schools for all customer service representatives and field sales personnel.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P81_S1	Training programs for distribution and service station personnel, as well as for end-users, are scheduled on a regular basis at most of our facilities and in the field.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P81_S2	We have approximately 340 service and repair stations worldwide that provide local and regional repair, warranty and general service work for distributors and end-users.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P81_S3	End-user trainees attending our various programs include representatives of 3M, Cummins Engine, DuPont, GTE, General Electric, John Deere, Praxair and many other industrial and entertainment organizations.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P82_S0	We also provide, in multiple languages, a variety of collateral material in video, cassette, CD-ROM, slide and print format addressing relevant material handling topics such as the care, use and inspection of chains and hoists, and overhead lifting and positioning safety.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P82_S1	In addition, we sponsor advisory boards made up of representatives of our primary distributors and service-after-sale network members who are invited to participate in discussions focused on improving products and service.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P82_S2	These boards enable us and our primary distributors to exchange product and market information relevant to industry trends.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P83_S0	Our backlog of orders at March 31, 2011 was approximately $89,393,000 compared to approximately $67,819,000 at March 31, 2010.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P83_S1	Our orders for standard products are generally shipped within one week.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P83_S2	Orders for products that are manufactured to customers specifications are generally shipped within four to twelve weeks.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P83_S3	Given the short product lead times, we do not believe that the amount of our backlog of orders is a reliable indication of our future sales.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P84_S0	Fluctuations in backlog reflect the project oriented nature of certain aspects of our business.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P85_S0	The material handling industry remains highly fragmented.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P85_S1	We face competition from a wide range of regional, national and international manufacturers globally.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P85_S2	In addition, we often compete with individual operating units of larger, highly diversified companies.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P86_S0	The principal competitive factors affecting our business include customer service and support as well as product availability, performance, functionality, brand reputation, reliability and price.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P86_S1	Other important factors include distributor relationships and territory coverage.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P87_S0	Major competitors for hoists are Konecranes, Demag Cranes and Kito (and its U.S. subsidiary Harrington); for chain are Campbell Chain, Peerless Chain Company and American Chain and Cable Company; for forged attachments are The Crosby Group and Brewer Tichner Company; for cranes are Konecranes, Demag Cranes and a variety of independent crane builders; for actuators and rotary unions are Deublin, Joyce-Dayton and Nook Industries; for tire shredders is Granutech; and for light-rail systems is Gorbel.

1005229_11_ITEM1_P88_S4	We believe that our relationship with our employees is good and that the risk of a disruption in production related to these negotiations is remote.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P89_S0	Our principal raw materials and components are steel, consisting of structural steel, processed steel bar, forging bar steel, steel rod and wire, steel pipe and tubing and tool steel; electric motors; bearings; gear reducers; castings; and electro-mechanical components.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P89_S1	These commodities are all available from multiple sources.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P89_S2	We purchase most of these raw materials and components from a limited number of strategic and preferred suppliers under long-term agreements which are negotiated on a company-wide basis through our Purchasing Council to take advantage of volume discounts.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P89_S3	We generally seek to pass on materials price increases to our distribution channel partners and end-user customers.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P89_S4	We will continue to monitor our costs and reevaluate our pricing policies.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P89_S5	Our ability to pass on these increases is determined by market conditions.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P90_S0	We use derivative instruments to manage selected foreign currency exposures.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P90_S1	The Company does not use derivative instruments for speculative trading purposes.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P91_S0	We use foreign currency forward agreements and a cross-currency swap to offset changes in the value of intercompany loans to certain foreign subsidiaries due to changes in foreign exchange rates.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P91_S1	In addition, we use foreign currency forward agreements to i) hedge changes in the value of booked foreign currency liabilities due to changes in foreign exchange rates at the settlement date and ii) to hedge a portion of forecasted inventory purchases denominated in a foreign currency.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P92_S0	We complement our own manufacturing by outsourcing components and finished goods from an established global network of suppliers.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P92_S1	We regularly upgrade our global manufacturing facilities and invest in tooling, equipment and technology.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P92_S2	In 2001, we began implementing Lean improvement techniques in our business which has resulted in inventory reductions in required manufacturing floor area, shorter product lead time and increased productivity.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P93_S0	Our manufacturing operations are highly integrated.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P93_S1	Although raw materials and some components such as motors, bearings, gear reducers, castings and electro-mechanical components are purchased, our vertical integration enables us to produce many of the components used in the manufacturing of our products.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P93_S2	We manufacture hoist lifting chain, steel forged gear blanks, lift wheels, trolley wheels, and hooks and other attachments for incorporation into our hoist products.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P93_S3	These products are also sold as spare parts for hoist repair.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P93_S4	Additionally, our hoists are used as components in the manufacture of crane systems by us as well as our crane-builder customers.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P94_S0	Like most manufacturing companies, we are subject to various federal, state and local laws relating to the protection of the environment.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P94_S1	To address the requirements of such laws, we have adopted a corporate environmental protection policy which provides that all of our owned or leased facilities shall, and all of our employees have the duty to, comply with all applicable environmental regulatory standards, and we have initiated an environmental auditing program for our facilities to ensure compliance with such regulatory standards.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P94_S2	We have also established managerial responsibilities and internal communication channels for dealing with environmental compliance issues that may arise in the course of our business.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P94_S3	We have made and could be required to continue to make significant expenditures to comply with environmental requirements.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P94_S4	Because of the complexity and changing nature of environmental regulatory standards, it is possible that situations will arise from time to time requiring us to incur additional expenditures in order to ensure environmental regulatory compliance.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P94_S5	However, we are not aware of any environmental condition or any operation at any of our facilities, either individually or in the aggregate, which would cause expenditures having a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition or cash flows and, accordingly, have not budgeted any material capital expenditures for environmental compliance for fiscal 2012.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P95_S0	In addition, we notified the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources (the DENR ) in April 2006 of the presence of certain contaminants in excess of regulatory standards at our Coffing Hoist facility in Wadesboro, North Carolina.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P95_S1	We filed an application with the DENR to enter its voluntary cleanup program and were accepted.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P95_S2	We investigated under the supervision of a DENR Registered Environmental Consultant ( the REC ) and have commenced voluntary clean-up at the facility.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P95_S3	At this time, additional remediation costs are not expected to exceed the accrued balance of $200,000.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P96_S0	In March of 2007, we also discovered the presence of certain contaminants in excess of regulatory standards at our Damascus, Virginia hoist plant and have notified the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality (the DEQ ).
1005229_11_ITEM1_P96_S1	We filed an application with the DEQ to participate in its voluntary remediation program and have been accepted.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P96_S2	We are currently investigating under the terms of the DEQ Voluntary Remediation Program and, if appropriate, will remediate site conditions at the facility.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P96_S3	At this time, investigative and remediation costs are not expected to be significant.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P97_S0	In June of 2007, we were identified by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation ( the DEC ), along with other companies, as a potential responsible party ( PRP ) at the Frontier Chemical Royal Avenue Site in Niagara Falls, New York.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P98_S0	From 1974 to 1992, the Frontier Royal Avenue Site had been operated as a commercial waste treatment and disposal facility.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P98_S1	We sent waste sulfuric acid pickling solution generated at our facility in Tonawanda, New York to the Frontier Royal Avenue Site during the period from approximately 1982 to 1984.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P98_S2	We have joined with other PRP members known as the Frontier Chemical Site Joint Defense Alliance Group to conduct investigation and, if appropriate, remediation activities at the site.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P98_S3	At this stage, we do not have an estimate of likely remediation costs, if any, but do not believe that such costs would have a material adverse effect on our financial condition or operating results.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P99_S0	For all of the currently known environmental matters, we have accrued a total of $300,000 as of March 31, 2011 which, in our opinion, is sufficient to deal with such matters.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P99_S1	Further, we believe that the environmental matters known to, or anticipated by us should not, individually or in the aggregate, have a material adverse effect on our operating results or financial condition.
1005229_11_ITEM1_P99_S2	However, there can be no assurance that potential liabilities and expenditures associated with unknown environmental matters, unanticipated events, or future compliance with environmental laws and regulations will not have a material adverse effect on us.

1005229_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Columbus McKinnon is subject to a number of risk factors that could negatively affect our results from business operations or cause actual results to differ materially from those projected or indicated in any forward looking statement.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Such factors include, but are not limited to, the following:
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Adverse changes in global economic conditions may negatively affect our industry, business and results of operations.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Financial markets in the United States, Europe and Asia have experienced substantial disruption including, among other things, extreme volatility in security prices, severely diminished liquidity and credit availability, rating downgrades of certain investments and declining valuations of others.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Governments have taken unprecedented actions intended to address these market conditions and the extent to which such government actions may prove effective remains unclear.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	The future economic environment may worsen.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Our industry is affected by changes in economic conditions outside our control, which can result in a general decrease in product demand from our customers.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Such economic developments may affect our business in a number of ways.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Reduced demand may drive us and our competitors to offer products at promotional prices, which would have a negative impact on our profitability.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P3_S3	In addition, the current tightening of credit in financial markets may adversely affect the ability of our customers and suppliers to obtain financing for significant purchases and operations and could result in a decrease in, or cancellation of, orders for our products.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P3_S4	If demand for our products slows down or decreases, we will not be able to improve our revenues and we may run the risk of failing to satisfy the financial and other restrictive covenants to which we are subject under our existing indebtedness.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Reduced revenues as a result of decreased demand may also reduce our planned growth and otherwise hinder our ability to improve our performance in connection with our long term strategy.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Our business is cyclical and is affected by industrial economic conditions, and, during the global recession in fiscal 2009 and fiscal 2010 we experienced substantially reduced demand for our products.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Many of the end-users of our products are in highly cyclical industries that are sensitive to changes in general economic conditions.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Their demand for our products, and thus our results of operations, is directly related to the level of production in their facilities, their construction and capital expenditure budgets, changes in their vertical market sectors and other factors beyond our control.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P5_S2	In the fiscal years ended March 31, 2009 and 2010, for example, we experienced significantly reduced demand for our products, generally as a result of the global economic slowdown.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P5_S3	These lower levels of demand resulted in a 20% decline in net sales from our 2008 fiscal year to our 2010 fiscal year, from $593,800,000 to $476,100,000, despite our acquisition of Pfaff in the middle of our 2009 fiscal year.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P5_S4	This decline in net sales resulted in a 105% decrease in our income from operations during the same period.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	We have seen improvement in demand for our products in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2011.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Our net sales for the year ended March 31, 2011 were $524,065,000, up $47,882,000 or 10.1% from the year ending March 31, 2010.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P6_S2	However, there is no certainty that this improvement will continue in the future.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Our business is highly competitive and subject to consolidation of competitors.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Increased competition could reduce our sales, earnings, and profitability.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The principal markets that we serve within the material handling industry are fragmented and highly competitive.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Competition is based primarily on customer service and support as well as product availability, performance, functionality, brand reputation, reliability and price.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Our competition in the markets in which we participate comes from companies of various sizes, some of which have greater financial and other resources than we do.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Increased competition could force us to lower our prices or to offer additional services at a higher cost to us, which could reduce our gross margins and net income.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	The greater financial resources or the lower amount of debt of certain of our competitors may enable them to commit larger amounts of capital in response to changing market conditions.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P9_S1	Certain competitors may also have the ability to develop product or service innovations that could put us at a disadvantage.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P9_S2	In addition, through consolidation, some of our competitors have achieved substantially more market penetration in certain of the markets in which we operate.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P9_S3	If we are unable to compete successfully against other manufacturers of material handling equipment, we could lose customers and our revenues may decline.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P9_S4	There can also be no assurance that customers will continue to regard our products favorably, that we will be able to develop new products that appeal to customers, that we will be able to improve or maintain our profit margins on sales to our customers or that we will be able to continue to compete successfully in our core markets.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our operations outside the U.S. pose certain risks that may adversely impact sales and earnings.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We have operations and assets located outside of the United States, primarily in China, Mexico, Germany, the United Kingdom, France, and Hungary.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P11_S1	In addition, we import a portion of our hoist product line from Asia, and sell our products to distributors located in approximately 50 countries.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P11_S2	In our fiscal year ended March 31, 2011, approximately 46% of our net sales were derived from non-U.S. markets.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P11_S3	These non-U.S. operations are subject to a number of special risks, in addition to the risks of our U.S. business, differing protections of intellectual property, trade barriers, labor unrest, exchange controls, regional economic uncertainty, differing (and possibly more stringent) labor regulation, risk of governmental expropriation, U.S. and foreign customs and tariffs, current and changing regulatory environments, difficulty in obtaining distribution support, difficulty in staffing and managing widespread operations, differences in the availability and terms of financing, political instability and risks of increases in taxes.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Also, in some foreign jurisdictions we may be subject to laws limiting the right and ability of entities organized or operating therein to pay dividends or remit earnings to affiliated companies unless specified conditions are met.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P11_S5	These factors may adversely affect our future profits.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Part of our strategy is to expand our worldwide market share and reduce costs by strengthening our international distribution capabilities and sourcing basic components in lower cost countries, in particular in China and Hungary.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Implementation of this strategy may increase the impact of the risks described above, and we cannot assure you that such risks will not have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Our strategy depends on successful integration of acquisitions.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Acquisitions are a key part of our growth strategy.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Our historical growth has depended, and our future growth is likely to depend on our ability to successfully implement our acquisition strategy, and the successful integration of acquired businesses into our existing operations.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P14_S2	We intend to continue to seek additional acquisition opportunities in accordance with our acquisition strategy, both to expand into new markets and to enhance our position in existing markets throughout the world.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P14_S3	If we are unable to successfully integrate acquired businesses into our existing operations or expand into new markets, our sales and earnings growth could be reduced.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Our products involve risks of personal injury and property damage, which exposes us to potential liability.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Our business exposes us to possible claims for personal injury or death and property damage resulting from the products that we sell.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P16_S1	We maintain insurance through a combination of self-insurance retentions and excess insurance coverage.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P16_S2	We monitor claims and potential claims of which we become aware and establish accrued liability reserves for the self-insurance amounts based on our liability estimates for such claims.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P16_S3	We cannot give any assurance that existing or future claims will not exceed our estimates for self-insurance or the amount of our excess insurance coverage.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P16_S4	In addition, we cannot give any assurance that insurance will continue to be available to us on economically reasonable terms or that our insurers would not require us to increase our self-insurance amounts.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P16_S5	Claims brought against us that are not covered by insurance or that are in excess of insurance coverage could have a material adverse effect on our results, financial condition, or liquidity.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	In addition, like many industrial manufacturers, we are also involved in asbestos-related litigation.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P17_S1	In continually evaluating costs relating to our estimated asbestos-related liability, we review, among other things, the incidence of past and recent claims, the historical case dismissal rate, the mix of the claimed illnesses and occupations of the plaintiffs, our recent and historical resolution of the cases, the number of cases pending against us, the status and results of broad-based settlement discussions, and the number of years such activity might continue.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P17_S2	Based on this review, we estimate our share of liability to defend and resolve probable asbestos related personal injury claims.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P17_S3	This estimate is highly uncertain due to the limitations of the available data and the difficulty of forecasting with any certainty the numerous variables that can affect the range of the liability.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P17_S4	We continue to study the variables in light of additional information in order to identify trends that may become evident and to assess their impact on the range of liability that is probable and estimable.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P17_S5	We believe that the potential additional costs for claims will not have a material after-tax effect on our financial condition or liquidity, although the net after-tax effect of any future liabilities recorded could be material to earnings in a future period.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P17_S6	See Note 16 to our March 31, 2011 consolidated financial statements incorporated herein by reference.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	As indicated above, our self-insurance coverage is effected through our captive insurance subsidiary.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P18_S1	The reserves of our captive insurance subsidiary are subject to periodic adjustments based upon actuarial evaluations, which adjustments impact our overall results of operations.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P18_S2	These periodic adjustments can be favorable or unfavorable.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We are subject to currency fluctuations from our sales outside the U.S..
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Our products are sold in many countries around the world.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Thus, a portion of our revenues (approximately $241,970,000 in our fiscal year ended March 31, 2011) are generated in foreign currencies, including principally the euro and the Canadian dollar, and while much of the costs incurred to generate those revenues are incurred in the same currency, a portion is incurred in other currencies.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Since our financial statements are denominated in U.S. dollars, changes in currency exchange rates between the U.S. dollar and other currencies have had, and will continue to have, a currency translation impact on our earnings.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Currency fluctuations may impact our financial performance in the future.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Our future operating results may be affected by fluctuations in steel or other material prices.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P22_S1	We may not be able to pass on increases in raw material costs to our customers.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	The principal raw material used in our chain, forging and crane building operations is steel.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P23_S1	The steel industry as a whole is highly cyclical, and at times pricing and availability can be volatile due to a number of factors beyond our control, including general economic conditions, labor costs, competition, import duties, tariffs and currency exchange rates.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P23_S2	This volatility can significantly affect our raw material costs.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P23_S3	In an environment of increasing raw material prices, competitive conditions will determine how much of the steel price increases we can pass on to our customers.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P23_S4	During historical rising cost periods, we were generally successful in adding and maintaining a surcharge to the prices of our high steel content products or incorporating them into price increases, with a goal of margin neutrality.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P23_S5	In the future, to the extent we are unable to pass on any steel price increases to our customers, our profitability could be adversely affected.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	We rely in large part on independent distributors for sales of our products.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P25_S0	For the most part, we depend on independent distributors to sell our products and provide service and aftermarket support to our end-user customers.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Distributors play a significant role in determining which of our products are stocked at the branch locations, and hence are most readily accessible to aftermarket buyers, and the price at which these products are sold.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Almost all of the distributors with whom we transact business offer competitive products and services to our end-user customers.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P25_S3	For the most part, we do not have written agreements with our distributors.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P25_S4	The loss of a substantial number of these distributors or an increase in the distributors' sales of our competitors' products to our ultimate customers could materially reduce our sales and profits.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P26_S0	We are subject to various environmental laws which may require us to expend significant capital and incur substantial cost.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Our operations and facilities are subject to various federal, state, local and foreign requirements relating to the protection of the environment, including those governing the discharges of pollutants in the air and water, the generation, management and disposal of hazardous substances and wastes and the cleanup of contaminated sites.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P27_S1	We have made, and will continue to make, expenditures to comply with such requirements.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Violations of, or liabilities under, environmental laws and regulations, or changes in such laws and regulations (such as the imposition of more stringent standards for discharges into the environment), could result in substantial costs to us, including operating costs and capital expenditures, fines and civil and criminal sanctions, third party claims for property damage or personal injury, clean-up costs or costs relating to the temporary or permanent discontinuance of operations.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Certain of our facilities have been in operation for many years, and we have remediated contamination at some of our facilities.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P28_S1	Over time, we and other predecessor operators of such facilities have generated, used, handled and disposed of hazardous and other regulated wastes.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P28_S2	Additional environmental liabilities could exist, including clean-up obligations at these locations or other sites at which materials from our operations were disposed, which could result in substantial future expenditures that cannot be currently quantified and which could reduce our profits or have an adverse effect on our financial condition, operations, or liquidity.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	We rely on subcontractors or suppliers to perform their contractual obligations.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Some of our contracts involve subcontracts with other companies upon which we rely to perform a portion of the services we must provide to our customers.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P30_S1	There is a risk that we may have disputes with our subcontractors, including disputes regarding the quality and timeliness of work performed by our subcontractor or customer concerns about the subcontractor.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P30_S2	Failure by our subcontractors to satisfactorily provide on a timely basis the agreed-upon supplies or perform the agreed upon services may materially and adversely impact our ability to perform our obligations as the prime contractor.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P30_S3	A delay in our ability to obtain components and equipment parts from our suppliers may affect our ability to meet our customers' needs and may have an adverse effect upon our profitability.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P31_S0	We are subject to debt covenant restrictions.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Our revolving credit facility contains, and the indenture governing the notes will contain, several financial and other restrictive covenants.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P32_S1	A significant decline in our operating income or cash generating ability could cause us to violate our leverage or fixed charge coverage ratios in our bank credit facility.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P32_S2	This could result in our being unable to borrow under our bank credit facility or being obliged to refinance and renegotiate the terms of our bank indebtedness.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P33_S0	We depend on our senior management team and the loss of any member could adversely affect our operations.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Our success is dependent on the management and leadership skills of our senior management team.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P34_S1	The loss of any of these individuals or an inability to attract, retain and maintain additional personnel could prevent us from implementing our business strategy.
1005229_11_ITEM1A_P34_S2	We cannot assure you that we will be able to retain our existing senior management personnel or to attract additional qualified personnel when needed.

1005229_11_ITEM6_P4_S0	During 2011, the Company recorded non-cash charge of $42,983,000 included within its provision for income taxes.
1005229_11_ITEM6_P4_S1	The majority of this charge relates to the Company s determination that a full valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets generated in the U.S is necessary.
1005229_11_ITEM6_P5_S0	Accounting rules require a reduction of the carrying amounts of deferred tax assets by a valuation allowance if, based on the available and objectively verifiable evidence, it is more likely than not that such assets will not be realized.
1005229_11_ITEM6_P6_S0	The existence of cumulative losses for a certain threshold period is a significant form of negative evidence used in the assessment.
1005229_11_ITEM6_P6_S1	If a cumulative loss threshold is met, the accounting rules indicate that forecasts of future profitability are generally not sufficient positive evidence to overcome the presumption that a valuation allowance is necessary.

1005229_11_ITEM7_P0_S0	This section should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this annual report.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P0_S1	Comments on the results of operations and financial condition below refer to our continuing operations, except in the section entitled Discontinued Operations.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	We are a leading worldwide designer, manufacturer and marketer of material handling products, systems and services which efficiently and safely move, lift, position or secure material.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P1_S1	Key products include hoists, actuators, cranes and lifting and rigging tools.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P1_S2	The Company is focused on commercial and industrial applications that require the safety and quality provided by its superior design and engineering know-how.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	Founded in 1875, we have grown to our current size and leadership position through organic growth and acquisitions.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P2_S1	We developed our leading market position over our 136-year history by emphasizing technological innovation, manufacturing excellence and superior after-sale service.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P2_S2	In addition, acquisitions significantly broadened our product lines and services and expanded our geographic reach, end-user markets and customer base.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P2_S3	Ongoing initiatives include improving our productivity and increasing penetration of the Asian, Latin American and European marketplaces.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P2_S4	In accordance with our strategy, we have been investing in our directed sales and marketing activities, new product development and Lean efforts across the Company.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P2_S5	Shareholder value will be enhanced through continued emphasis on improvement of the fundamentals including market expansion, a high degree of customer satisfaction, new product development, manufacturing efficiency, cost containment, and efficient capital investment.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	Over the course of our history, we have managed through many business cycles and our strong cash flow profile has helped us grow and expand globally.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P3_S1	We stand with a strong capital structure which includes sufficient cash reserves, significant revolver availability with an expiration of May 2013, fixed-rate long-term debt which expires in 2019 and a strong cash flow business profile.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P3_S2	We believe our liquidity strength and operational cost management actions have enabled us to withstand the recent global economic downturn.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P3_S3	During fiscal 2010 we initiated projects to strategically reorganize our North American hoist and rigging operations, which were essentially completed during the first quarter of fiscal 2011.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P3_S4	The projects included the closure of two manufacturing facilities and the significant downsizing of a third facility.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P3_S5	The closures and downsizing resulted in a reduction of approximately 500,000 square feet of manufacturing space (or approximately 25% of total manufacturing space) and we expect to generate annual savings estimated at approximately $15,000,000.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	Additionally our revenue base is now more geographically diverse than at any time in our Company s history, with approximately 46% derived from customers outside the U.S. in fiscal 2011.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	We believe this will help balance the impact of changes that will occur in different global economies at different times.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	As in the past, we monitor both U.S. and Eurozone Industrial Capacity Utilization statistics as indicators of anticipated demand for our product.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	Since their June 2009 trough, these statistics have consistently improved through April 2011.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P5_S2	In addition, we continue to monitor the potential impact of other global and U.S. trends including industrial production, energy costs, steel price fluctuations, interest rates, currency exchange and activity of end-user markets around the globe.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	From a strategic perspective, we are investing in global markets and new products as we focus on our greatest opportunities for growth.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P6_S1	We maintain a strong North American market share with significant leading market positions in hoists, lifting and sling chain, forged attachments and actuators.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P6_S2	We seek to maintain and enhance our market share by continuing and focusing our sales and marketing activities directed toward select North American and global market sectors including energy, construction, entertainment, mining and food processing.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P6_S3	Our fiscal 2009 acquisition of Pfaff is enhancing our European market penetration as well as strengthening our global actuator offering.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P6_S4	Further, we continue to invest in emerging market penetration, including the geographic regions of Asia, Latin America, and Eastern Europe.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P6_S5	We complement these activities with continued investments in new product development, particularly products with global reach.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	Regardless of the economic climate and point in the economic cycle, we constantly explore ways to manage our operating margins as well as further improve our productivity and competitiveness.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	We have specific initiatives related to improved customer satisfaction, reduction of defects, shortened lead times, improved inventory turns and on-time deliveries, reduction of warranty costs, and improved working capital utilization.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P7_S2	The initiatives are being driven by the continued implementation of our Lean efforts which are fundamentally changing our manufacturing and business processes to be more responsive to customer demand and improving on-time delivery and productivity.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P7_S3	In addition to Lean, we are working to achieve these strategic initiatives through product simplification, the creation of centers of excellence, and improved supply chain management.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	We continuously monitor market prices of steel.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	We purchase approximately $25,000,000 to $35,000,000 of steel annually in a variety of forms including rod, wire, bar, structural and others.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	Generally, as we experience fluctuations in our costs, we reflect them as price increases or surcharges to our customers with the goal of being margin neutral.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P9_S1	Some of our steel costs have increased during this quarter primarily with regards to forged bar as the result of higher scrap and alloy surcharges.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	We are also looking for opportunities for growth via strategic acquisitions or joint ventures.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	The focus of our acquisition strategy centers on opportunities for international market penetration and product line expansion in alignment with our existing core product offering.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	We operate in a highly competitive and global business environment, and we are effectively managing through a global economic cycle.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	We face a variety of opportunities in those markets and geographies, including trends toward increased utilization of the global labor force and the expansion of market opportunities in Asia and other emerging markets.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P11_S2	While we continue to execute our long-term growth strategy, we have weathered the current economic cycle with our strong capital structure, including a solid cash position and flexible cost base, aggressively addressing costs and restructuring to enhance future margin opportunities.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	Fiscal 2011 sales were $524,065,000, up 10.1%, or $47,882,000 compared with fiscal 2010.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P12_S1	The increase in sales was primarily due to an increase of $52,785,000 in volume resulting from the economic recovery and market share gains.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P12_S2	Further, price increases resulted in a $4,651,000 increase in sales.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P12_S3	These increases were offset by a reduction of sales of $2,695,000 from the October 2009 divestiture of our American Lifts business as well as a negative foreign currency impact of $6,828,000.

1005229_11_ITEM7_P12_S5	Our Pfaff acquisition contributed $71,500,000 to our sales for fiscal 2010 with the remaining business being down 28.1%, or $158,000,000, excluding Pfaff.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P12_S6	The decline in sales was primarily due to volume decline resulting from the global economic slow down.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P12_S7	The divestiture of our American Lift business as well as fewer shipping days also contributed to lower sales in FY 2010 by approximately $5,000,000 but was partially offset by favorable foreign currency impact of approximately $3,500,000.

1005229_11_ITEM7_P48_S0	Our costs are affected by inflation in the U.S. economy and, to a lesser extent, in non-U.S. economies including those of Europe, Canada, Mexico, South America and Asia-Pacific.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P48_S1	We do not believe that general inflation has had a material effect on our results of operations over the periods presented primarily due to overall low inflation levels over such periods and our ability to generally pass on rising costs through annual price increases and surcharges.

1005229_11_ITEM7_P49_S0	In the future, we may be further affected by inflation that we may not be able to pass on as price increases.

1005229_11_ITEM7_P52_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in our consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.

1005229_11_ITEM7_P53_S0	Sales are recorded when title passes to the customer which is generally at the time of shipment to the customer.

1005229_11_ITEM7_P53_S2	The credit risk is controlled through credit approvals, limits and monitoring procedures.

1005229_11_ITEM7_P53_S4	The Company establishes an allowance for doubtful accounts based upon factors surrounding the credit risk of specific customers, historical trends and other factors.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P53_S5	Accounts receivable are charged against the allowance for doubtful accounts once all collection efforts have been exhausted.

1005229_11_ITEM7_P54_S0	Pension and Other Postretirement Benefits .
1005229_11_ITEM7_P55_S0	The determination of the obligations and expense for pension and postretirement benefits is dependent on our selection of certain assumptions that are used by actuaries in calculating such amounts.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P55_S1	Those assumptions are disclosed in Note 13 to our fiscal 2011 consolidated financial statements and include the discount rates, expected long-term rate of return on plan assets and rates of future increases in compensation and healthcare costs.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P56_S0	The pension discount rate assumptions of 5.75%, 6%, and 7.25, as of March 31, 2011, 2010, and 2009, respectively, are primarily based on long-term AA rated corporate bond rates.

1005229_11_ITEM7_P56_S2	The decrease in the discount rates for fiscal 2010 resulted in an $33,900,000 increase in the projected benefit obligation as of March 31, 2010.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P56_S3	The rate of return on plan assets assumptions of 7.5% for each of the years ended March 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 is based on the targeted plan asset allocation (approximately 70% equities and 30% fixed income) and their long-term historical returns.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P56_S4	Investment gains of $15,010,000 in fiscal 2011 and $30,549,000 in fiscal 2010 with the fiscal 2011 decrease a result of less volatility in US capital markets in fiscal 2011.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P56_S5	Our under-funded status for all pension plans as of March 31, 2011 and 2010 was $32,366,000 and $36,782,000, or 18.2% and 21.8% of the projected benefit obligation, respectively.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P56_S6	Our pension contributions during fiscal 2011 and 2010 were approximately $7,796,000 and $18,026,000, respectively.
1005229_11_ITEM7_P56_S7	The under-funded status may result in future pension expense increases.
