1005229_12_ITEM1_P88_S1	Approximately 13% of our employees are represented under four separate U.S. or Canadian collective bargaining agreements which terminate at various times between August 2013 and April 2015.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P88_S2	We also have various labor agreements with our non-U.S. employees which we negotiate from time to time.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P88_S3	We believe that our relationship with our employees is good and that the risk of a disruption in production related to these negotiations is remote.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P89_S0	Our principal raw materials and components are steel, consisting of structural steel, processed steel bar, forging bar steel, steel rod and wire, steel pipe and tubing and tool steel; electric motors; bearings; gear reducers; castings; and electro-mechanical components.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P89_S1	These commodities are all available from multiple sources.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P89_S2	We purchase most of these raw materials and components from a limited number of strategic and preferred suppliers under long-term agreements which are negotiated on a company-wide basis through our Purchasing Council to take advantage of volume discounts.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P89_S3	We generally seek to pass on materials price increases to our distribution channel partners and end-user customers.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P89_S4	We will continue to monitor our costs and reevaluate our pricing policies.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P89_S5	Our ability to pass on these increases is determined by market conditions.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P90_S0	We use derivative instruments to manage selected foreign currency exposures.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P90_S1	The Company does not use derivative instruments for speculative trading purposes.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P91_S0	We use foreign currency forward agreements and cross-currency swaps to offset changes in the value of intercompany loans to certain foreign subsidiaries due to changes in foreign exchange rates.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P91_S1	In addition, we use foreign currency forward agreements to i) hedge changes in the value of booked foreign currency liabilities due to changes in foreign exchange rates at the settlement date and ii) to hedge a portion of forecasted inventory purchases and sales denominated in a foreign currency.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P92_S0	We complement our own manufacturing by outsourcing components and finished goods from an established global network of suppliers.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P92_S1	We regularly upgrade our global manufacturing facilities and invest in tooling, equipment and technology.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P92_S2	In 2001, we began implementing Lean improvement techniques in our business which has resulted in inventory reductions in required manufacturing floor area, shorter product lead time and increased productivity.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P93_S0	Our manufacturing operations are highly integrated.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P93_S1	Although raw materials and some components such as motors, bearings, gear reducers, castings and electro-mechanical components are purchased, our vertical integration enables us to produce many of the components used in the manufacturing of our products.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P93_S2	We manufacture hoist lifting chain, steel forged gear blanks, lift wheels, trolley wheels, and hooks and other attachments for incorporation into our hoist products.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P93_S3	These products are also sold as spare parts for hoist repair.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P93_S4	Additionally, our hoists are used as components in the manufacture of crane systems by us as well as our crane-builder customers.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P94_S0	Like most manufacturing companies, we are subject to various federal, state and local laws relating to the protection of the environment.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P94_S1	To address the requirements of such laws, we have adopted a corporate environmental protection policy which provides that all of our owned or leased facilities shall, and all of our employees have the duty to, comply with all applicable environmental regulatory standards, and we have initiated an environmental auditing program for our facilities to ensure compliance with such regulatory standards.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P94_S2	We have also established managerial responsibilities and internal communication channels for dealing with environmental compliance issues that may arise in the course of our business.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P94_S3	We have made and could be required to continue to make significant expenditures to comply with environmental requirements.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P94_S4	Because of the complexity and changing nature of environmental regulatory standards, it is possible that situations will arise from time to time requiring us to incur additional expenditures in order to ensure environmental regulatory compliance.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P94_S5	However, we are not aware of any environmental condition or any operation at any of our facilities, either individually or in the aggregate, which would cause expenditures having a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition or cash flows and, accordingly, have not budgeted any material capital expenditures for environmental compliance for fiscal 2013.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P95_S0	We notified the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources (the DENR ) in April 2006 of the presence of certain contaminants in excess of regulatory standards at our Coffing Hoist facility in Wadesboro, North Carolina.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P95_S1	We filed an application with the DENR to enter its voluntary cleanup program and were accepted.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P95_S2	We investigated under the supervision of a DENR Registered Environmental Consultant ( the REC ) and have commenced voluntary clean-up at the facility.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P95_S3	At this time, additional remediation costs are not expected to exceed the accrued balance of $200,000.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P96_S0	In March of 2007, we also discovered the presence of certain contaminants in excess of regulatory standards at our Damascus, Virginia hoist plant and have notified the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality (the DEQ ).
1005229_12_ITEM1_P96_S1	We filed an application with the DEQ to participate in its voluntary remediation program and have been accepted.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P96_S2	We are currently investigating under the terms of the DEQ Voluntary Remediation Program and, if appropriate, will remediate site conditions at the facility.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P96_S3	At this time, investigative and remediation costs are not expected to be significant.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P97_S0	In June of 2007, we were identified by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation ( the DEC ), along with other companies, as a potential responsible party ( PRP ) at the Frontier Chemical Royal Avenue Site in Niagara Falls, New York.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P98_S0	From 1974 to 1992, the Frontier Royal Avenue Site had been operated as a commercial waste treatment and disposal facility.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P98_S1	We sent waste sulfuric acid pickling solution generated at our facility in Tonawanda, New York to the Frontier Royal Avenue Site during the period from approximately 1982 to 1984.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P98_S2	We have joined with other PRP members known as the Frontier Chemical Site Joint Defense Alliance Group to conduct investigation and, if appropriate, remediation activities at the site.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P98_S3	We do not believe that such costs will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating results or cash flows.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P99_S0	For all of the currently known environmental matters, we have accrued a total of $356,000 as of March 31, 2012 which, in our opinion, is sufficient to deal with such matters.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P99_S1	Further, we believe that the environmental matters known to, or anticipated by us should not, individually or in the aggregate, have a material adverse effect on our operating results or financial condition.
1005229_12_ITEM1_P99_S2	However, there can be no assurance that potential liabilities and expenditures associated with unknown environmental matters, unanticipated events, or future compliance with environmental laws and regulations will not have a material adverse effect on us.

1005229_12_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Columbus McKinnon is subject to a number of risk factors that could negatively affect our results from business operations or cause actual results to differ materially from those projected or indicated in any forward looking statement.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Such factors include, but are not limited to, the following:
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Adverse changes in global economic conditions may negatively affect our industry, business and results of operations.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Financial markets in the United States, Europe and Asia have experienced substantial disruption including, among other things, extreme volatility in security prices, severely diminished liquidity and credit availability, rating downgrades of certain investments and declining valuations of others.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Governments have taken unprecedented actions intended to address these market conditions and the extent to which such government actions may prove effective remains unclear.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P2_S2	The future economic environment may worsen.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Our industry is affected by changes in economic conditions outside our control, which can result in a general decrease in product demand from our customers.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Such economic developments may affect our business in a number of ways.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Reduced demand may drive us and our competitors to offer products at promotional prices, which would have a negative impact on our profitability.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P3_S3	In addition, the tightening of credit in financial markets may adversely affect the ability of our customers and suppliers to obtain financing for significant purchases and operations and could result in a decrease in, or cancellation of, orders for our products.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P3_S4	If demand for our products slows down or decreases, we will not be able to improve our revenues and we may run the risk of failing to satisfy the financial and other restrictive covenants to which we are subject under our existing indebtedness.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Reduced revenues as a result of decreased demand may also reduce our planned growth and otherwise hinder our ability to improve our performance in connection with our long term strategy.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Our business is cyclical and is affected by industrial economic conditions, and, during the global recession in fiscal 2009 and fiscal 2010 we experienced substantially reduced demand for our products.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Many of the end-users of our products are in highly cyclical industries that are sensitive to changes in general economic conditions.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Their demand for our products, and thus our results of operations, is directly related to the level of production in their facilities, their construction and capital expenditure budgets, changes in their vertical market sectors and other factors beyond our control.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P5_S2	In the fiscal years ended March 31, 2009 and 2010, for example, we experienced significantly reduced demand for our products, generally as a result of the global economic slowdown.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P5_S3	These lower levels of demand resulted in a 20% decline in net sales from our 2008 fiscal year to our 2010 fiscal year, from $593,800,000 to $476,100,000, despite our acquisition of Pfaff in the middle of our 2009 fiscal year.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P5_S4	This decline in net sales resulted in a 105% decrease in our income from operations during the same period.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	We have seen improvement in demand for our products in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2012.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Our net sales for the year ended March 31, 2012 were $591,945,000, up $67,880,000 or 13.0% from the year ending March 31, 2011.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P6_S2	However, there is no certainty that this improvement will continue in the future.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Our business is highly competitive and subject to consolidation of competitors.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Increased competition could reduce our sales, earnings, and profitability.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The principal markets that we serve within the material handling industry are fragmented and highly competitive.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Competition is based primarily on customer service and support as well as product availability, performance, functionality, brand reputation, reliability and price.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Our competition in the markets in which we participate comes from companies of various sizes, some of which have greater financial and other resources than we do.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Increased competition could force us to lower our prices or to offer additional services at a higher cost to us, which could reduce our gross margins and net income.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P9_S0	The greater financial resources or the lower amount of debt of certain of our competitors may enable them to commit larger amounts of capital in response to changing market conditions.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P9_S1	Certain competitors may also have the ability to develop product or service innovations that could put us at a disadvantage.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P9_S2	In addition, through consolidation, some of our competitors have achieved substantially more market penetration in certain of the markets in which we operate.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P9_S3	If we are unable to compete successfully against other manufacturers of material handling equipment, we could lose customers and our revenues may decline.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P9_S4	There can also be no assurance that customers will continue to regard our products favorably, that we will be able to develop new products that appeal to customers, that we will be able to improve or maintain our profit margins on sales to our customers or that we will be able to continue to compete successfully in our core markets.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our operations outside the U.S. pose certain risks that may adversely impact sales and earnings.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We have operations and assets located outside of the United States, primarily in China, Mexico, Germany, the United Kingdom, France, and Hungary.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P11_S1	In addition, we import a portion of our hoist product line from Asia, and sell our products to distributors located in approximately 50 countries.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P11_S2	In our fiscal year ended March 31, 2012, approximately 45% of our net sales were derived from non-U.S. markets.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P11_S3	These non-U.S. operations are subject to a number of special risks, in addition to the risks of our U.S. business, differing protections of intellectual property, trade barriers, labor unrest, exchange controls, regional economic uncertainty, differing (and possibly more stringent) labor regulation, risk of governmental expropriation, U.S. and foreign customs and tariffs, current and changing regulatory environments, difficulty in obtaining distribution support, difficulty in staffing and managing widespread operations, differences in the availability and terms of financing, political instability and risks of increases in taxes.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Also, in some foreign jurisdictions we may be subject to laws limiting the right and ability of entities organized or operating therein to pay dividends or remit earnings to affiliated companies unless specified conditions are met.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P11_S5	These factors may adversely affect our future profits.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Part of our strategy is to expand our worldwide market share and reduce costs by strengthening our international distribution capabilities and sourcing basic components in lower cost countries, in particular in China and Hungary.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Implementation of this strategy may increase the impact of the risks described above, and we cannot assure you that such risks will not have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Our strategy depends on successful integration of acquisitions.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Acquisitions are a key part of our growth strategy.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Our historical growth has depended, and our future growth is likely to depend on our ability to successfully implement our acquisition strategy, and the successful integration of acquired businesses into our existing operations.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P14_S2	We intend to continue to seek additional acquisition opportunities in accordance with our acquisition strategy, both to expand into new markets and to enhance our position in existing markets throughout the world.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P14_S3	If we are unable to successfully integrate acquired businesses into our existing operations or expand into new markets, our sales and earnings growth could be reduced.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Our products involve risks of personal injury and property damage, which exposes us to potential liability.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Our business exposes us to possible claims for personal injury or death and property damage resulting from the products that we sell.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P16_S1	We maintain insurance through a combination of self-insurance retentions and excess insurance coverage.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P16_S2	We monitor claims and potential claims of which we become aware and establish accrued liability reserves for the self-insurance amounts based on our liability estimates for such claims.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P16_S3	We cannot give any assurance that existing or future claims will not exceed our estimates for self-insurance or the amount of our excess insurance coverage.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P16_S4	In addition, we cannot give any assurance that insurance will continue to be available to us on economically reasonable terms or that our insurers would not require us to increase our self-insurance amounts.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P16_S5	Claims brought against us that are not covered by insurance or that are in excess of insurance coverage could have a material adverse effect on our results, financial condition, or liquidity.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P17_S0	In addition, like many industrial manufacturers, we are also involved in asbestos-related litigation.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P17_S1	In continually evaluating costs relating to our estimated asbestos-related liability, we review, among other things, the incidence of past and recent claims, the historical case dismissal rate, the mix of the claimed illnesses and occupations of the plaintiffs, our recent and historical resolution of the cases, the number of cases pending against us, the status and results of broad-based settlement discussions, and the number of years such activity might continue.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P17_S2	Based on this review, we estimate our share of liability to defend and resolve probable asbestos related personal injury claims.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P17_S3	This estimate is highly uncertain due to the limitations of the available data and the difficulty of forecasting with any certainty the numerous variables that can affect the range of the liability.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P17_S4	We continue to study the variables in light of additional information in order to identify trends that may become evident and to assess their impact on the range of liability that is probable and estimable.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P17_S5	We believe that the potential additional costs for claims will not have a material after-tax effect on our financial condition or liquidity, although the net after-tax effect of any future liabilities recorded could be material to earnings in a future period.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P17_S6	See Note 16 to our March 31, 2012 consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this form 10K.

1005229_12_ITEM1A_P18_S2	These periodic adjustments can be favorable or unfavorable.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We are subject to currency fluctuations from our sales outside the U.S.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Our products are sold in many countries around the world.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Thus, a portion of our revenues (approximately $268,654,000 in our fiscal year ended March 31, 2012) are generated in foreign currencies, including principally the euro and the Canadian dollar, and while much of the costs incurred to generate those revenues are incurred in the same currency, a portion is incurred in other currencies.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Since our financial statements are denominated in U.S. dollars, changes in currency exchange rates between the U.S. dollar and other currencies have had, and will continue to have, a currency translation impact on our earnings.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Currency fluctuations may impact our financial performance in the future.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Our future operating results may be affected by fluctuations in steel or other material prices.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P22_S1	We may not be able to pass on increases in raw material costs to our customers.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P23_S0	The principal raw material used in our chain, forging and crane building operations is steel.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P23_S1	The steel industry as a whole is highly cyclical, and at times pricing and availability can be volatile due to a number of factors beyond our control, including general economic conditions, labor costs, competition, import duties, tariffs and currency exchange rates.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P23_S2	This volatility can significantly affect our raw material costs.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P23_S3	In an environment of increasing raw material prices, competitive conditions will determine how much of the steel price increases we can pass on to our customers.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P23_S4	During historical rising cost periods, we were generally successful in adding and maintaining a surcharge to the prices of our high steel content products or incorporating them into price increases, with a goal of margin neutrality.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P23_S5	In the future, to the extent we are unable to pass on any steel price increases to our customers, our profitability could be adversely affected.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P24_S0	We rely in large part on independent distributors for sales of our products.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P25_S0	For the most part, we depend on independent distributors to sell our products and provide service and aftermarket support to our end-user customers.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Distributors play a significant role in determining which of our products are stocked at the branch locations, and hence are most readily accessible to aftermarket buyers, and the price at which these products are sold.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Almost all of the distributors with whom we transact business offer competitive products and services to our end-user customers.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P25_S3	For the most part, we do not have written agreements with our distributors.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P25_S4	The loss of a substantial number of these distributors or an increase in the distributors' sales of our competitors' products to our ultimate customers could materially reduce our sales and profits.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P26_S0	We are subject to various environmental laws which may require us to expend significant capital and incur substantial cost.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Our operations and facilities are subject to various federal, state, local and foreign requirements relating to the protection of the environment, including those governing the discharges of pollutants in the air and water, the generation, management and disposal of hazardous substances and wastes and the cleanup of contaminated sites.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P27_S1	We have made, and will continue to make, expenditures to comply with such requirements.

1005229_12_ITEM1A_P30_S3	A delay in our ability to obtain components and equipment parts from our suppliers may affect our ability to meet our customers' needs and may have an adverse effect upon our profitability.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P31_S0	We are subject to debt covenant restrictions.

1005229_12_ITEM1A_P32_S2	This could result in our being unable to borrow under our bank credit facility or being obliged to refinance and renegotiate the terms of our bank indebtedness.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P33_S0	We depend on our senior management team and the loss of any member could adversely affect our operations.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Our success is dependent on the management and leadership skills of our senior management team.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P34_S1	The loss of any of these individuals or an inability to attract, retain and maintain additional personnel could prevent us from implementing our business strategy.
1005229_12_ITEM1A_P34_S2	We cannot assure you that we will be able to retain our existing senior management personnel or to attract additional qualified personnel when needed.

1005229_12_ITEM6_P4_S0	During 2011, the Company recorded non-cash charge of $42,983,000 included within its provision for income taxes.
1005229_12_ITEM6_P4_S1	The majority of this charge relates to the Company s determination that a full valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets generated in the U.S is necessary.
1005229_12_ITEM6_P5_S0	Accounting rules require a reduction of the carrying amounts of deferred tax assets by a valuation allowance if, based on the available and objectively verifiable evidence, it is more likely than not that such assets will not be realized.
1005229_12_ITEM6_P6_S0	The existence of cumulative losses for a certain threshold period is a significant form of negative evidence used in the assessment.
1005229_12_ITEM6_P6_S1	If a cumulative loss threshold is met, the accounting rules indicate that forecasts of future profitability are generally not sufficient positive evidence to overcome the presumption that a valuation allowance is necessary.

1005229_12_ITEM7_P0_S0	This section should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this annual report.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P0_S1	Comments on the results of operations and financial condition below refer to our continuing operations, except in the section entitled Discontinued Operations.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P1_S0	We are a leading worldwide designer, manufacturer and marketer of material handling products, systems and services which efficiently and safely move, lift, position and secure material.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P1_S1	Key products include hoists, actuators, cranes and rigging tools.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P1_S2	The Company is focused on serving commercial and industrial applications that require the safety and quality provided by the Company s superior design and engineering know-how.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P2_S0	Founded in 1875, we have grown to our current size and leadership position through organic growth and acquisitions.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P2_S1	We developed our leading market position over our 137-year history by emphasizing technological innovation, manufacturing excellence and superior after-sale service.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P2_S2	In addition, acquisitions significantly broadened our product lines and services and expanded our geographic reach, end-user markets and customer base.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P2_S3	Ongoing initiatives include improving our productivity and increasing penetration of the Asian, Latin American and European marketplaces.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P2_S4	In accordance with our strategy, we have been investing in our directed sales and marketing activities, new product development and Lean efforts across the Company.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P2_S5	Shareholder value will be enhanced through continued emphasis on improvement of the fundamentals including market expansion, a high degree of customer satisfaction, new product development, manufacturing efficiency, cost containment, and efficient capital investment.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P3_S0	Over the course of our history, we have managed through many business cycles and our solid cash flow profile has helped us grow and expand globally.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P3_S1	We stand with a capital structure which includes sufficient cash reserves, significant revolver availability with an expiration of December 2013, fixed-rate long-term debt which expires in 2019 and a solid cash flow business profile.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P4_S0	During fiscal 2010 we initiated projects to strategically reorganize our North American hoist and rigging operations, which were essentially completed during the first quarter of fiscal 2011.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P4_S1	The projects included the closure of two manufacturing facilities and the significant downsizing of a third facility.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P4_S2	The closures and downsizing resulted in a reduction of approximately 500,000 square feet of manufacturing space (or approximately 25% of total manufacturing space).
1005229_12_ITEM7_P5_S0	Additionally our revenue base is now more geographically diverse than at any time in our Company s history, with approximately 45% derived from customers outside the U.S. for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2012.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P5_S1	We believe this will help balance the impact of changes that will occur in local economies as well as benefit the Company from growth in emerging markets.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P6_S0	As in the past, we monitor both U.S. and Eurozone Industrial Capacity Utilization statistics as indicators of anticipated demand for our product.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P6_S1	Since their June 2009 trough, these statistics have improved through April 2012.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P6_S2	In addition, we continue to monitor the potential impact of other global and U.S. trends including industrial production, energy costs, steel price fluctuations, interest rates, currency exchange and activity of end-user markets around the globe.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P7_S0	From a strategic perspective, we are investing in global markets and new products as we focus on our greatest opportunities for growth.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P7_S1	We maintain a strong North American market share with significant leading market positions in hoists, lifting and sling chain, forged attachments and actuators.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P7_S2	We seek to maintain and enhance our market share by focusing our sales and marketing activities toward select North American and global market sectors including energy, construction, entertainment, mining and food processing.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P8_S0	Regardless of the economic climate and point in the economic cycle, we constantly explore ways to manage our operating margins as well as further improve our productivity and competitiveness.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P8_S1	We have specific initiatives related to improved customer satisfaction, reduction of defects, shortened lead times, improved inventory turns and on-time deliveries, reduction of warranty costs, and improved working capital utilization.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P8_S2	The initiatives are being driven by the continued implementation of our Lean efforts which are fundamentally changing our manufacturing and business processes to be more responsive to customer demand and improving on-time delivery and productivity.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P8_S3	In addition to Lean, we are working to achieve these strategic initiatives through product simplification, the creation of centers of excellence, and improved supply chain management.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P9_S0	We continuously monitor market prices of steel.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P9_S1	We purchase approximately $30,000,000 to $40,000,000 of steel annually in a variety of forms including rod, wire, bar, structural and others.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P10_S0	Generally, as we experience fluctuations in our costs, we reflect them as price increases or surcharges to our customers with the goal of being margin neutral.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P10_S1	Some of our steel costs have increased during this year as a result of higher scrap and alloy surcharges.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P11_S0	We are also looking for opportunities for growth via strategic acquisitions or joint ventures.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P11_S1	The focus of our acquisition strategy centers on opportunities for non-U.S. market penetration and product line expansion in alignment with our existing core product offering.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P12_S0	We operate in a highly competitive and global business environment.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P12_S1	We face a variety of opportunities in those markets and geographies, including trends toward increased utilization of the global labor force and the expansion of market opportunities in Asia and other emerging markets.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P12_S2	While we continue to execute our long-term growth strategy, we are supported by our solid capital structure, including our cash position and flexible cost base.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P12_S3	We are also aggressively addressing costs and restructuring opportunities to enhance future margin opportunities.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P13_S0	Fiscal 2012 sales were $591,945,000, up 13.0%, or $67,880,000 compared with fiscal 2011.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P13_S1	The increase in sales was primarily due to an increase of $43,735,000 in volume resulting from the economic recovery and market share gains.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P13_S2	Price increases resulted in a $13,585,000 increase in sales.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P13_S3	Favorable foreign currency translation impacted sales by $10,560,000.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P13_S4	Fiscal 2011 sales were $524,065,000, up 10.1%, or $47,882,000 compared with fiscal 2010.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P13_S5	The increase in sales was primarily due to an increase of $52,785,000 in volume resulting from the economic recovery and market share gains.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P13_S6	Further, price increases resulted in a $4,651,000 increase in sales.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P13_S7	These increases were offset by a reduction of sales of $2,695,000 from the October 2009 divestiture of our American Lifts business as well as a negative foreign currency impact of $6,828,000.

1005229_12_ITEM7_P14_S2	Foreign currency translation had a favorable impact on gross profit of $2,616,000.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P14_S3	The fiscal 2011 increase in gross profit of $10,113,000 is the result of a $12,800,000 increase in volume, a $6,700,000 increase in restructuring benefits, $1,500,000 increase in savings on U.S. health and pension expenses, offset by a decrease of $6,800,000 from inefficiencies in our forgings operation, a decrease of $1,800,000 for increases in our product liability and asbestos related reserves, a decrease of $1,800,000 for increases in costs of materials and freight and a decrease of $487,000 for currency translation and other.

1005229_12_ITEM7_P37_S6	In the event of a Change of Control (as defined in the indenture for such notes), each holder of the Unregistered 7 7/8% Notes may require us to repurchase all or a portion of such holder s Unregistered 7 7/8% Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof.

1005229_12_ITEM7_P49_S0	Our costs are affected by inflation in the U.S. economy and, to a lesser extent, in non-U.S. economies including those of Europe, Canada, Mexico, South America and Asia-Pacific.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P49_S1	We do not believe that general inflation has had a material effect on our results of operations over the periods presented primarily due to overall low inflation levels over such periods and our ability to generally pass on rising costs through annual price increases and surcharges.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P49_S2	However, U.S. employee benefits costs such as health insurance, workers compensation insurance, pensions as well as energy and business insurance have exceeded general inflation levels.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P50_S0	In the future, we may be further affected by inflation that we may not be able to pass on as price increases.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P50_S1	With changes in worldwide demand for steel and fluctuating scrap steel prices over the past several years, we experienced fluctuations in our costs that we have reflected as price increases and surcharges to our customers.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P50_S2	We believe we have been successful in instituting surcharges and price increases to pass on these material cost increases.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P50_S3	We will continue to monitor our costs and reevaluate our pricing policies.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P51_S0	Our quarterly results may be materially affected by the timing of large customer orders, periods of high vacation and holiday concentrations, restructuring charges and other costs attributable to our facility rationalization program, divestitures, acquisitions and the magnitude of rationalization integration costs.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P51_S1	Therefore, our operating results for any particular fiscal quarter are not necessarily indicative of results for any subsequent fiscal quarter or for the full fiscal year.

1005229_12_ITEM7_P53_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in our consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P53_S1	We continually evaluate the estimates and their underlying assumptions, which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying value of our assets and liabilities.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P53_S2	Actual results inevitably will differ from those estimates.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P53_S3	We have identified below the accounting policies involving estimates that are critical to our financial statements.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P53_S4	Other accounting policies are more fully described in Note 2 of our consolidated financial statements.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P54_S0	Sales are recorded when title passes to the customer which is generally at the time of shipment to the customer.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P54_S1	The Company performs ongoing credit evaluations of its customers financial condition, but generally does not require collateral to support customer receivables.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P54_S2	The credit risk is controlled through credit approvals, limits and monitoring procedures.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P54_S3	Accounts receivable are reported at net realizable value and do not accrue interest.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P55_S0	Pension and Other Postretirement Benefits .
1005229_12_ITEM7_P56_S0	The determination of the obligations and expense for pension and postretirement benefits is dependent on our selection of certain assumptions that are used by actuaries in calculating such amounts.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P56_S1	Those assumptions are disclosed in Note 13 to our fiscal 2012 consolidated financial statements and include the discount rates, expected long-term rate of return on plan assets and rates of future increases in compensation and healthcare costs.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P57_S0	The pension discount rate assumptions of 4.70%, 5.75%, and 6.0%, as of March 31, 2012, 2011, and 2010, respectively, are based on long-term AA rated corporate and municipal bond rates.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P57_S1	The decrease in the discount rate for fiscal 2012 resulted in a $11,500,000 increase in the projected benefit obligation.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P57_S2	The decrease in the discount rates for fiscal 2011 resulted in an $4,700,000 increase in the projected benefit obligation as of March 31, 2011.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P57_S3	The rate of return on plan assets assumptions of 7.5% for each of the years ended March 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010 is based on the targeted plan asset allocation (approximately 70% equities and 30% fixed income) and their long-term historical returns.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P57_S4	Our under-funded status for all pension plans as of March 31, 2012 and 2011 was $65,123,000 and $32,366,000, or 30.3% and 18.2% of the projected benefit obligation, respectively.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P57_S5	Our pension contributions during fiscal 2012 and 2011 were approximately $5,974,000 and $7,796,000, respectively.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P57_S6	The under-funded status may result in future pension expense increases.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P57_S7	Pension expense for the March 31, 2013 fiscal year is expected to approximate $7,137,000, slightly less than the fiscal 2012 amount of $7,547,000, which includes a curtailment charge of $1,120,000.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P57_S8	Pension funding contributions for the March 31, 2013 fiscal year is expected to increase by approximately $4,412,000 compared to fiscal 2012.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P57_S9	The compensation increase assumption of 2% as of March 31, 2012, 2011, and 2010 is based on expected wage trends and historical patterns.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P58_S0	The healthcare costs inflation assumptions of 8.0% 8.5%, and 8.0% for fiscal 2012, 2011, and 2010, respectively, are based on anticipated trends.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P59_S0	Healthcare costs in the United States have increased substantially over the last several years.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P59_S1	If this trend continues, the cost of postretirement healthcare will increase in future years.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P60_S0	Our accrued general and product liability reserves as described in Note 16 to consolidated financial statements involve actuarial techniques including the methods selected to estimate ultimate claims, and assumptions including emergence patterns, payment patterns, initial expected losses and increased limit factors.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P60_S1	These actuarial estimates are subject to a high degree of uncertainty due to a variety of factors, including extended lag time in the reporting and resolution of claims, trends or changes in claim settlement patterns, insurance industry practices, and legal interpretations.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P60_S2	As a result, actual costs could differ significantly from the estimated amounts.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P61_S0	Adjustments to estimated reserves are recorded in the period in which the change in estimate occurs.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P61_S1	Other insurance reserves such as workers compensation and group health insurance are based on actual historical and current claim data provided by third party administrators or internally maintained.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P62_S0	Allowances for doubtful accounts and credit memo reserves are also judgmentally determined based on formulas applied to historical bad debt write-offs and credit memos issued, assessing potentially uncollectible customer accounts and analyzing the accounts receivable aging.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P63_S0	Accounts receivable are charged against the allowance for doubtful accounts once all collection efforts have been exhausted.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P63_S1	At March 31, 2012 the allowance for doubtful accounts totaled $2,700,000.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P64_S0	Impairment of depreciable and amortizable long-lived assets .
1005229_12_ITEM7_P64_S1	Property, plant and equipment and certain intangibles are depreciated or amortized over their assigned lives.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P65_S0	We test long-lived assets for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of those assets may not be recoverable and exceed their fair market value.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P65_S1	The following summarizes the value of long-lived assets subject to impairment testing when events or circumstances indicate potential impairment (amounts in millions):
1005229_12_ITEM7_P66_S0	Impairment may exist if the carrying amount of the asset in question exceeds the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P66_S1	The impairment loss, if any, would be measured as the amount by which the carrying amount of a long-lived asset exceeds its fair market value as determined by appropriate valuation techniques.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P67_S0	Our goodwill balance, $106,435,000 as of March 31, 2012 is subject to impairment testing.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P67_S1	We test goodwill for impairment at least annually, as of the end of February, and more frequently whenever events occur or circumstances change that indicate there may be impairment.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P67_S2	These events or circumstances could include a significant long-term adverse change in the business climate, poor indicators of operating performance, or a sale or disposition of a significant portion of a reporting unit.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P68_S0	We test goodwill at the reporting unit level, which is one level below our operating segment.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P68_S1	We identify our reporting units by assessing whether the components of our operating segment constitute businesses for which discrete financial information is available and segment management regularly reviews the operating results of those components.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P69_S0	We also aggregate components that have similar economic characteristics into single reporting units (for example, similar products and / or services, similar long-term financial results, product processes, classes of customers, etc.).
1005229_12_ITEM7_P69_S1	We have four reporting units, only two of which have goodwill.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P69_S2	Our Duff-Norton reporting unit and Rest of Products reporting unit have goodwill totaling $9,821,000 and $96,614,000, respectively, at March 31, 2012.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P70_S0	When we evaluate the potential for goodwill impairment, we assess a range of qualitative factors including, but not limited to, macroeconomic conditions, industry conditions, the competitive environment, changes in the market for our products and services, regulatory and political developments, entity specific factors such as strategy and changes in key personnel and overall financial performance.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P70_S1	If, after completing this assessment, it is determined that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value, we proceed to a two-step impairment test.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P71_S0	In order to perform the two-step impairment test, we use the discounted cash flow method to estimate the fair value of each of our reporting units.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P71_S1	The discounted cash flow method incorporates various assumptions, the most significant being projected revenue growth rates, operating profit margins and cash flows, the terminal growth rate and the discount rate.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P72_S0	Management projects revenue growth rates, operating margins and cash flows based on each reporting unit s current business, expected developments and operational strategies over a five-year period.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P73_S0	In estimating the terminal growth rate, we consider our historical and projected results, as well as the economic environment in which our reporting units operate.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P73_S1	The discount rates utilized for each reporting unit reflect management s assumptions of marketplace participants cost of capital and risk assumptions, both specific to the reporting unit and overall in the economy.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P74_S0	We performed our qualitative assessment during the fourth quarter and determined that it was not more likely than not that the fair value of each of our reporting units was less than that its applicable carrying value.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P74_S1	Accordingly, we did not perform the two-step goodwill impairment test for any of our reporting units.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P75_S0	On a quarterly basis, we review our marketable securities for declines in market value that may be considered other than temporary.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P75_S1	We generally consider market value declines to be other than temporary if there are declines for a period longer than six months and in excess of 20% of original cost.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P75_S2	We also consider the nature of the underlying investments and other market conditions.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P76_S0	Deferred Tax Asset Valuation Allowance .
1005229_12_ITEM7_P76_S1	During the fiscal year ended March 31, 2011, the Company recorded a non-cash charge of $42,983,000 included within its provision for income taxes.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P76_S2	The balance of the valuation allowance at March 31, 2012 is $53,325,000.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P76_S3	This charge relates to the Company s determination that a full valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets generated in the U.S. was necessary.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P76_S4	The deferred tax assets relate principally to liabilities related to employee benefit plans, insurance reserves, U.S. tax credits, and U.S. net operating loss carryforwards.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P76_S5	The U.S. net operating loss carryforwards have been generated primarily as a result of restructuring costs in fiscal years 2010 and 2011.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P77_S0	Accounting rules require a reduction of the carrying amounts of deferred tax assets by a valuation allowance if, based on the available and objectively verifiable evidence, it is more likely than not that such assets will not be realized.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P78_S0	The existence of cumulative losses for a certain threshold period is a significant form of negative evidence used in the assessment.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P79_S0	During the third quarter ended December 31, 2010, the Company determined that it would be in a three-year cumulative pretax loss position in the U.S. at March 31, 2011 primarily due to restructuring-related charges incurred in the U.S. to-date in fiscal 2011, despite our expectations of future profitability.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P80_S0	If a cumulative loss threshold is met, the accounting rules indicate that forecasts of future profitability are generally not sufficient positive evidence to overcome the presumption that a valuation allowance is necessary.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P81_S0	The recording of this non-cash charge does not impact the Company s ability to realize the economic benefit of its deferred tax assets (including those related to net operating loss carryforwards) amounting to $58,226,000 on a gross basis at March 31, 2012 on future tax returns.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P81_S1	In future periods, the allowance could be reduced or reversed based on sufficient objectively verifiable evidence indicating that it is more likely than not that a portion or all of the Company s deferred tax assets will be realized.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P82_S0	The Internal Revenue Code imposes limitations on a corporation s ability to utilize NOLs if it experiences an ownership change.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P83_S0	In general terms, an ownership change may result from transactions increasing the ownership of certain stockholders in the stock of a corporation by more than 50 percentage points over a three year period.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P83_S1	If we were to experience an ownership change, utilization of our NOLs would be subject to an annual limitation determined by multiplying the market value of our outstanding shares of stock at the time of the ownership change by the applicable long-term tax-exempt rate.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P83_S2	Any unused annual limitation may be carried over to later years within the allowed NOL carryforward period.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P83_S3	The amount of the limitation may, under certain circumstances, be increased or decreased by built-in gains or losses held by us at the time of the change that are recognized in the five-year period after the change.

1005229_12_ITEM7_P84_S1	Among the new provisions in ASU 2011-05 was a requirement for entities to present reclassification adjustments out of accumulated other comprehensive income by component in both the statement in which net income is presented and the statement in which other comprehensive income is presented (for both interim and annual financial statements); however this reclassification requirement is indefinitely deferred by ASU 2011-12 and will be further deliberated by the FASB at a future date.

1005229_12_ITEM7_P86_S0	In September 2011, the FASB issued ASU No. 2011-08, Intangibles Goodwill and Other (Topic 350) Testing Goodwill for Impairment.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P86_S1	The amendment permits entities to first assess qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events or circumstances leads to a determination that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P86_S2	If, after assessing relevant events or circumstances, an entity determines that it is not more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, then performing the two-step impairment test is unnecessary.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P86_S3	However, if an entity concludes otherwise, then it is required to follow the existing provisions of the two-step impairment test.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P86_S4	The amendments are effective for annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P86_S5	We adopted the new guidance for our annual goodwill impairment test, which we tested as of our measurement date of February 29, 2012.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P86_S6	The adoption of this standard did not have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P87_S0	In June 2011, the FASB issued ASU No. 2011-05, Presentation of Comprehensive Income ( ASU 2011-05 ), effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2011.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P87_S1	The issuance of ASU 2011-5 is intended to improve the comparability, consistency and transparency of financial reporting and to increase the prominence of items reported in other comprehensive income.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P87_S2	The guidance in ASU 2011-5 supersedes the presentation options in ASC Topic 220 and facilitates convergence of U.S. generally accepted accounting principles and International Financial Reporting Standards by eliminating the option to present components of other comprehensive income as part of the statement of changes in stockholders equity and requiring that all nonowner changes in stockholders equity be presented either in a single continuous statement of comprehensive income or in two separate but consecutive statements.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P87_S3	The Company does not expect that the adoption of ASU 2011-05 will have a significant impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.

1005229_12_ITEM7_P88_S1	ASU 2011-04 represents the converged guidance of the FASB and the International Accounting Standards Board (the Boards ) on fair value measurements.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P88_S2	The collective efforts of the Boards and their staffs, reflected in ASU 2011-04, have resulted in common requirements for measuring fair value and for disclosing information about fair value measurements, including a consistent meaning of the term fair value.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P88_S3	The Boards have concluded the common requirements will result in greater comparability of fair value measurements presented and disclosed in financial statements prepared in accordance with GAAP and IFRS.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P88_S4	The amendments in this ASU are required to be applied prospectively, and are effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2011.
1005229_12_ITEM7_P88_S5	The Company does not expect that the adoption of ASU 2011-04 will have a significant impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.

1005229_12_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market rates and prices, such as interest rates.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P0_S1	We are exposed to various market risks, including commodity prices for raw materials, foreign currency exchange rates and changes in interest rates.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P0_S2	We may enter into financial instrument transactions, which attempt to manage and reduce the impact of such changes.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P0_S3	We do not enter into derivatives or other financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Our primary commodity risk is related to changes in the price of steel.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P1_S1	We control this risk through negotiating purchase contracts on a consolidated basis and by attempting to build changes in raw material costs into the selling prices of or surcharges on our products.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P1_S2	We have not entered into financial instrument transactions related to raw material costs.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P2_S0	In fiscal 2012, 45% of our net sales were from manufacturing plants and sales offices in foreign jurisdictions.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P2_S1	We manufacture our products in the United States, China, Germany, United Kingdom, Hungary, Mexico and France and sell our products in approximately 50 countries.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Our results of operations could be affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency rates or weak economic conditions in foreign markets.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Our operating results are exposed to fluctuations between the U.S. dollar and the Canadian dollar, European currencies, the Mexican peso and the Chinese Yuan.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P2_S4	For example, when the U.S. dollar weakens against the Euro, the value of our net sales and net income denominated in Euros increases when translated into U.S. dollars for inclusion in our consolidated results.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P3_S0	We are also exposed to foreign currency fluctuations in relation to purchases denominated in foreign currencies.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P3_S1	Our foreign currency risk is mitigated since the majority of our foreign operations net sales and the related expense transactions are denominated in the same currency so therefore a significant change in foreign exchange rates would likely have a very minor impact on net income.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P3_S2	For example, a 10% change in the value of the U.S. dollar in relation to our most significant foreign currency exposures would have had an impact of approximately $1,200,000 on our net income.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P3_S3	In addition, the majority of our export sale transactions are denominated in U.S. dollars.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The Company has foreign currency forward agreements and cross-currency swaps in place to offset changes in the value of intercompany loans to certain foreign subsidiaries due to changes in foreign exchange rates.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P4_S1	The notional amount of these derivatives is $11,120,000 and all contracts mature by September 30, 2013.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P4_S2	These contracts are not designated as hedges.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The Company has foreign currency forward agreements in place to hedge changes in the value of recorded foreign currency liabilities due to changes in foreign exchange rates at the settlement date.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The notional amount of those derivatives is $2,597,000 and all contracts mature within twelve months.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P5_S2	These contracts are marked to market each balance sheet date and are not designated as hedges.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P6_S0	The Company has foreign currency forward agreements that are designated as cash flow hedges to hedge a portion of forecasted inventory purchases and sales, including multi-year contracts related to capital project sales, denominated in a foreign currency.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P6_S1	The notional amount of those derivatives is $10,098,000 and all contracts mature within twenty-seven months of March 31, 2012.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P7_S0	We control risk related to changes in interest rates by structuring our debt instruments with a combination of fixed and variable interest rates and by periodically entering into financial instrument transactions as appropriate.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P7_S1	At March 31, 2012, we do not have any material swap agreements or similar financial instruments in place.
1005229_12_ITEM7A_P7_S2	At March 31, 2012 and 2011, approximately 99% and 99% of our outstanding debt had fixed interest rates, respectively.

1005229_12_ITEM8_P13_S0	Goodwill is not amortized but is tested for impairment at least annually, in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 350-20-35-1.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P13_S1	Goodwill impairment is deemed to exist if the net book value of a reporting unit exceeds its estimated fair value.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P13_S2	The fair value of a reporting unit is determined using a discounted cash flow methodology.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P13_S3	The Company s reporting units are determined based upon whether discrete financial information is available and reviewed regularly, whether those units constitute a business, and the extent of economic similarities between those reporting units for purposes of aggregation.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P13_S4	The Company s reporting units identified under ASC Topic 350-20-35-33 are at the component level, or one level below the reporting segment level as defined under ASC Topic 280-10-50-10 Segment Reporting Disclosure.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P14_S0	The Company s one segment is subdivided into four reporting units.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P15_S0	When the Company evaluates the potential for goodwill impairment, it assesses a range of qualitative factors including, but not limited to, macroeconomic conditions, industry conditions, the competitive environment, changes in the market for its products and services, regulatory and political developments, entity specific factors such as strategy and changes in key personnel and overall financial performance.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P15_S1	If, after completing this assessment, it is determined that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value, the Company proceeds to a two-step impairment test.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P16_S0	The Company performed its qualitative assessment during the fourth quarter and determined that it was not more likely than not that the fair value of each of its reporting units was less than that its applicable carrying value.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P16_S1	Accordingly, the Company did not perform the two-step goodwill impairment test for any of its reporting units.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P16_S2	See Note 9 for further discussion of goodwill and intangible assets.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P17_S0	The Company assesses impairment of its long-lived assets in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 360 Property, Plant, and Equipment.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P17_S1	This statement requires long-lived assets, such as property and equipment and purchased intangibles subject to amortization to be reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset group may not be recoverable.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P18_S0	Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of an asset group to estimated undiscounted future cash flows expected to be generated by the asset group.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P18_S1	If the carrying amount of an asset group exceeds its estimated future cash flows, an impairment charge is recognized equal to the amount by which the carrying amount of the asset group exceeds the fair value of the asset group.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P19_S0	In assessing long-lived assets for an impairment loss, assets are grouped with other assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other assets and liabilities.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P19_S1	Asset grouping requires a significant amount of judgment.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P19_S2	Accordingly, facts and circumstances will influence how asset groups are determined for impairment testing.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P20_S0	In assessing long-lived assets for impairment, management considered the Company s product line portfolio, customers and related commercial agreements, labor agreements and other factors in grouping assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are independent.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P20_S1	The Company considers projected future undiscounted cash flows, trends and other factors in its assessment of whether impairment conditions exist.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P20_S2	While the Company believes that its estimates of future cash flows are reasonable, different assumptions regarding such factors as future production volumes, customer pricing, economics and productivity and cost initiatives, could significantly affect its estimates.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P21_S0	In determining fair value of long-lived assets, management uses management estimates, discounted cash flow calculations, and appraisals where necessary.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P22_S0	At acquisition, the Company estimates and records the fair value of purchased intangible assets which primarily consist of trade names, customer relationships and technology.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P22_S1	The fair values are estimated based on management s assessment as well as independent third party appraisals.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P22_S2	Such valuations may include a discounted cash flow of anticipated revenues resulting from the acquired intangible asset.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P23_S0	Amortization of intangible assets with finite lives is recognized over their estimated useful lives using an amortization method that reflects the pattern in which the economic benefits of the intangible assets are consumed or otherwise realized.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P24_S0	The straight line method is used for customer relationships.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P24_S1	As a result of the negligible attrition rate in our customer base, the difference between the straight line method and attrition method is not considered significant.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P25_S0	The estimated useful lives for our intangible assets range from 3 to 18 years.

1005229_12_ITEM8_P54_S0	ASC Topic 820 Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures establishes the standards for reporting financial assets and liabilities and nonfinancial assets and liabilities that are recognized or disclosed at fair value on a recurring basis (at least annually).
1005229_12_ITEM8_P54_S1	Under these standards, fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability (i.e. the "exit price") in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P55_S0	ASC Topic 820-10-35-37 establishes a hierarchy for inputs used in measuring fair value that maximizes the use of observable inputs and minimizes the use of unobservable inputs by requiring that the most observable inputs be used when available.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P56_S0	Observable inputs are inputs that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability developed based on market data obtained from sources independent of the Company.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P56_S1	Unobservable inputs are inputs that reflect the Company's assumptions about the valuation techniques that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability developed based on the best information available in the circumstances.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P56_S2	The hierarchy is separated into three levels based on the reliability of inputs as follows:
1005229_12_ITEM8_P57_S0	Level 1 - Valuations based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the Company has the ability to access.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P57_S1	Since valuations are based on quoted prices that are readily and regularly available in an active market, valuation of these products does not entail a significant degree of judgment.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P58_S0	Level 2 - Valuations based on quoted prices in markets that are not active or for which all significant inputs are observable, either directly or indirectly, involving some degree of judgment.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P59_S0	Level 3 - Valuations based on inputs that are unobservable and significant to the overall fair value measurement.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P59_S1	The degree of judgment exercised in determining fair value is greatest for instruments categorized in Level 3.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P60_S0	The availability of observable inputs can vary and is affected by a wide variety of factors, including the type of asset/liability, whether the asset/liability is established in the marketplace, and other characteristics particular to the transaction.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P61_S0	To the extent that valuation is based on models or inputs that are less observable or unobservable in the market, the determination of fair value requires more judgment.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P62_S0	In certain cases, the inputs used to measure fair value may fall into different levels of the fair value hierarchy.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P62_S1	In such cases, for disclosure purposes the level in the fair value hierarchy within which the fair value measurement in its entirety falls is determined based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P63_S0	Fair value is a market-based measure considered from the perspective of a market participant rather than an entity-specific measure.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P63_S1	Therefore, even when market assumptions are not readily available, assumptions are required to reflect those that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability at the measurement date.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P64_S0	When valuing our derivative portfolio, the Company uses readily observable market data in conjunction with commonly used valuation models.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P64_S1	Consequently, the Company designates our derivatives as Level 2.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P65_S0	The following table provides information regarding financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis:

1005229_12_ITEM8_P91_S0	As discussed in Note 2, goodwill is not amortized but is tested for impairment at least annually, in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 350-20-35-1.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P91_S1	Goodwill impairment is deemed to exist if the net book value of a reporting unit exceeds its estimated fair value.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P91_S2	The fair value of a reporting unit is determined using a discounted cash flow methodology.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P91_S3	The Company s reporting units are determined based upon whether discrete financial information is available and reviewed regularly, whether those units constitute a business, and the extent of economic similarities between those reporting units for purposes of aggregation.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P91_S4	The Company s reporting units identified under ASC Topic 350-20-35-33 are at the component level, or one level below the reporting segment level as defined under ASC Topic 280-10-50-10 Segment Reporting Disclosure.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P91_S5	The Company has four reporting units.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P91_S6	Only two of the four reporting units carry goodwill at March 31, 2012 and March 31, 2011.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P91_S7	The Duff-Norton reporting unit (which designs, manufactures and sources mechanical and electromechanical actuators and rotary unions) had goodwill of $9,821,000 and $9,902,000 at March 31, 2012 and 2011, respectively, and the Rest of Products reporting unit (representing the hoist, chain, and forgings design, manufacturing, and distribution businesses) had goodwill of $96,614,000 and $96,153,000 at March 31, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P92_S0	When we evaluate the potential for goodwill impairment, we assess a range of qualitative factors including, but not limited to, macroeconomic conditions, industry conditions, the competitive environment, changes in the market for our products and services, regulatory and political developments, entity specific factors such as strategy and changes in key personnel and overall financial performance.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P92_S1	If, after completing this assessment, it is determined that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value, we proceed to a two-step impairment test.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P93_S0	In accordance with ASC Topic 350-20-35-3, the measurement of impairment of goodwill consists of two steps.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P94_S0	In the first step, the Company compares the fair value of each reporting unit to its carrying value.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P94_S1	As part of the impairment analysis, the Company determines the fair value of each of its reporting units with goodwill using the income approach.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P94_S2	The income approach uses a discounted cash flow methodology to determine fair value.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P94_S3	This methodology recognizes value based on the expected receipt of future economic benefits.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P94_S4	Key assumptions in the income approach include a free cash flow projection, an estimated discount rate, a long-term growth rate and a terminal value.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P94_S5	These assumptions are based upon the Company s historical experience, current market trends and future expectations.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P95_S0	We performed our qualitative assessment during the fourth quarter and determined that it was not more likely than not that the fair value of each of our reporting units was less than that its applicable carrying value.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P95_S1	Accordingly, we did not perform the two-step goodwill impairment test for any of our reporting units.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P96_S0	Future impairment indicators, such as declines in forecasted cash flows, may cause additional significant impairment charges.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P96_S1	Impairment charges could be based on such factors as the Company s stock price, forecasted cash flows, assumptions used, control premiums or other variables.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P97_S0	Identifiable intangible assets acquired in a business combination are amortized over their estimated useful lives.

1005229_12_ITEM8_P103_S0	The Company uses derivative instruments to manage selected foreign currency exposures.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P103_S1	The Company does not use derivative instruments for speculative trading purposes.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P103_S2	All derivative instruments must be recorded on the balance sheet at fair value.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P103_S3	For derivatives designated as cash flow hedges, the effective portion of changes in the fair value of the derivative is recorded as accumulated other comprehensive loss ( AOCL ) and is reclassified to earnings when the underlying transaction has an impact on earnings.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P103_S4	The ineffective portion of changes in the fair value of the derivative is reported in foreign currency exchange (gain) loss in the Company s consolidated statement of operations.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P103_S5	For derivatives not classified as cash flow hedges, all changes in market value are recorded as a foreign currency exchange (gain) loss in the Company s consolidated statements of operations.

1005229_12_ITEM8_P164_S0	The guidance in ASC Topic 718 "Compensation - Stock Compensation" and covered in sub-topic 718-40 "Employee Stock Ownership Plans" requires that compensation expense for ESOP shares be measured based on the fair value of those shares when committed to be released to employees, rather than based on their original cost.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P164_S1	Also, dividends on those ESOP shares that have not been allocated or committed to be released to ESOP participants are not reflected as a reduction of retained earnings.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P164_S2	Rather, since those dividends are used for debt service, a charge to compensation expense is recorded.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P164_S3	Furthermore, ESOP shares that have not been allocated or committed to be released are not considered outstanding for purposes of calculating earnings per share.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P165_S0	The obligation of the ESOP to repay borrowings incurred to purchase shares of the Company s common stock is guaranteed by the Company; the unpaid balance of such borrowings, if any, would be reflected in the consolidated balance sheet as a liability.

1005229_12_ITEM8_P190_S0	The fair value of stock options granted was estimated on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option pricing model.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P191_S0	The Black-Scholes option valuation model was developed for use in estimating the fair value of traded options which have no vesting restrictions and are fully transferable.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P191_S1	In addition, option valuation models require the input of highly subjective assumptions including the expected stock price volatility.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P191_S2	Because the Company s employee stock options have characteristics significantly different from those of traded options, and because changes in the subjective input assumptions can materially affect the fair value estimate, in management s opinion, the existing models do not necessarily provide a reliable single measure of the fair value of its employee stock options.
1005229_12_ITEM8_P191_S3	The weighted-average fair value of the options was $9.81, $9.29, and $8.18 for options granted during fiscal 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
