1005229_14_ITEM1_P30_S0	Introducing New Products We continue to expand our business by developing new products and services and expanding the breadth of our product lines to address the material handling needs of our customers.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P30_S1	We design our powered hoist products to meet applicable national and international standards such as ASME, FEM, DIN and other region-specific/application-specific standards to maximize product utility across global markets.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P30_S2	We employ the StageGate process to enhance discipline and focus in our new product development program.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P31_S0	New product sales (defined as new products introduced within the last three years and products engineered for our customers) amounted to $140,000,000 in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2014, or 24.1% of total sales exceeding our goal of having new products amounting to at least 20% of total sales.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P31_S1	New product sales amounted to $142,000,000 in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2013 (23.7% of total sales) and $121,000,000 in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2012 (20.4% of total sales).
1005229_14_ITEM1_P32_S0	Our large, diversified, global customer base, our extensive distribution channels and our close relationships with end-users and channel partners provide us with insights into customer preferences and product requirements that allow us to anticipate and address the future needs of the marketplace.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P32_S1	We are also investing in key vertical markets that will help us increase our revenues.

1005229_14_ITEM1_P34_S0	Industrial channel partners offer a broad array of industrial components that are used by many end-user markets.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P34_S1	We continue to review and add new material handling products to broaden our offerings.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P35_S0	Continue to Grow in Non-U.S. Markets - Our non-U.S. sales of $251,902,000 comprised 43% of our net sales for the year ended March 31, 2014, as compared with $253,252,000, or 42% in fiscal 2013 and as compared to 16% of our net sales in fiscal 1996, the year we became a public company.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P35_S1	Although we have made significant progress, our goal is to continue to increase our presence outside the U.S to capitalize on the higher growth opportunities and continue to diversify our business profile.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P35_S2	We presently sell to distributors in over 50 countries and have our primary non-U.S. manufacturing facilities in China, Germany, United Kingdom, Hungary, Mexico and France.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P35_S3	In addition to new product introductions, we continue to expand our sales and service presence in the major and developing market areas of Asia-Pacific, Europe, and Latin America and have sales offices and warehouse facilities in Canada, various countries in Western and Eastern Europe, China, Thailand, Brazil, Uruguay, Panama and Mexico.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P35_S4	We intend to increase our sales in Asia-Pacific by manufacturing a broader array of high quality, low-cost products and components in China.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P35_S5	We have developed and are continuing to expand upon new hoist and other products in compliance with global standards and international designs to enhance our global distribution.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P36_S0	Our objective is to provide the highest quality products and services at prices consistent with the value created for our customers.

1005229_14_ITEM1_P36_S3	We continually seek ways to reduce our operating costs and increase our manufacturing productivity, while maintaining quality.

1005229_14_ITEM1_P40_S0	We design, manufacture and distribute a broad range of material handling products for various applications.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P40_S1	Products include a wide variety of electric and air-powered, lever, and hand hoists, hoist trolleys, winches, industrial crane systems such as bridge, gantry and jib cranes; alloy and carbon steel chain; forged attachments, such as hooks, shackles, textile slings, clamps, logging tools and load binders; mechanical and electromechanical actuators and rotary unions; below-the-hook special purpose lifters; tire shredders; and light-rail systems.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P40_S2	These products are typically manufactured for stock or assembled to order from standard components and are sold primarily through a variety of commercial distributors and to a lesser extent, directly to end-users.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P40_S3	The diverse end-users of our products are in a variety of industries including: manufacturing, power generation and distribution, utilities, wind power, warehouses, commercial construction, oil and gas exploration and refining, petrochemical, marine, ship building, transportation and heavy duty trucking, agriculture, logging and mining.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P40_S4	We also serve a niche market for the entertainment industry including permanent and traveling concerts, live theater and sporting venues.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P41_S0	Nearly 80% of our net sales are derived from the sale of products that we sell at a unit price of less than $5,000.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P41_S1	Of our fiscal 2014 sales, $331,388,000 or 57% were U.S. and $251,902,000, or 43% were non-U.S.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P41_S2	The following table sets forth certain sales data for our products, expressed as a percentage of net sales for fiscal 2014 and 2013:
1005229_14_ITEM1_P42_S0	Hoists - We manufacture a wide variety of electric chain hoists, electric wire rope hoists, hand-operated hoists, winches, lever tools and air-powered hoists.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P42_S1	Load capacities for our hoist product lines range from one-eighth of a ton to 80 tons.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P42_S2	These products are sold under our Budgit, Chester, CM, Coffing, Little Mule, Pfaff, Shaw-Box, Yale and other recognized brands.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P43_S0	Our hoists are sold for use in numerous general industrial applications, as well as for use in the construction, energy, mining, food services, entertainment and other markets.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P43_S1	We also supply hoist trolleys, driven manually or by electric motors, that are used in conjunction with hoists.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P44_S0	We also offer several lines of standard and custom-designed, below-the-hook tooling, clamps, and textile strappings.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P45_S0	Below-the-hook tooling, textile and chain slings and associated forgings, and clamps are specialized lifting apparatus used in a variety of lifting activities performed in conjunction with hoisting or lifting applications.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P46_S0	Chain and Rigging Tools - We manufacture alloy and carbon steel chain for various industrial and consumer applications.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P46_S1	U.S. federal regulations require the use of alloy chain, which we first developed, for overhead lifting applications because of its strength and wear characteristics.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P46_S2	A line of our alloy chain is sold under the Herc-Alloy TM brand name for use in overhead lifting, pulling and restraining applications.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P46_S3	In addition, we also sell specialized load chain for use in hoists, as well as three grades and multiple sizes of carbon steel welded-link chain for various load securing and other non-overhead lifting applications.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P47_S0	We produce a broad line of alloy and carbon steel closed-die forged chain attachments, including hooks, shackles, Hammerloks TM , and master links.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P47_S1	These forged attachments are used in chain, wire rope and textile rigging applications in a variety of industries, including transportation, mining, construction, marine, logging, petrochemical and agriculture.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P48_S0	In addition, we manufacture carbon steel forged and stamped products, such as load binders, logging tools and other securing devices, for sale to the industrial and logging markets through industrial distributors, hardware distributors, mass merchandiser outlets and OEMs.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P49_S0	Industrial Cranes - We participate in the U.S. crane manufacturing and servicing markets through our offering of overhead bridge, jib and gantry cranes.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P49_S1	Our products are sold under the CES, Abell-Howe and Washington Equipment brands.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P50_S0	Crane builders represent a specific distribution channel for electric wire rope hoists, chain hoists and other crane components.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P51_S0	Actuators and Rotary Unions - Through our Duff-Norton and Pfaff divisions, we design and manufacture industrial components such as mechanical and electromechanical actuators and rotary unions.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P52_S0	Actuators are linear motion devices used in a variety of industries, including the transportation, paper, steel, energy, aerospace and many other commercial industries.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P53_S0	Rotary unions are devices that transfer a liquid or gas from a fixed pipe or hose to a rotating drum, cylinder or other device.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P53_S1	Rotary unions are used in a varie ty of industries including pulp and paper, printing, textile and fabric manufacturing, rubber and plastic.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P54_S0	With our recent acquisition of Unified Industries, Inc. we now manufacture and market overhead aluminum light rail workstations primarily used in automotive and other industrial applications.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P54_S1	Our products are sold under the Unified Industries brand.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P55_S0	Other - This category primar ily includes tire shredders.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P56_S0	We have developed and patented a line of heavy equipment that shred whole tires, for use in recycling the various components of a tire including: rubber and steel.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P56_S1	These recycled products also can be used as aggregate, playgrounds, sports surfaces, landscaping and other such applications, as well as scrap steel.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P57_S0	Our sales and marketing efforts consist of the following programs:
1005229_14_ITEM1_P58_S0	Factory-Direct Field Sales and Customer Service - We sell our products through our sales force of more than 110 sales people and through independent sales agents worldwide.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P58_S1	We compensate our sales force through a combination of base salary and a commission plan based on top line sales and a pre-established sales quota.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P59_S0	Product Advertising - We promote our products by advertising in leading trade journals as well as producing and distributing high quality information catalogs.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P59_S1	We place targeted advertisements for hoists, chain, forged attachments, actuators, and cranes in key industrial publications.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P60_S0	Target Marketing - We provide marketing literature to target specific end-user market sectors including entertainment, construction, energy, mining, and others.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P60_S1	This literature displays our broad product offering applicable to those sectors to enhance awareness at the end-user level within those sectors.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P60_S2	We also employ vertical market specialists to support our field sales force to assist our customers with solving their material handling application needs.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P61_S0	Trade Show Participation - Trade shows are an effective way to promote our products to distributors and end users.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P61_S1	Shows can range in size from distributor open houses to large, global shows such as CeMAT held in Hanover, Germany.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P62_S0	Through partnerships with our distributors, we have expanded our reach to the end user while strengthening our distribution network.

1005229_14_ITEM1_P62_S2	Examples include: OTC (US) for oil gas, MODEX (US) for material handling, MINExpo (US) for mining industry, LDI (US) for the entertainment industry, PALM Expo (China) for the entertainment industry, CEMAT ASIA for material handling, automation, transport/logistics industries, Prolight Sound (Germany) for industrial equipment, Plasa (UK) for entertainment, Mec nica (Brazil) for automation and process controls, Rio for oil gas (Brazil) and Expo Manejo de Materiales y Log stica (Mexico) for handling of materials and logistics.

1005229_14_ITEM1_P63_S1	(Specialty Carriers and Riggers Association), WSTDA (Web Sling and Tie Down Association), MHI (Material Handling Institute), HMI (Hoist Manufacturers Institute), CMAA (Crane Manufacturers Association of America), ESTA (Entertainment Services and Technology Association), NACM (National Association of Chain Manufacturers), and AMSE (American Society of Mechanical Engineers).
1005229_14_ITEM1_P64_S0	Product Standards and Safety Training Classes - We conduct on-site training and certification programs worldwide for distributors and end-users to promote and reinforce the attributes of our products and their safe use and operation in various material handling applications.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P64_S1	These training and certification programs include crane inspection and operation training and certification, hoist inspection and repair training and certification, various rigging training courses, load securement training, and entertainment technology equipment training and certification classes.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P65_S0	CMCO University - Launched in September 2013, CMCO University is a three-day training program designed to give our Channel Partners an intimate knowledge of Columbus McKinnon products.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P65_S1	Held at the Columbus McKinnon Niagara Training Center, this program consists of classroom and hands-on training aimed at providing the sales and product information our Channel Partners need to select the right product for their end-users application and the tools to win in the marketplace.

1005229_14_ITEM1_P66_S1	The site also provides detailed search and simultaneous product comparisons, the ability to submit Requests for Quotations and allow users to be able chat live with a member of our customer service department.

1005229_14_ITEM1_P67_S0	Our distribution channels include a variety of commercial distributors.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P67_S1	In addition, we sell overhead bridge, jib and gantry cranes as well as certain Pfaff products directly to end-users.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P68_S0	The following describes our global distribution channels:
1005229_14_ITEM1_P69_S0	General Distribution Channels - Our global general distribution channels consist of:
1005229_14_ITEM1_P70_S0	Industrial distributors that serve local or regional industrial markets and sell a variety of products for maintenance repair, operating and production, or MROP, applications through their own direct sales force.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P71_S0	Rigging shops that are distributors with expertise in rigging, lifting, positioning and load securing.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P71_S1	Most rigging shops assemble and distribute chain, wire rope and synthetic slings and distribute manual hoists and attachments, chain slings and other products.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P72_S0	Independent crane builders that design, build, install and service overhead crane and light-rail systems for general industry and also distribute a wide variety of hoists and crane components.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P72_S1	We sell electric wire rope hoists and chain hoists as well as crane components, such as end trucks, trolleys, drives and electrification systems to crane builders.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P73_S0	Specialty Distribution Channels - Our global specialty distribution channels consist of:
1005229_14_ITEM1_P74_S0	National distributors that market a variety of MROP supplies, including material handling products, either exclusively through large, nationally distributed catalogs, or through a combination of catalog, internet and branch sales and a field sales force.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P74_S1	The customer base served by national distributors such as W. W. Grainger, which traditionally included smaller industrial companies and consumers, has grown to include large industrial accounts and integrated suppliers.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P75_S0	Material handling specialists and integrators that design and assemble systems incorporating hoists, overhead rail systems, trolleys, scissor lift tables, manipulators, air balancers, jib arms and other material handling products to provide end-users with solutions to their material handling problems.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P76_S0	Entertainment equipment distributors that design, supply and install a variety of material handling and rigging equipment for concerts, theaters, ice shows, sporting events, convention centers and night clubs.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P77_S0	Pfaff International Direct - Our German-based Pfaff business markets and sells most of its actuators and certain of its hoist products direct to end-users, providing an additional method to market for us in the European region.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P78_S0	Crane End-Users - We market and sell overhead bridge, jib and gantry cranes, parts and service to end-users through our wholly owned crane builder, Crane Equipment Service, Inc. ( CES ).
1005229_14_ITEM1_P78_S1	CES which includes Abell-Howe and Washington Equipment brands designs, manufactures, installs and services a variety of cranes with capacities up to 100 tons.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P79_S0	Service-After-Sale Distribution Channel - Service-after-sale distributors include our authorized network of 16 chain repair service stations and over 200 certified hoist service and repair stations throughout North America.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P79_S1	This service network is designed for easy parts and service access for our large installed base of hoists and related equipment in that region.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P80_S0	OEMs that supply various component parts directly to other industrial manufacturers as well as private branding and packaging of our traditional products for material handling, lifting, positioning and special purpose applications.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P81_S0	Government agencies, including the U.S. and Canadian Navies and Coast Guards, that purchase primarily load securing chain and forged attachments.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P81_S1	We also provide our products to the U.S government for a variety of military applications.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P82_S0	We maintain customer service departments staffed by trained personnel for all of our sales divisions, and regularly schedule product and service training schools for all customer service representatives and field sales personnel.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P82_S1	Training programs for distribution and service station personnel, as well as for end-users, are scheduled on a regular basis at most of our facilities and in the field.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P82_S2	We have over 200 service and repair stations worldwide that provide local and regional repair, warranty and general service work for distributors and end-users.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P82_S3	End-user trainees attending our various programs include representatives of 3M, DuPont, General Electric, and many other industrial and entertainment organizations.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P83_S0	We also provide, in multiple languages, a variety of collateral material in video, CD-ROM, slide and print format addressing relevant material handling topics such as the care, use and inspection of chains and hoists, and overhead lifting and positioning safety.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P83_S1	In addition, we sponsor advisory boards made up of representatives of our primary distributors and service-after-sale network members who are invited to participate in discussions focused on improving products and service.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P83_S2	These boards enable us and our primary distributors to exchange product and market information relevant to industry trends.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P84_S0	Our backlog of orders at March 31, 2014 was approximately $86,801,000 compared to approximately $99,034,000 at March 31, 2013.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P84_S1	The decrease in backlog at March 31, 2014 is primarily due to the timing of orders and shortened lead times.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P84_S2	Our orders for standard products are generally shipped within one week.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P84_S3	Orders for products that are manufactured to customers specifications are generally shipped within four to twelve weeks.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P84_S4	Given the short product lead times, we do not believe that the amount of our backlog of orders is a reliable indication of our future sales.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P85_S0	Fluctuations in backlog reflect the project oriented nature of certain aspects of our business.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P86_S0	The material handling industry remains highly fragmented.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P86_S1	We face competition from a wide range of regional, national and international manufacturers globally.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P86_S2	In addition, we often compete with individual operating units of larger, highly diversified companies.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P87_S0	The principal competitive factors affecting our business include customer service and support as well as product availability, performance, functionality, brand reputation, reliability and price.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P87_S1	Other important factors include distributor relationships and territory coverage.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P88_S0	Major competitors for hoists are Konecranes, Terex (acquired Demag Cranes) and Kito (and its U.S. subsidiary Harrington); for chain are Campbell Chain, Peerless Chain Company and American Chain and Cable Company; for forged attachments are The Crosby Group and Brewer Tichner Company; for cranes are Konecranes, Terex (Demag Cranes) and a variety of independent crane builders; for actuators and rotary unions are Deublin, Joyce-Dayton and Nook Industries; and for tire shredders is Granutech.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P89_S0	At March 31, 2014, we had 2,626 employees; 1,466 in the U.S./Canada, 115 in Latin America, 834 in Europe and 211 in Asia.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P89_S1	Approximately 13% of our employees are represented under four separate U.S. or Canadian collective bargaining agreements which terminate at various times between September 2014 and May 2017.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P89_S2	We also have various labor agreements with our non-U.S. employees which we negotiate from time to time.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P89_S3	We believe that our relationship with our employees is good and that the risk of a disruption in production related to these negotiations is remote.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P90_S0	Our principal raw materials and components are steel, consisting of structural steel, processed steel bar, forging bar steel, steel rod and wire, steel pipe and tubing and tool steel; electric motors; bearings; gear reducers; castings; and electro-mechanical components.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P90_S1	These commodities are all available from multiple sources.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P90_S2	We purchase most of these raw materials and components from a limited number of strategic and preferred suppliers under long-term agreements which are negotiated on a company-wide basis through our global purchasing group to take advantage of volume discounts.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P90_S3	We generally seek to pass on materials price increases to our channel partners and end-user customers.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P90_S4	We continue to monitor our costs and reevaluate our pricing policies.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P90_S5	Our ability to pass on these increases is determined by market conditions.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P91_S0	We use derivative instruments to manage selected foreign currency exposures.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P91_S1	The Company does not use derivative instruments for speculative trading purposes.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P92_S0	We use foreign currency forward agreements to i) hedge changes in the value of booked foreign currency liabilities due to changes in foreign exchange rates at the settlement date and ii) to hedge a portion of forecasted inventory purchases denominated in a foreign currency.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P93_S0	We complement our own manufacturing by outsourcing components and finished goods from an established global network of suppliers.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P93_S1	We regularly upgrade our global manufacturing facilities and invest in tooling, equipment and technology.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P94_S0	Our manufacturing operations are highly integrated.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P94_S1	Although raw materials and some components such as motors, bearings, gear reducers, castings and electro-mechanical components are purchased, our vertical integration enables us to produce many of the components used in the manufacturing of our products.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P94_S2	We manufacture hoist lifting chain, steel forged gear blanks, lift wheels, trolley wheels, overhead light rail workstations, and hooks and other attachments for incorporation into our hoist products.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P94_S3	These products are also sold as spare parts for hoist repair.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P94_S4	Additionally, our hoists are used as components in the manufacture of crane systems by us as well as our crane-builder customers.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P95_S0	Like most manufacturing companies, we are subject to various federal, state and local laws relating to the protection of the environment.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P95_S1	To address the requirements of such laws, we have adopted a corporate environmental protection policy which provides that all of our owned or leased facilities shall, and all of our employees have the duty to, comply with all applicable environmental regulatory standards, and we have initiated an environmental auditing program for our facilities to ensure compliance with such regulatory standards.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P95_S2	We have also established managerial responsibilities and internal communication channels for dealing with environmental compliance issues that may arise in the course of our business.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P95_S3	We have made and could be required to continue to make significant expenditures to comply with environmental requirements.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P95_S4	Because of the complexity and changing nature of environmental regulatory standards, it is possible that situations will arise from time to time requiring us to incur additional expenditures to ensure environmental regulatory compliance.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P95_S5	However, we are not aware of any environmental condition or any operation at any of our facilities, either individually or in the aggregate, which would cause expenditures having a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition or cash flows.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P96_S0	We notified the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources (the DENR ) in April 2006 of the presence of certain contaminants in excess of regulatory standards at our facility in Wadesboro, North Carolina.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P96_S1	We filed an application with the DENR to enter its voluntary cleanup program and were accepted.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P96_S2	We investigated under the supervision of a DENR Registered Environmental Consultant ( the REC ) and have commenced voluntary clean-up at the facility.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P96_S3	At this time, additional remediation costs are not expected to exceed the accrued balance of $245,000.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P97_S0	We have been a part of the Pendleton Site PRP Group since about 1993.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P97_S1	We sent its pickle liquor wastes from Tonawanda, NY to the Pendleton Site for treatment and disposal.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P97_S2	The Pendleton Site PRP Group signed an Order on Consent with the NYS DEC in 1996 and the cleanup was concluded in the early 2000s.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P97_S3	The Order on Consent required a post-construction operation and maintenance period of 30 years and we are required to pay its share of the costs associated with the operation and maintenance period.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P97_S4	These annual costs are approximately $50,000 of which we pay 13.4% or $6,700.
1005229_14_ITEM1_P97_S5	Reserves on the books are sufficient to cover these costs for the remainder of the operations and maintenance period.

1005229_14_ITEM1_P98_S1	Further, we believe that the environmental matters known to, or anticipated by us should not, individually or in the aggregate, have a material adverse effect on our operating results or financial condition.

1005229_14_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Columbus McKinnon is subject to a number of risk factors that could negatively affect our results from business operations or cause actual results to differ materially from those projected or indicated in any forward looking statement.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Such factors include, but are not limited to, the following:
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Adverse changes in global economic conditions may negatively affect our industry, business and results of operations.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P2_S0	During the last five years, financial markets in the United States, Europe and Asia have experienced substantial disruption including, among other things, extreme volatility in security prices, severely diminished liquidity and credit availability, rating downgrades of certain investments and declining valuations of others.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Governments have taken unprecedented actions intended to address these market conditions and the extent to which such government actions may prove effective remains unclear.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P2_S2	The future economic environment may worsen.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Our industry is affected by changes in economic conditions outside our control, which can result in a general decrease in product demand from our customers.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Such economic developments may affect our business in a number of ways.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Reduced demand may drive us and our competitors to offer products at promotional prices, which would have a negative impact on our profitability.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P3_S3	In addition, the tightening of credit in financial markets may adversely affect the ability of our customers and suppliers to obtain financing for significant purchases and operations and could result in a decrease in, or cancellation of, orders for our products.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P3_S4	If demand for our products slows down or decreases, we will not be able to maintain our revenues and we may run the risk of failing to satisfy the financial and other restrictive covenants to which we are subject under our existing indebtedness.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Reduced revenues as a result of decreased demand may also reduce our planned growth and otherwise hinder our ability to improve our performance in connection with our long term strategy.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Our business is cyclical and is affected by industrial economic conditions.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Many of the end-users of our products are in highly cyclical industries, such as manufacturing, power generation and distribution, commercial construction, oil and gas exploration and refining, transportation, agriculture, logging, and mining that are sensitive to changes in general economic conditions.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Their demand for our products, and thus our results of operations, is directly related to the level of production in their facilities, which changes as a result of changes in general economic conditions and other factors beyond our control.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P5_S2	If there is deterioration in the general economy or in the industries we serve, our business, results of operations and financial condition could be materially adversely affected.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P5_S3	In addition, the cyclical nature of our business could at times also adversely affect our liquidity and ability to borrow under our revolving credit facility.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our business is highly competitive and subject to consolidation of competitors.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Increased competition could reduce our sales, earnings, and profitability.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The principal markets that we serve within the material handling industry are fragmented and highly competitive.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Competition is based primarily on customer service and support as well as product availability, performance, functionality, brand reputation, reliability and price.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Our competition in the markets in which we participate comes from companies of various sizes, some of which have greater financial and other resources than we do.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P7_S3	Increased competition could force us to lower our prices or to offer additional services at a higher cost to us, which could reduce our gross margins and net income.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The greater financial resources or the lower amount of debt of certain of our competitors may enable them to commit larger amounts of capital in response to changing market conditions.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Certain competitors may also have the ability to develop product or service innovations that could put us at a disadvantage.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P8_S2	In addition, through consolidation, some of our competitors have achieved substantially more market penetration in certain of the markets in which we operate.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P8_S3	If we are unable to compete successfully against other manufacturers of material handling equipment, we could lose customers and our revenues may decline.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P8_S4	There can also be no assurance that customers will continue to regard our products favorably, that we will be able to develop new products that appeal to customers, that we will be able to improve or maintain our profit margins on sales to our customers or that we will be able to continue to compete successfully in our core markets.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our operations outside the U.S. pose certain risks that may adversely impact sales and earnings.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We have operations and assets located outside of the United States, primarily in China, Mexico, Germany, the United Kingdom, France, and Hungary.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P10_S1	In addition, we import a portion of our hoist product line from Asia, and sell our products to distributors located in approximately 50 countries.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P10_S2	In our fiscal year ended March 31, 2014, approximately 43% of our net sales were derived from non-U.S. markets.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P10_S3	These non-U.S. operations are subject to a number of special risks, in addition to the risks of our U.S. business, differing protections of intellectual property, trade barriers, labor unrest, exchange controls, regional economic uncertainty, differing (and possibly more stringent) labor regulation, risk of governmental expropriation, U.S. and foreign customs and tariffs, current and changing regulatory environments, difficulty in obtaining distribution support, difficulty in staffing and managing widespread operations, differences in the availability and terms of financing, political instability and risks of increases in taxes.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P10_S4	Also, in some foreign jurisdictions we may be subject to laws limiting the right and ability of entities organized or operating therein to pay dividends or remit earnings to affiliated companies unless specified conditions are met.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P10_S5	These factors may adversely affect our future profits.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Part of our strategy is to expand our worldwide market share and reduce costs by strengthening our international distribution capabilities and sourcing components in lower cost countries, in particular in China and Hungary.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Implementation of this strategy may increase the impact of the risks described above, and we cannot assure you that such risks will not have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Our strategy depends on successful integration of acquisitions.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Acquisitions are a key part of our growth strategy.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Our historical growth has depended, and our future growth is likely to depend on our ability to successfully implement our acquisition strategy, and the successful integration of acquired businesses into our existing business.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P13_S2	We intend to continue to seek additional acquisition opportunities in accordance with our acquisition strategy, both to expand into new markets and to enhance our position in existing markets throughout the world.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P13_S3	If we are unable to successfully integrate acquired businesses into our existing business or expand into new markets, our sales and earnings growth could be reduced.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Our products involve risks of personal injury and property damage, which exposes us to potential liability.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Our business exposes us to possible claims for personal injury or death and property damage resulting from the products that we sell.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P15_S1	We maintain insurance through a combination of self-insurance retentions and excess insurance coverage.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P15_S2	We monitor claims and potential claims of which we become aware and establish accrued liability reserves for the self-insurance amounts based on our liability estimates for such claims.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P15_S3	We cannot give any assurance that existing or future claims will not exceed our estimates for self-insurance or the amount of our excess insurance coverage.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P15_S4	In addition, we cannot give any assurance that insurance will continue to be available to us on economically reasonable terms or that our insurers would not require us to increase our self-insurance amounts.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P15_S5	Claims brought against us that are not covered by insurance or that are in excess of insurance coverage could have a material adverse effect on our results, financial condition, or liquidity.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P16_S0	In addition, like many industrial manufacturers, we are also involved in asbestos-related litigation.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P16_S1	In continually evaluating costs relating to our estimated asbestos-related liability, we review, among other things, the incidence of past and recent claims, the historical case dismissal rate, the mix of the claimed illnesses and occupations of the plaintiffs, our recent and historical resolution of the cases, the number of cases pending against us, the status and results of broad-based settlement discussions, and the number of years such activity might continue.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P16_S2	Based on this review, we estimate our share of liability to defend and resolve probable asbestos related personal injury claims.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P16_S3	This estimate is highly uncertain due to the limitations of the available data and the difficulty of forecasting with any certainty the numerous variables that can affect the range of the liability.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P16_S4	We continue to study the variables in light of additional information in order to identify trends that may become evident and to assess their impact on the range of liability that is probable and estimable.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P16_S5	We believe that the potential additional costs for claims will not have a material after-tax effect on our financial condition or liquidity, although the net after-tax effect of any future liabilities recorded could be material to earnings in a future period.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P16_S6	See Note 16 to our March 31, 2014 consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this form 10K.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P17_S0	As indicated above, our self-insurance coverage is effected through our captive insurance subsidiary.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P17_S1	The reserves of our captive insurance subsidiary are subject to periodic adjustments based upon actuarial evaluations, which adjustments impact our overall results of operations.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P17_S2	These periodic adjustments can be favorable or unfavorable.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P18_S0	We are subject to currency fluctuations from our sales outside the U.S.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Our products are sold in many countries around the world.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Thus, a portion of our revenues (approximately $251,902,000 in our fiscal year ended March 31, 2014) are generated in foreign currencies, including principally the euro, the Canadian dollar, and the Brazilian real, and while much of the costs incurred to generate those revenues are incurred in the same currency, a portion is incurred in other currencies.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P19_S2	Since our financial statements are denominated in U.S. dollars, changes in currency exchange rates between the U.S. dollar and other currencies have had, and will continue to have, a currency translation impact on our earnings.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Currency fluctuations may impact our financial performance in the future.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Our future operating results may be affected by fluctuations in steel or other material prices.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P21_S1	We may not be able to pass on increases in raw material costs to our customers.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P22_S0	The principal raw material used in our chain, forging and crane building operations is steel.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P22_S1	The steel industry as a whole is highly cyclical, and at times pricing and availability can be volatile due to a number of factors beyond our control, including general economic conditions, labor costs, competition, import duties, tariffs and currency exchange rates.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P22_S2	This volatility can significantly affect our raw material costs.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P22_S3	In an environment of increasing raw material prices, competitive conditions will determine how much of the steel price increases we can pass on to our customers.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P22_S4	During historical rising cost periods, we were generally successful in adding and maintaining a surcharge to the prices of our high steel content products or incorporating them into price increases, with a goal of margin neutrality.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P22_S5	In the future, to the extent we are unable to pass on any steel price increases to our customers, our profitability could be adversely affected.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P23_S0	We rely in large part on independent distributors for sales of our products.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P24_S0	For the most part, we depend on independent distributors to sell our products and provide service and aftermarket support to our end-user customers.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P24_S1	Distributors play a significant role in determining which of our products are stocked at their locations, and hence are most readily accessible to aftermarket buyers, and the price at which these products are sold.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P24_S2	Almost all of the distributors with whom we transact business offer competitive products and services to our end-user customers.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P24_S3	For the most part, we do not have written agreements with our distributors.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P24_S4	The loss of a substantial number of these distributors or an increase in the distributors' sales of our competitors' products to our ultimate customers could materially reduce our sales and profits.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P25_S0	We are subject to various environmental laws which may require us to expend significant capital and incur substantial cost.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Our operations and facilities are subject to various federal, state, local and foreign requirements relating to the protection of the environment, including those governing the discharges of pollutants in the air and water, the generation, management and disposal of hazardous substances and wastes and the cleanup of contaminated sites.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P26_S1	We have made, and will continue to make, expenditures to comply with such requirements.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P26_S2	Violations of, or liabilities under, environmental laws and regulations, or changes in such laws and regulations (such as the imposition of more stringent standards for discharges into the environment), could result in substantial costs to us, including operating costs and capital expenditures, fines and civil and criminal sanctions, third party claims for property damage or personal injury, clean-up costs or costs relating to the temporary or permanent discontinuance of operations.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Certain of our facilities have been in operation for many years, and we have remediated contamination at some of our facilities.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Over time, we and other predecessor operators of such facilities have generated, used, handled and disposed of hazardous and other regulated wastes.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Additional environmental liabilities could exist, including clean-up obligations at these locations or other sites at which materials from our operations were disposed, which could result in substantial future expenditures that cannot be currently quantified and which could reduce our profits or have an adverse effect on our financial condition, operations, or liquidity.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P28_S0	We rely on subcontractors or suppliers to perform their contractual obligations.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Some of our contracts involve subcontracts with other companies upon which we rely to perform a portion of the services we must provide to our customers.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P29_S1	There is a risk that we may have disputes with our subcontractors, including disputes regarding the quality and timeliness of work performed by our subcontractor or customer concerns about the subcontractor.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P29_S2	Failure by our subcontractors to satisfactorily provide on a timely basis the agreed-upon supplies or perform the agreed upon services may materially and adversely impact our ability to perform our obligations as the prime contractor.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P29_S3	A delay in our ability to obtain components and equipment parts from our suppliers may affect our ability to meet our customers' needs and may have an adverse effect upon our profitability.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P30_S0	We are subject to debt covenant restrictions.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Our revolving credit facility and the indenture governing the notes contain several financial and other restrictive covenants.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P31_S1	A significant decline in our operating income or cash generating ability could cause us to violate our leverage or fixed charge coverage ratios in our bank credit facility.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P31_S2	This could result in our being unable to borrow under our bank credit facility or being obliged to refinance and renegotiate the terms of our bank indebtedness.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P32_S0	We depend on our senior management team and the loss of any member could adversely affect our operations.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Our success is dependent on the management and leadership skills of our senior management team.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P33_S1	The loss of any of these individuals or an inability to attract, retain and maintain additional personnel could prevent us from implementing our business strategy.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P33_S2	We cannot assure you that we will be able to retain our existing senior management personnel or to attract additional qualified personnel when needed.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P34_S0	We continually evaluate and assess our personnel and may make additional changes to the members or assignments of our senior management team in the future.
1005229_14_ITEM1A_P35_S0	We have not entered into employment agreements with any of our senior management personnel with the exception of Dr. Ivo Celi, our Vice President, EMEA.

1005229_14_ITEM6_P3_S0	(2) The Company had a valuation allowance of $53,325,000 recorded as of March 31, 2012 due to the uncertainty of whether the Company's net operating loss carryforwards and deferred tax assets might ultimately be realized.
1005229_14_ITEM6_P3_S1	The Company was able to utilize $14,567,000 of U.S. federal net operating loss carryforwards in fiscal 2013 which reduced the valuation allowance by $5,107,000.
1005229_14_ITEM6_P4_S0	As a result of the increased operating performance of the Company over the past several years, the Company reevaluated the certainty as to whether the Company's remaining net operating loss carryforwards and other deferred tax assets may ultimately be realized.
1005229_14_ITEM6_P4_S1	As a result of the determination that it is more likely than not that all of the remaining deferred tax assets will be realized with the exception of certain U.S. federal tax credit carryforwards, a significant portion of the remaining U.S. valuation allowance totaling $49,161,000 was reversed in fiscal 2013.
1005229_14_ITEM6_P5_S0	(3) During 2011, the Company recorded non-cash charge of $42,983,000 included within its provision for income taxes.
1005229_14_ITEM6_P5_S1	As noted in footnote number (3) above, this valuation allowance was reversed in fiscal 2013.
1005229_14_ITEM6_P5_S2	The majority of this charge relates to the Company s determination that a full valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets generated in the U.S was necessary.
1005229_14_ITEM6_P6_S0	Accounting rules require a reduction of the carrying amounts of deferred tax assets by a valuation allowance if, based on the available and objectively verifiable evidence, it is more likely than not that such assets will not be realized.
1005229_14_ITEM6_P7_S0	The existence of cumulative losses for a certain threshold period is a significant form of negative evidence used in the assessment.
1005229_14_ITEM6_P7_S1	If a cumulative loss threshold is met, the accounting rules indicate that forecasts of future profitability are generally not sufficient positive evidence to overcome the presumption that a valuation allowance is necessary.
1005229_14_ITEM6_P8_S0	(4) In May 2002, the Company sold substantially all of the assets of ASI.

1005229_14_ITEM7_P0_S1	Comments on the results of operations and financial condition below refer to our continuing operations, except in the section entitled Discontinued Operations.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P1_S0	We are a leading worldwide designer, manufacturer and marketer of material handling products, systems and services which efficiently and safely move, lift, position and secure material.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P1_S1	Key products include hoists, actuators, cranes and rigging tools.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P1_S2	The Company is focused on serving commercial and industrial applications that require the safety and quality provided by the Company s superior design and engineering know-how.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P2_S0	Founded in 1875, we have grown to our current size and leadership position through organic growth and acquisitions.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P2_S1	We developed our leading market position over our 139-year history by emphasizing technological innovation, manufacturing excellence and superior after-sale service.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P2_S2	In addition, acquisitions significantly broadened our product lines and services and expanded our geographic reach, end-user markets and customer base.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P2_S3	Ongoing initiatives include improving our productivity and increasing penetration of the Asian, Latin American and European marketplaces.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P2_S4	In accordance with our strategy, we have been investing in our sales and marketing activities, new product development and Lean efforts across the Company.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P2_S5	Shareholder value will be enhanced through continued emphasis on market expansion, customer satisfaction, new product development, manufacturing efficiency, cost containment, and efficient capital investment.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P3_S0	Over the course of our history, we have managed through many business cycles and our solid cash flow profile has helped us grow and expand globally.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P3_S1	We stand with a capital structure which includes sufficient cash reserves, significant revolver availability with an expiration of October 31, 2017, fixed-rate long-term debt which expires in 2019 and a solid cash flow business profile.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P3_S2	Additionally, our revenue base is geographically diverse with approximately 43% derived from customers outside the U.S. for the year ended March 31, 2014.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P3_S3	We believe this will help balance the impact of changes that will occur in local economies as well as benefit the Company from growth in emerging markets.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P4_S0	As in the past, we monitor both U.S. and Eurozone Industrial Capacity Utilization statistics as indicators of anticipated demand for our products.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P4_S1	Since their June 2009 trough, these statistics have generally improved over the last several years.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P4_S2	In addition, we continue to monitor the potential impact of other global and U.S. trends including industrial production, energy costs, steel price fluctuations, interest rates, foreign currency exchange rates and activity of end-user markets around the globe.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P4_S3	From a strategic perspective, we are investing in global markets and new products as we focus on our greatest opportunities for growth.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P4_S4	We maintain a strong North American market share with significant leading market positions in hoists, load chain, forged fittings and actuators.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P4_S5	We seek to maintain and enhance our market share by focusing our sales and marketing activities toward select North American and global market sectors including energy, general industrial, entertainment, and mining.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P4_S6	Regardless of the economic climate and point in the economic cycle, we constantly explore ways to increase our operating margins as well as further improve our productivity and competitiveness.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P4_S7	We have specific initiatives related to improved workplace safety, customer satisfaction, reduced defects, shortened lead times, improved inventory turns and on-time deliveries, reduced warranty costs, and improved working capital utilization.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P4_S8	The initiatives are being driven by the continued implementation of our Lean efforts which are fundamentally changing our manufacturing and business processes to be more responsive to customer demand and improving on-time delivery and productivity.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P4_S9	In addition to Lean, we are working to achieve these strategic initiatives through product simplification, the creation of centers of excellence, and improved supply chain management.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P5_S0	We continuously monitor market prices of steel.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P5_S1	We purchase approximately $30,000,000 to $40,000,000 of steel annually in a variety of forms including rod, wire, bar, structural and others.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P6_S0	Generally, as we experience fluctuations in our costs, we reflect them as price increases to our customers with the goal of being margin neutral.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P6_S1	We are also looking for opportunities for growth via strategic acquisitions or joint ventures.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P6_S2	The focus of our acquisition strategy centers on product line expansion in alignment with our existing core product offering and opportunities for non-U.S. market penetration.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P6_S3	We operate in a highly competitive and global business environment.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P6_S4	We face a variety of opportunities in those markets and geographies, including trends toward increased utilization of the global labor force and the expansion of market opportunities in Asia and other emerging markets.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P6_S5	While we continue to execute our long-term growth strategy, we are supported by our solid capital structure, including our cash position and flexible cost base.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P6_S6	We are also aggressively pursuing cost reduction opportunities to enhance future margins.

1005229_14_ITEM7_P55_S0	Our costs are affected by inflation in the U.S. economy and, to a lesser extent, in non-U.S. economies including those of Europe, Canada, Mexico, South America and Asia-Pacific.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P55_S1	We do not believe that general inflation has had a material effect on our results of operations over the periods presented primarily due to overall low inflation levels over such periods and our ability to generally pass on rising costs through annual price increases and surcharges.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P55_S2	However, increases in U.S. employee benefits costs such as health insurance, workers compensation insurance, pensions as well as energy and business insurance have exceeded general inflation levels.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P56_S0	In the future, we may be further affected by inflation that we may not be able to pass on as price increases.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P56_S1	With changes in worldwide demand for steel and fluctuating scrap steel prices over the past several years, we experienced fluctuations in our costs that we have reflected as price increases and surcharges to our customers.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P56_S2	We believe we have been successful in instituting surcharges and price increases to pass on these material cost increases.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P56_S3	We will continue to monitor our costs and reevaluate our pricing policies.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P57_S0	Our quarterly results may be materially affected by the timing of large customer orders, periods of high vacation and holiday concentrations, restructuring charges and other costs attributable to our facility rationalization program, divestitures, acquisitions and the magnitude of rationalization integration costs.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P57_S1	Therefore, our operating results for any particular fiscal quarter are not necessarily indicative of results for any subsequent fiscal quarter or for the full fiscal year.

1005229_14_ITEM7_P59_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in our consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P59_S1	We continually evaluate the estimates and their underlying assumptions, which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying value of our assets and liabilities.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P59_S2	Actual results inevitably will differ from those estimates.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P59_S3	If interpreted differently under different conditions or circumstances, changes in our estimates could result in material changes to our reported results.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P60_S0	We have identified below the accounting policies involving estimates that are critical to our financial statements.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P60_S1	Other accounting policies are more fully described in Note 2 of our consolidated financial statements.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P61_S0	Sales are recorded when title passes to the customer which is generally at the time of shipment to the customer.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P61_S1	The Company performs ongoing credit evaluations of its customers financial condition, but generally does not require collateral to support customer receivables.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P61_S2	The credit risk is controlled through credit approvals, limits and monitoring procedures.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P61_S3	Accounts receivable are reported at net realizable value and do not accrue interest.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P61_S4	Sales tax is excluded from revenue.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P62_S0	Pension and Other Postretirement Benefits .
1005229_14_ITEM7_P63_S0	The determination of the obligations and expense for pension and postretirement benefits is dependent on our selection of certain assumptions that are used by actuaries in calculating such amounts.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P63_S1	Those assumptions are disclosed in Note 13 to our fiscal 2014 consolidated financial statements and include the discount rates, expected long-term rate of return on plan assets and rates of future increases in compensation and healthcare costs.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P63_S2	Changes in these assumptions can result in the calculation of different plan expense and liability amounts.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P63_S3	Further, actual experience can differ from the assumptions.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P64_S0	The weighted average pension discount rate assumptions of 4.60%, 4.35%, and 4.70%, as of March 31, 2014 , 2013 , and 2012 , respectively, are based on long-term AA rated corporate and municipal bond rates.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P64_S1	The increase in the discount rate for fiscal 2014 resulted in a $9,200,000 decrease in the projected benefit obligation.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P64_S2	The decrease in the discount rates for fiscal 2013 resulted in an $9,300,000 increase in the projected benefit obligation.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P64_S3	The rate of return on plan assets assumptions of 7.5% for each of the years ended March 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 is based on the targeted plan asset allocation (approximately 65% equities and 35% fixed income) and their long-term historical returns.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P64_S4	Our under-funded status for all pension plans as of March 31, 2014 and 2013 was $37,457,000 and $62,163,000, or 16.6% and 27.1% of the projected benefit obligation, respectively.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P64_S5	Our pension contributions during fiscal 2014 and 2013 were approximately $11,041,000 and $10,328,000, respectively.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P64_S6	The under-funded status may result in future pension expense increases.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P64_S7	Pension expense for the March 31, 2015 fiscal year is expected to approximate $2,973,000, less than the fiscal 2014 amount of $5,838,000.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P64_S8	Pension funding contributions for the March 31, 2015 fiscal year is expected to remain the same as compared to fiscal 2014 .
1005229_14_ITEM7_P64_S9	The compensation increase assumption of 2% as of March 31, 2014 , 2013 , and 2012 is based on expected wage trends and historical patterns.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P65_S0	The healthcare costs inflation assumptions of 7.0% 7.5%, and 8.0% for fiscal 2014 , 2013 , and 2012 , respectively, are based on anticipated trends.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P65_S1	While the healthcare inflation rate assumptions have been decreasing, healthcare costs continue to outpace inflation in the U.S.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P66_S0	Our accrued general and product liability reserves as described in Note 16 to consolidated financial statements involve actuarial techniques including the methods selected to estimate ultimate claims, and assumptions including emergence patterns, payment patterns, initial expected losses and increased limit factors.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P66_S1	These actuarial estimates are subject to a high degree of uncertainty due to a variety of factors, including extended lag time in the reporting and resolution of claims, trends or changes in claim settlement patterns, insurance industry practices, and legal interpretations.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P66_S2	Changes to these estimates could result in material changes to the amount of expense and liabilities recorded in our financial statements.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P66_S3	Further, actual costs could differ significantly from the estimated amounts.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P67_S0	Adjustments to estimated reserves are recorded in the period in which the change in estimate occurs.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P67_S1	Other insurance reserves such as workers compensation and group health insurance are based on actual historical and current claim data provided by third party administrators or internally maintained.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P68_S0	Our goodwill balance of $119,303,000 as of March 31, 2014 is subject to impairment testing.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P68_S1	We test goodwill for impairment at least annually, as of the end of February, and more frequently whenever events occur or circumstances change that indicate there may be impairment.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P68_S2	These events or circumstances could include a significant long-term adverse change in the business climate, poor indicators of operating performance, or a sale or disposition of a significant portion of a reporting unit.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P69_S0	We test goodwill at the reporting unit level, which is one level below our operating segment.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P69_S1	We identify our reporting units by assessing whether the components of our operating segment constitute businesses for which discrete financial information is available and segment management regularly reviews the operating results of those components.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P70_S0	We also aggregate components that have similar economic characteristics into single reporting units (for example, similar products and / or services, similar long-term financial results, product processes, classes of customers, etc.).
1005229_14_ITEM7_P70_S1	We have five reporting units, only three of which have goodwill.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P70_S2	Our Unified Industries, Duff-Norton, and Rest of Products reporting units have goodwill totaling $6,980,000, $9,865,000, and $102,458,000, respectively, at March 31, 2014 .
1005229_14_ITEM7_P71_S0	When we evaluate the potential for goodwill impairment, we assess a range of qualitative factors including, but not limited to, macroeconomic conditions, industry conditions, the competitive environment, changes in the market for our products and services, regulatory and political developments, entity specific factors such as strategy and changes in key personnel and overall financial performance.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P71_S1	If, after completing this assessment, it is determined that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value, we proceed to a two-step impairment test.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P72_S0	We performed our qualitative assessment as of February 28, 2014 and determined that it was not more likely than not that the fair value of each of our reporting units other than Duff-Norton was less than that its applicable carrying value.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P72_S1	Accordingly, we did not perform the two-step goodwill impairment test for any of our reporting units other than the Duff-Norton reporting unit.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P73_S0	In order to perform the two-step impairment test, we use the discounted cash flow method to estimate the fair value of each of our reporting units.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P73_S1	The discounted cash flow method incorporates various assumptions, the most significant being projected revenue growth rates, operating profit margins and cash flows, the terminal growth rate and the discount rate.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P74_S0	Management projects revenue growth rates, operating margins and cash flows based on each reporting unit s current business, expected developments and operational strategies over a five-year period.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P75_S0	In estimating the terminal growth rate, we consider our historical and projected results, as well as the economic environment in which the reporting unit operates.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P75_S1	The discount rates utilized for each reporting unit reflect management s assumptions of marketplace participants cost of capital and risk assumptions, both specific to the reporting unit and overall in the economy.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S0	We performed step one of the two-step impairment test for the Duff-Norton reporting unit.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S1	Testing goodwill for impairment under the two-step method requires us to estimate fair values of reporting units using significant estimates and judgmental factors.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S2	The key estimates and factors used in our discounted cash flow valuation include revenue growth rates and profit margins based on internal forecasts, terminal value, and the weighted-average cost of capital used to discount future cash flows.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S3	The compound annual growth rate for revenue during the first five years of our projections was approximately 5%.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S4	The terminal value was calculated assuming a projected growth rate of 4.5% after five years.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S5	These rates reflect our estimate of long-term growth into perpetuity and approximate the long-term gross domestic product growth expected on a global basis as well as our normal annual price increases.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S6	Operating profit margins were projected to return to historical norms in fiscal 2015 and 2016.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S7	The estimated weighted-average cost of capital for the reporting units was determined to be 12.8% based upon an analysis of similar companies and their debt to equity mix, their related volatility and the size of their market capitalization.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S8	We also consider any additional risk of the Duff-Norton reporting unit achieving its forecast, and adjust the weighted-average cost of capital applied when determining the reporting unit s estimated fair value.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S9	Future changes in these estimates and assumptions could materially affect the results of our goodwill impairment tests.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S10	For example, a decline in the terminal growth rate by 50 basis points would decrease fair market value by $1,128,000 and an increase in the weighted-average cost of capital by 100 basis points would result in a decrease in fair market value by $3,296,000 for the Duff-Norton reporting unit.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P76_S11	Even with such changes the fair value of the reporting units would be greater than their net book values as of February 28, 2014, necessitating no Step 2 calculations.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P77_S0	Purchase Price Allocations for Business Combinations.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P77_S1	During the fiscal year ended March 31, 2014, we completed two business combinations for a total purchase price of $22,354,000.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P78_S0	Under purchase accounting, we recorded assets and liabilities at fair value as of the acquisition dates.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P78_S1	We identified and assigned value to engineered drawings, customer relationships, trademarks and names, backlog, and non-compete contracts.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P78_S2	We estimated the useful lives over which these intangible assets would be amortized.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P78_S3	Valuations of these assets were performed largely using discounted cash flow models and estimates of replacement cost.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P78_S4	These valuations support the conclusion that identifiable intangible assets had a value of $8,659,000.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P79_S0	Assigning value to intangible assets requires estimates used in projecting relevant future cash flows and estimates of replacement costs, in addition to estimating useful lives of such assets.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P80_S0	Allowances for doubtful accounts an d credit memo reserves are also judgmentally determined based on formulas applied to historical bad debt write-offs and credit memos issued, assessing potentially uncollectible customer accounts and analyzing the accounts receivable aging.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P81_S0	Accounts receivable are charged against the allowance for doubtful accounts once all collection efforts have been exhausted.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P81_S1	At March 31, 2014 the allowance for doubtful accounts totaled $2,323,000.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P82_S0	Impairment of depreciable and amortizable long-lived assets .
1005229_14_ITEM7_P82_S1	Property, plant and equipment and certain intangibles are depreciated or amortized over their assigned lives.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P83_S0	We test long-lived assets for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of those assets may not be recoverable and exceed their fair market value.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P83_S1	The following summarizes the value of long-lived assets subject to impairment testing when events or circumstances indicate potential impairment (amounts in millions):
1005229_14_ITEM7_P84_S0	Impairment may exist if the carrying amount of the asset in question exceeds the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P84_S1	The impairment loss, if any, would be measured as the amount by which the carrying amount of a long-lived asset exceeds its fair market value as determined by appropriate valuation techniques.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P85_S0	On a quarterly basis, we review our marketable securities for declines in market value that may be considered other than temporary.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P85_S1	We generally consider market value declines to be other than temporary if there are declines for a period longer than six months and in excess of 20% of original cost.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P85_S2	We also consider the nature of the underlying investments and other market conditions or when other evidence indicates impairment.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P86_S0	Deferred Tax Asset Valuation Allowance .
1005229_14_ITEM7_P87_S0	In fiscal years 2013 and 2012 income taxes as a percentage of income before income taxes were not reflective of U.S. statutory rates.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P87_S1	The Company had a valuation allowance of $53,325,000 at March 31, 2012 due to the uncertainty of whether U.S. federal and certain foreign net operating loss carryforwards ("NOLs") and deferred tax assets might ultimately be realized.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P87_S2	In fiscal year 2013, we utilized the remaining U.S. federal NOLs thereby, reducing the valuation allowance by $5,107,000.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P88_S0	As a result of our increased operating performance over the past several years, we reevaluated the certainty as to whether our remaining NOLs and other deferred tax assets may ultimately be realized.
1005229_14_ITEM7_P88_S1	Management concluded that it is more likely than not that almost all of the remaining deferred tax assets will be realized; therefore, $49,161,000 of the remaining U.S. valuation allowance was reversed as of March 31, 2013 .

1005229_14_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market rates and prices, such as interest rates.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P0_S1	We are exposed to various market risks, including commodity prices for raw materials, foreign currency exchange rates and changes in interest rates.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P0_S2	We may enter into financial instrument transactions, which attempt to manage and reduce the impact of such changes.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P0_S3	We do not enter into derivatives or other financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Our primary commodity risk is related to changes in the price of steel.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P1_S1	We control this risk through negotiating purchase contracts on a consolidated basis and by attempting to build changes in raw material costs into the selling prices of or surcharges on our products.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P1_S2	We have not entered into financial instrument transactions related to raw material costs.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P2_S0	In fiscal 2014, 43% of our net sales were from manufacturing plants and sales offices in foreign jurisdictions.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P2_S1	We manufacture our products in the United States, China, Germany, United Kingdom, Hungary, Mexico and France and sell our products in approximately 50 countries.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Our results of operations could be affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency rates or weak economic conditions in foreign markets.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Our operating results are exposed to fluctuations between the U.S. dollar and the Canadian dollar, European currencies, the Mexican peso, the Brazilian real, and the Chinese yuan.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P2_S4	For example, when the U.S. dollar weakens against the Euro, the value of our net sales and net income denominated in Euros increases when translated into U.S. dollars for inclusion in our consolidated results.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P3_S0	We are also exposed to foreign currency fluctuations in relation to purchases denominated in foreign currencies.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P3_S1	Our foreign currency risk is mitigated since the majority of our foreign operations net sales and the related expense transactions are denominated in the same currency so therefore a significant change in foreign exchange rates would likely have a very minor impact on net income.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P3_S2	For example, a 10% change in the value of the U.S. dollar in relation to our most significant foreign currency exposures would have had an impact of approximately $1,400,000 on our income from operations.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P3_S3	In addition, the majority of our export sale transactions are denominated in U.S. dollars.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The Company has foreign currency forward agreements in place to hedge changes in the value of recorded foreign currency liabilities due to changes in foreign exchange rates at the settlement date.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P4_S1	The notional amount of those derivatives is $3,659,000 and all contracts mature within twelve months.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P4_S2	These contracts are marked to market each balance sheet date and are not designated as hedges.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The Company has foreign currency forward agreements that are designated as cash flow hedges to hedge a portion of forecasted inventory purchases, denominated in a foreign currency.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The notional amount of those derivatives is $3,402,000 and all contracts mature within fourteen months of March 31, 2014.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P6_S0	We control risk related to changes in interest rates by structuring our debt instruments with a combination of fixed and variable interest rates and by evaluating the need to enter into financial instrument transactions as appropriate.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P6_S1	At March 31, 2014, we do not have any material swap agreements or similar financial instruments in place.
1005229_14_ITEM7A_P6_S2	At March 31, 2014 and 2013, all of our outstanding debt had fixed interest rates.
