1005229_15_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Columbus McKinnon is subject to a number of risk factors that could negatively affect our results from business operations or cause actual results to differ materially from those projected or indicated in any forward looking statement.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Such factors include, but are not limited to, the following:
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Adverse changes in global economic conditions may negatively affect our industry, business and results of operations.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P2_S0	During the last five years, financial markets in the United States, Europe and Asia have experienced substantial disruption including, among other things, extreme volatility in security prices, severely diminished liquidity and credit availability, rating downgrades of certain investments and declining valuations of others.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Governments have taken unprecedented actions intended to address these market conditions and the extent to which such government actions may prove effective remains unclear.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P2_S2	The future economic environment may worsen.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Our industry is affected by changes in economic conditions outside our control, which can result in a general decrease in product demand from our customers.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Such economic developments may affect our business in a number of ways.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Reduced demand may drive us and our competitors to offer products at promotional prices, which would have a negative impact on our profitability.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P3_S3	In addition, the tightening of credit in financial markets may adversely affect the ability of our customers and suppliers to obtain financing for significant purchases and operations and could result in a decrease in, or cancellation of, orders for our products.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P3_S4	If demand for our products slows down or decreases, we will not be able to maintain our revenues and we may run the risk of failing to satisfy the financial and other restrictive covenants to which we are subject under our existing indebtedness.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Reduced revenues as a result of decreased demand may also reduce our planned growth and otherwise hinder our ability to improve our performance in connection with our long term strategy.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Our business is cyclical and is affected by industrial economic conditions.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Many of the end-users of our products are in highly cyclical industries, such as manufacturing, power generation and distribution, commercial construction, oil and gas exploration and refining, transportation, agriculture, logging, and mining that are sensitive to changes in general economic conditions.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Their demand for our products, and thus our results of operations, is directly related to the level of production in their facilities, which changes as a result of changes in general economic conditions and other factors beyond our control.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P5_S2	If there is deterioration in the general economy or in the industries we serve, our business, results of operations and financial condition could be materially adversely affected.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P5_S3	In addition, the cyclical nature of our business could at times also adversely affect our liquidity and ability to borrow under our revolving credit facility.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our business is highly competitive and subject to consolidation of competitors.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Increased competition could reduce our sales, earnings, and profitability.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The principal markets that we serve within the material handling industry are fragmented and highly competitive.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Competition is based primarily on customer service and support as well as product availability, performance, functionality, brand reputation, reliability and price.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Our competition in the markets in which we participate comes from companies of various sizes, some of which have greater financial and other resources than we do.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P7_S3	Increased competition could force us to lower our prices or to offer additional services at a higher cost to us, which could reduce our gross margins and net income.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The greater financial resources or the lower amount of debt of certain of our competitors may enable them to commit larger amounts of capital in response to changing market conditions.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Certain competitors may also have the ability to develop product or service innovations that could put us at a disadvantage.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P8_S2	In addition, through consolidation, some of our competitors have achieved substantially more market penetration in certain of the markets in which we operate.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P8_S3	If we are unable to compete successfully against other manufacturers of material handling equipment, we could lose customers and our revenues may decline.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P8_S4	There can also be no assurance that customers will continue to regard our products favorably, that we will be able to develop new products that appeal to customers, that we will be able to improve or maintain our profit margins on sales to our customers or that we will be able to continue to compete successfully in our core markets.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our operations outside the U.S. pose certain risks that may adversely impact sales and earnings.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We have operations and assets located outside of the United States, primarily in China, Mexico, Germany, the United Kingdom, France, and Hungary.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P10_S1	In addition, we import a portion of our hoist product line from Asia, and sell our products to distributors located in approximately 50 countries.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P10_S2	In our fiscal year ended March 31, 2015, approximately 42% of our net sales were derived from non-U.S. markets.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P10_S3	These non-U.S. operations are subject to a number of special risks, in addition to the risks of our U.S. business, differing protections of intellectual property, trade barriers, labor unrest, exchange controls, regional economic uncertainty, differing (and possibly more stringent) labor regulation, risk of governmental expropriation, U.S. and foreign customs and tariffs, current and changing regulatory environments, difficulty in obtaining distribution support, difficulty in staffing and managing widespread operations, differences in the availability and terms of financing, political instability and risks of increases in taxes.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P10_S4	Also, in some foreign jurisdictions we may be subject to laws limiting the right and ability of entities organized or operating therein to pay dividends or remit earnings to affiliated companies unless specified conditions are met.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P10_S5	These factors may adversely affect our future profits.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Part of our strategy is to expand our worldwide market share and reduce costs by strengthening our international distribution capabilities and sourcing components in lower cost countries, in particular in China, Mexico, and Hungary.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Implementation of this strategy may increase the impact of the risks described above, and we cannot assure you that such risks will not have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Our strategy depends on successful integration of acquisitions.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Acquisitions are a key part of our growth strategy.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Our historical growth has depended, and our future growth is likely to depend on our ability to successfully implement our acquisition strategy, and the successful integration of acquired businesses into our existing business.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P13_S2	We intend to continue to seek additional acquisition opportunities in accordance with our acquisition strategy, both to expand into new markets and to enhance our position in existing markets throughout the world.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P13_S3	If we are unable to successfully integrate acquired businesses into our existing business or expand into new markets, our sales and earnings growth could be reduced.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Our products involve risks of personal injury and property damage, which exposes us to potential liability.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Our business exposes us to possible claims for personal injury or death and property damage resulting from the products that we sell.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P15_S1	We maintain insurance through a combination of self-insurance retentions and excess insurance coverage.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P15_S2	We monitor claims and potential claims of which we become aware and establish accrued liability reserves for the self-insurance amounts based on our liability estimates for such claims.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P15_S3	We cannot give any assurance that existing or future claims will not exceed our estimates for self-insurance or the amount of our excess insurance coverage.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P15_S4	In addition, we cannot give any assurance that insurance will continue to be available to us on economically reasonable terms or that our insurers would not require us to increase our self-insurance amounts.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P15_S5	Claims brought against us that are not covered by insurance or that are in excess of insurance coverage could have a material adverse effect on our results, financial condition, or liquidity.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P16_S0	In addition, like many industrial manufacturers, we are also involved in asbestos-related litigation.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P16_S1	In continually evaluating costs relating to our estimated asbestos-related liability, we review, among other things, the incidence of past and recent claims, the historical case dismissal rate, the mix of the claimed illnesses and occupations of the plaintiffs, our recent and historical resolution of the cases, the number of cases pending against us, the status and results of broad-based settlement discussions, and the number of years such activity might continue.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P16_S2	Based on this review, we estimate our share of liability to defend and resolve probable asbestos related personal injury claims.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P16_S3	This estimate is highly uncertain due to the limitations of the available data and the difficulty of forecasting with any certainty the numerous variables that can affect the range of the liability.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P16_S4	We continue to study the variables in light of additional information in order to identify trends that may become evident and to assess their impact on the range of liability that is probable and estimable.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P17_S0	We believe that the potential additional costs for claims will not have a material effect on the financial condition of the Company or its liquidity, although the effect of any future liabilities recorded could be material to earnings in a future period.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P17_S1	See Note 16 to our March 31, 2015 consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this form 10K.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P18_S0	As indicated above, our self-insurance coverage is effected through our captive insurance subsidiary.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P18_S1	The reserves of our captive insurance subsidiary are subject to periodic adjustments based upon actuarial evaluations, which adjustments impact our overall results of operations.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P18_S2	These periodic adjustments can be favorable or unfavorable.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We are subject to currency fluctuations from our sales outside the U.S.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Our products are sold in many countries around the world.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Thus, a portion of our revenues (approximately $244,033,000 in our fiscal year ended March 31, 2015) are generated in foreign currencies, including principally the euro, the British Pound, the Canadian dollar, and the Brazilian real, and while much of the costs incurred to generate those revenues are incurred in the same currency, a portion is incurred in other currencies.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Since our financial statements are denominated in U.S. dollars, changes in currency exchange rates between the U.S. dollar and other currencies have had, and will continue to have, a currency translation impact on our earnings.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Currency fluctuations may impact our financial performance in the future.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Our future operating results may be affected by fluctuations in steel or other material prices.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P22_S1	We may not be able to pass on increases in raw material costs to our customers.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P23_S0	The principal raw material used in our chain, forging and crane building operations is steel.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P23_S1	The steel industry as a whole is highly cyclical, and at times pricing and availability can be volatile due to a number of factors beyond our control, including general economic conditions, labor costs, competition, import duties, tariffs and currency exchange rates.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P23_S2	This volatility can significantly affect our raw material costs.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P23_S3	In an environment of increasing raw material prices, competitive conditions will determine how much of the steel price increases we can pass on to our customers.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P23_S4	During historical rising cost periods, we were generally successful in adding and maintaining a surcharge to the prices of our high steel content products or incorporating them into price increases, with a goal of margin neutrality.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P23_S5	In the future, to the extent we are unable to pass on any steel price increases to our customers, our profitability could be adversely affected.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P24_S0	We rely in large part on independent distributors for sales of our products.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P25_S0	For the most part, we depend on independent distributors to sell our products and provide service and aftermarket support to our end-user customers.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Distributors play a significant role in determining which of our products are stocked at their locations, and hence are most readily accessible to aftermarket buyers, and the price at which these products are sold.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Almost all of the distributors with whom we transact business offer competitive products and services to our end-user customers.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P25_S3	For the most part, we do not have written agreements with our distributors.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P25_S4	The loss of a substantial number of these distributors or an increase in the distributors' sales of our competitors' products to our ultimate customers could materially reduce our sales and profits.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P26_S0	We are subject to various environmental laws which may require us to expend significant capital and incur substantial cost.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Our operations and facilities are subject to various federal, state, local and foreign requirements relating to the protection of the environment, including those governing the discharges of pollutants in the air and water, the generation, management and disposal of hazardous substances and wastes and the cleanup of contaminated sites.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P27_S1	We have made, and will continue to make, expenditures to comply with such requirements.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Violations of, or liabilities under, environmental laws and regulations, or changes in such laws and regulations (such as the imposition of more stringent standards for discharges into the environment), could result in substantial costs to us, including operating costs and capital expenditures, fines and civil and criminal sanctions, third party claims for property damage or personal injury, clean-up costs or costs relating to the temporary or permanent discontinuance of operations.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Certain of our facilities have been in operation for many years, and we have remediated contamination at some of our facilities.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P28_S1	Over time, we and other predecessor operators of such facilities have generated, used, handled and disposed of hazardous and other regulated wastes.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P28_S2	Additional environmental liabilities could exist, including clean-up obligations at these locations or other sites at which materials from our operations were disposed, which could result in substantial future expenditures that cannot be currently quantified and which could reduce our profits or have an adverse effect on our financial condition, operations, or liquidity.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P29_S0	We rely on subcontractors or suppliers to perform their contractual obligations.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Some of our contracts involve subcontracts with other companies upon which we rely to perform a portion of the services we must provide to our customers.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P30_S1	There is a risk that we may have disputes with our subcontractors, including disputes regarding the quality and timeliness of work performed by our subcontractor or customer concerns about the subcontractor.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P30_S2	Failure by our subcontractors to satisfactorily provide on a timely basis the agreed-upon supplies or perform the agreed upon services may materially and adversely impact our ability to perform our obligations as the prime contractor.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P30_S3	A delay in our ability to obtain components and equipment parts from our suppliers may affect our ability to meet our customers' needs and may have an adverse effect upon our profitability.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P31_S0	We are subject to debt covenant restrictions.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Our revolving credit facility and Term Loan contain several financial and other restrictive covenants.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P32_S1	A significant decline in our operating income or cash generating ability could cause us to violate our leverage or fixed charge coverage ratios in our bank credit facility.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P32_S2	This could result in our being unable to borrow under our bank credit facility or being obliged to refinance and renegotiate the terms of our bank indebtedness.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P33_S0	We depend on our senior management team and the loss of any member could adversely affect our operations.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Our success is dependent on the management and leadership skills of our senior management team.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P34_S1	The loss of any of these individuals or an inability to attract, retain and maintain additional personnel could prevent us from implementing our business strategy.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P34_S2	We cannot assure you that we will be able to retain our existing senior management personnel or to attract additional qualified personnel when needed.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P35_S0	We continually evaluate and assess our personnel and may make additional changes to the members or assignments of our senior management team in the future.
1005229_15_ITEM1A_P36_S0	We have not entered into employment agreements with any of our senior management personnel with the exception of Dr. Ivo Celi, our Vice President, EMEA.

1005229_15_ITEM6_P1_S0	(1) The Company had a valuation allowance of $53,325,000 recorded as of March 31, 2012 due to the uncertainty of whether the Company's net operating loss carryforwards and deferred tax assets might ultimately be realized.
1005229_15_ITEM6_P1_S1	The Company was able to utilize $14,567,000 of U.S. federal net operating loss carryforwards in fiscal 2013 which reduced the valuation allowance by $5,107,000.
1005229_15_ITEM6_P2_S0	As a result of the increased operating performance of the Company over the past several years, the Company reevaluated the certainty as to whether the Company's remaining net operating loss carryforwards and other deferred tax assets may ultimately be realized.
1005229_15_ITEM6_P2_S1	As a result of the determination that it is more likely than not that all of the remaining deferred tax assets will be realized with the exception of certain U.S. federal tax credit carryforwards, a significant portion of the remaining U.S. valuation allowance totaling $49,161,000 was reversed in fiscal 2013.
1005229_15_ITEM6_P3_S0	(2) During 2011, the Company recorded non-cash charge of $42,983,000 included within its provision for income taxes.
1005229_15_ITEM6_P3_S1	As noted in footnote number (1) above, this valuation allowance was reversed in fiscal 2013.
1005229_15_ITEM6_P3_S2	The majority of this charge relates to the Company s determination that a full valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets generated in the U.S was necessary.
1005229_15_ITEM6_P4_S0	Accounting rules require a reduction of the carrying amounts of deferred tax assets by a valuation allowance if, based on the available and objectively verifiable evidence, it is more likely than not that such assets will not be realized.
1005229_15_ITEM6_P5_S0	The existence of cumulative losses for a certain threshold period is a significant form of negative evidence used in the assessment.
1005229_15_ITEM6_P5_S1	If a cumulative loss threshold is met, the accounting rules indicate that forecasts of future profitability are generally not sufficient positive evidence to overcome the presumption that a valuation allowance is necessary.

1005229_15_ITEM7_P0_S0	This section should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this annual report.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P0_S1	Comments on the results of operations and financial condition below refer to our continuing operations, except in the section entitled Discontinued Operations.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P1_S0	We are a leading worldwide designer, manufacturer and marketer of material handling products, systems and services which efficiently and safely move, lift, position and secure material.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P1_S1	Key products include hoists, actuators, cranes and rigging tools.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P1_S2	The Company is focused on serving commercial and industrial applications that require the safety and quality provided by the Company s superior design and engineering know-how.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P2_S0	Founded in 1875, we have grown to our current size and leadership position through organic growth and acquisitions.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P2_S1	We developed our leading market position over our 140-year history by emphasizing technological innovation, manufacturing excellence and superior after-sale service.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P2_S2	In addition, acquisitions significantly broadened our product lines and services and expanded our geographic reach, end-user markets and customer base.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P2_S3	Ongoing initiatives include growing revenue by increasing our penetration of the Asian, Latin American and European marketplaces, pursuing new products and targeted vertical markets, and by improving our productivity.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P2_S4	In accordance with our strategy, we have been investing in our sales and marketing activities, new product development and Lean efforts across the Company.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P2_S5	Shareholder value will be enhanced through continued emphasis on market expansion, customer satisfaction, new product development, manufacturing efficiency, cost containment, and efficient capital investment.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P3_S0	During fiscal 2015, we significantly enhanced our capital structure.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P3_S1	We elected to redeem our 7 7/8% Notes.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P3_S2	In connection with this, we entered into a new $150,000,000 senior secured revolving credit facility and established a new $125,000,000 delayed draw senior secured term loan facility effective January 23, 2015.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P3_S3	Our previous revolving credit facility was canceled as a result of this transaction.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P3_S4	Both the revolver and the new term loan have five-year terms maturing in 2020.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P3_S5	The proceeds from the new term loan and $25,000,000 in cash were used to redeem the 7 7/8% Notes.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P3_S6	This refinancing provides additional flexibility to our capital structure by allowing prepayable debt and will significantly reduce our cash interest expense by approximately $7,600,000 annually.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P3_S7	The cash interest savings are based on a weighted average interest rate of approximately 2.8% which reflects the Company s policy of maintaining a fixed interest ratio of 50-70%.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P4_S0	Additionally, our revenue base is geographically diverse with approximately 42% derived from customers outside the U.S. for the year ended March 31, 2015.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P4_S1	We believe this will help balance the impact of changes that will occur in local economies as well as benefit the Company from growth in emerging markets.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P5_S0	As in the past, we monitor both U.S. and Eurozone Industrial Capacity Utilization statistics as indicators of anticipated demand for our products.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P5_S1	Since their June 2009 trough, these statistics have improved.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P5_S2	However, over the past year, the Eurozone statistics have been relatively flat as the outlook for the Eurozone appears to be for low growth in the coming year.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P5_S3	In addition, we continue to monitor the potential impact of other global and U.S. trends including industrial production, energy costs, steel price fluctuations, interest rates, foreign currency exchange rates and activity of end-user markets around the globe.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P6_S0	From a strategic perspective, we are investing in global markets and new products as we focus on our greatest opportunities for growth.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P6_S1	We maintain a strong North American market share with significant leading market positions in hoists, lifting and sling chain, forged attachments and actuators.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P6_S2	We seek to maintain and enhance our market share by focusing our sales and marketing activities toward select North American and global market sectors including energy, automotive, heavy OEM, entertainment, and construction and infrastructure.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P7_S0	Regardless of the economic climate and point in the economic cycle, we constantly explore ways to increase our operating margins as well as further improve our productivity and competitiveness.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P7_S1	We have specific initiatives related to improved customer satisfaction, reduced defects, shortened lead times, improved inventory turns and on-time deliveries, reduced warranty costs, and improved working capital utilization.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P7_S2	The initiatives are being driven by the continued implementation of our Lean efforts which are fundamentally changing our manufacturing and business processes to be more responsive to customer demand and improving on-time delivery and productivity.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P7_S3	In addition to Lean, we are working to achieve these strategic initiatives through product simplification, the creation of centers of excellence, and improved supply chain management.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P7_S4	We are also aggressively pursuing cost reduction opportunities to enhance future margins.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P8_S0	We continuously monitor market prices of steel.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P8_S1	We purchase approximately $30,000,000 to $40,000,000 of steel annually in a variety of forms including rod, wire, bar, structural and others.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P9_S0	Generally, as we experience fluctuations in our costs, we reflect them as price increases or surcharges to our customers with the goal of being margin neutral.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P10_S0	We are also looking for opportunities for growth via strategic acquisitions or joint ventures.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P10_S1	The focus of our acquisition strategy centers on product line expansion in alignment with our existing core product offering and opportunities for non-U.S. market penetration.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P11_S0	We operate in a highly competitive and global business environment.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P11_S1	We face a variety of opportunities in those markets and geographies, including trends toward increased utilization of the global labor force and the expansion of market opportunities in Asia and other emerging markets.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P11_S2	While we continue to execute our long-term growth strategy, we are supported by our solid capital structure, including our cash position and flexible cost base.

1005229_15_ITEM7_P48_S0	The terms of the New Credit Agreement include the following:
1005229_15_ITEM7_P49_S0	An aggregate $125,000,000 secured term loan facility which requires quarterly principal amortization of 2.5% with the remaining principal due at maturity date.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P50_S0	An aggregate $150,000,000 secured revolving credit facility which includes sublimits for the issuance of standby letters of credit, swingline loans and multi-currency borrowings in certain specified foreign currencies.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P51_S0	Fees and Interest Rates: Commitment fees and interest rates are determined on the basis of either a Eurocurrency rate or a Base rate plus an applicable margin based upon the Company's Total Leverage Ratio (as defined in the New Credit Agreement).
1005229_15_ITEM7_P52_S0	Prepayments: Provisions permitting a Borrower to voluntarily prepay either the Term Loan or New Revolving Credit Facility in whole or in part at any time, and provisions requiring certain mandatory prepayments of the Term Loan or New Revolving Credit Facility on the occurrence of certain events which will permanently reduce the commitments under the New Credit Agreement, each without premium or penalty.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P53_S0	A Borrower may irrevocably cancel, in whole or in part, the unutilized portion of the commitments under the New Credit Agreement in excess of any outstanding loans, the stated amount of all outstanding letters of credit and all unreimbursed amounts drawn under any letters of credit.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P54_S0	Covenants: Provisions containing covenants required of the Company and its subsidiaries including various affirmative and negative financial and operational covenants.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P54_S1	Key financial covenants include a minimum fixed charge coverage ratio of 1.25x; a maximum total leverage ratio, net of cash, of 3.50x (which may be temporarily increased following a material acquisition, which may be elected two times over the course of the New Credit Agreement, (i) if financed by secured debt the total leverage rate as at the end of the fiscal quarter in which such material acquisition occurs and the three fiscal quarters immediately thereafter, shall not be greater than 4.00:1.00 and as at the end of any fiscal quarter thereafter, the total leverage ratio shall not be greater than 3.50:1.00, and (ii) if financed with unsecured or subordinated indebtedness, the total leverage ratio at the end of the fiscal quarter in which such material acquisition occurs and at the end of any fiscal quarter thereafter, shall not be greater than 4.50:1.00, and permit the secured leverage ratio, to be greater than 3.25:1.00), and maximum capital expenditures of $30 million per fiscal year ($40 million following a material acquisition) with the ability to transfer any unused portion of expenditure to the immediately following fiscal year.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P54_S2	Our actual fixed charges coverage ratio and total leverage ratio, as calculated per the terms of our New Revolving Credit Facility, were 0.89x and 4.52x, respectively, at March 31, 2015.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P55_S0	The New Revolving Credit Facility is secured by all U.S. inventory, receivables, equipment, real property, subsidiary stock (limited to 65% of non-U.S. subsidiaries) and intellectual property.

1005229_15_ITEM7_P65_S0	Our costs are affected by inflation in the U.S. economy and, to a lesser extent, in non-U.S. economies including those of Europe, Canada, Mexico, South America and Asia-Pacific.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P65_S1	We do not believe that general inflation has had a material effect on our results of operations over the periods presented primarily due to overall low inflation levels over such periods and our ability to generally pass on rising costs through annual price increases and surcharges.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P65_S2	However, increases in U.S. employee benefits costs such as health insurance and workers compensation insurance have exceeded general inflation levels.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P65_S3	In the future, we may be further affected by inflation that we may not be able to pass on as price increases.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P65_S4	With changes in worldwide demand for steel and fluctuating scrap steel prices over the past several years, we experienced fluctuations in our costs that we have reflected as price increases and surcharges to our customers.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P65_S5	We believe we have been successful in instituting surcharges and price increases to pass on these material cost increases.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P65_S6	We will continue to monitor our costs and reevaluate our pricing policies.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P66_S0	Our quarterly results may be materially affected by the timing of large customer orders, periods of high vacation and holiday concentrations, restructuring charges and other costs attributable to plan closures as well as divestitures and acquisitions.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P66_S1	Therefore, our operating results for any particular fiscal quarter are not necessarily indicative of results for any subsequent fiscal quarter or for the full fiscal year.

1005229_15_ITEM7_P68_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in our consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P68_S1	We continually evaluate the estimates and their underlying assumptions, which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying value of our assets and liabilities.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P68_S2	Actual results inevitably will differ from those estimates.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P68_S3	If interpreted differently under different conditions or circumstances, changes in our estimates could result in material changes to our reported results.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P69_S0	We have identified below the accounting policies involving estimates that are critical to our financial statements.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P69_S1	Other accounting policies are more fully described in Note 2 of our consolidated financial statements.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P70_S0	Sales are recorded when title passes to the customer which is generally at the time of shipment to the customer.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P70_S1	The Company performs ongoing credit evaluations of its customers financial condition, but generally does not require collateral to support customer receivables.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P70_S2	The credit risk is controlled through credit approvals, limits and monitoring procedures.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P70_S3	Accounts receivable are reported at net realizable value and do not accrue interest.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P70_S4	Sales tax is excluded from revenue.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P71_S0	Pension and Other Postretirement Benefits .
1005229_15_ITEM7_P72_S0	The determination of the obligations and expense for pension and postretirement benefits is dependent on our selection of certain assumptions that are used by actuaries in calculating such amounts.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P72_S1	Those assumptions are disclosed in Note 13 to our fiscal 2015 consolidated financial statements and include the discount rates, expected long-term rate of return on plan assets and rates of future increases in compensation and healthcare costs.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P72_S2	Changes in these assumptions can result in the calculation of different plan expense and liability amounts.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P72_S3	Further, actual experience can differ from the assumptions.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S0	The weighted average pension discount rate assumptions of 3.83% , 4.60%, and 4.35%, as of March 31, 2015 , 2014 , and 2013 , respectively, are based on long-term AA rated corporate and municipal bond rates.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S1	The decrease in the discount rate for fiscal 2015 resulted in a $19,400,000 increase in the projected benefit obligation.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S2	Additionally, the Company adopted updated mortality tables in calculating its U.S. pension obligation.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S3	The change in mortality tables resulted in a $15,400,000 increase in the projected benefit obligation.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S4	The increase in the discount rates for fiscal 2014 resulted in a $9,300,000 decrease in the projected benefit obligation.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S5	The rate of return on plan assets assumptions of 7.50% for the years ended March 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 is based on the targeted plan asset allocation (approximately 65% equities and 35% fixed income) and their long-term historical returns.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S6	Our under-funded status for all pension plans as of March 31, 2015 and 2014 was $57,339,000 and $37,457,000, or 21.9% and 16.6% of the projected benefit obligation, respectively.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S7	Our pension contributions during fiscal 2015 and 2014 were approximately $11,013,000 and $11,041,000, respectively.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S8	The under-funded status may result in future pension expense increases.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S9	Pension expense for the March 31, 2016 fiscal year is expected to approximate $700,000, less than the fiscal 2015 amount of $1,361,000 .
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S10	Pension funding contributions for the March 31, 2016 fiscal year are expected to approximate $5,908,000 .
1005229_15_ITEM7_P73_S11	The compensation increase assumption of 2.3% as of March 31, 2015 and 2.0% as of March 31, 2014 and 2013 is based on expected wage trends and historical patterns.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P74_S0	The healthcare costs inflation assumptions of 7.0% 7.0%, and 7.5% for fiscal 2015 , 2014 , and 2013 , respectively, are based on anticipated trends.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P74_S1	While the healthcare inflation rate assumptions have been decreasing, healthcare costs continue to outpace inflation in the U.S.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P75_S0	Our accrued general and product liability reserves as described in Note 16 to consolidated financial statements involve actuarial techniques including the methods selected to estimate ultimate claims, and assumptions including emergence patterns, payment patterns, initial expected losses and increased limit factors.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P75_S1	These actuarial estimates are subject to a high degree of uncertainty due to a variety of factors, including extended lag time in the reporting and resolution of claims, trends or changes in claim settlement patterns, insurance industry practices, and legal interpretations.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P75_S2	Changes to these estimates could result in material changes to the amount of expense and liabilities recorded in our financial statements.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P75_S3	Further, actual costs could differ significantly from the estimated amounts.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P76_S0	Adjustments to estimated reserves are recorded in the period in which the change in estimate occurs.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P76_S1	Other insurance reserves such as workers compensation and group health insurance are based on actual historical and current claim data provided by third party administrators or internally maintained.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P77_S0	Our goodwill balance of $121,461,000 as of March 31, 2015 is subject to impairment testing.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P77_S1	We test goodwill for impairment at least annually, as of the end of February, and more frequently whenever events occur or circumstances change that indicate there may be impairment.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P77_S2	These events or circumstances could include a significant long-term adverse change in the business climate, poor indicators of operating performance, or a sale or disposition of a significant portion of a reporting unit.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P78_S0	We test goodwill at the reporting unit level, which is one level below our operating segment.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P78_S1	We identify our reporting units by assessing whether the components of our operating segment constitute businesses for which discrete financial information is available and segment management regularly reviews the operating results of those components.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P79_S0	We also aggregate components that have similar economic characteristics into single reporting units (for example, similar products and / or services, similar long-term financial results, product processes, classes of customers, etc.).
1005229_15_ITEM7_P79_S1	We have four reporting units, only two of which have goodwill.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P79_S2	Duff-Norton and Rest of Products reporting units have goodwill totaling $9,563,000, and $111,898,000, respectively, at March 31, 2015 .
1005229_15_ITEM7_P80_S0	When we evaluate the potential for goodwill impairment, we assess a range of qualitative factors including, but not limited to, macroeconomic conditions, industry conditions, the competitive environment, changes in the market for our products and services, regulatory and political developments, entity specific factors such as strategy and changes in key personnel and overall financial performance.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P80_S1	If, after completing this assessment, it is determined that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value, we proceed to a two-step impairment test.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P81_S0	We performed our qualitative assessment as of February 28, 2015 and determined that it was not more likely than not that the fair value of each of our reporting units other than Rest of Products was less than its applicable carrying value.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P81_S1	Accordingly, we did not perform the two-step goodwill impairment test for any of our reporting units other than the Rest of Products reporting unit.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P82_S0	In order to perform the two-step impairment test, we use the discounted cash flow method and comparable market method to estimate fair value.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P83_S0	The discounted cash flow method incorporates various assumptions, the most significant being projected revenue growth rates, operating profit margins and cash flows, the terminal growth rate and the discount rate.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P84_S0	Management projects revenue growth rates, operating margins and cash flows based on each reporting unit s current business, expected developments and operational strategies over a five-year period.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P85_S0	In estimating the terminal growth rate, we consider our historical and projected results, as well as the economic environment in which the reporting unit operates.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P85_S1	The discount rates utilized for each reporting unit reflect management s assumptions of marketplace participants cost of capital and risk assumptions, both specific to the reporting unit and overall in the economy.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P86_S0	The comparable market method estimates fair value based on prices obtained in actual transactions.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P86_S1	The method consists of examining selling prices for comparable assets.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P86_S2	After studying the selling prices, value adjustments are made for any dissimilarities.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P87_S0	We performed step one of the two-step impairment test for the Rest of Products reporting unit.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P87_S1	Testing goodwill for impairment under the two-step method requires us to estimate fair values of reporting units using significant estimates and judgmental factors.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P87_S2	The key estimates and factors used in our discounted cash flow valuation include revenue growth rates and profit margins based on internal forecasts, terminal value, and the weighted-average cost of capital used to discount future cash flows.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P87_S3	The compound annual growth rate for revenue during the first six years of our projections was approximately 3.8%.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P87_S4	The terminal value was calculated assuming a projected growth rate of 3.0% after six years.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P87_S5	These rates reflect our estimate of long-term growth into perpetuity and approximate the long-term gross domestic product growth expected on a global basis as well as our normal annual price increases.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P87_S6	The estimated weighted-average cost of capital for the reporting units was determined to be 10.1% based upon an analysis of similar companies and their debt to equity mix, their related volatility and the size of their market capitalization.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P87_S7	We also consider any additional risk of the Rest of Product reporting unit achieving its forecast, and adjust the weighted-average cost of capital applied when determining the reporting unit s estimated fair value.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P87_S8	Future changes in these estimates and assumptions could materially affect the results of our goodwill impairment tests.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P87_S9	For example, a decline in the terminal growth rate by 50 basis points would decrease fair market value by $10,851,000 and an increase in the weighted-average cost of capital by 100 basis points would result in a decrease in fair market value by $33,478,000 for the Rest of Products reporting unit.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P87_S10	Even with such changes the fair value of the reporting unit would be greater than its net book value as of February 28, 2015, necessitating no Step 2 calculations.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P88_S0	Purchase Price Allocations for Business Combinations.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P88_S1	During the fiscal year ended March 31, 2015, we completed a business combination for a total purchase price of $25,423,000 plus $6,487,000 in the assumption of debt.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P89_S0	Under purchase accounting, we recorded assets and liabilities at fair value as of the acquisition dates.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P89_S1	We identified and assigned value to trademarks and trade names, customer relationships, non-compete agreements, backlog, and patents.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P89_S2	We estimated the useful lives over which these intangible assets would be amortized.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P89_S3	Valuations of these assets were performed largely using discounted cash flow models and estimates of replacement cost.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P89_S4	These valuations support the conclusion that identifiable intangible assets had a value of $3,408,000.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P89_S5	The resulting goodwill was $9,487,000 .
1005229_15_ITEM7_P90_S0	Assigning value to intangible assets requires estimates used in projecting relevant future cash flows and estimates of replacement costs, in addition to estimating useful lives of such assets.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P91_S0	Allowances for doubtful accounts and credit memo reserves are also judgmentally determined based on formulas applied to historical bad debt write-offs and credit memos issued, assessing potentially uncollectible customer accounts and analyzing the accounts receivable aging.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P92_S0	Accounts receivable are charged against the allowance for doubtful accounts once all collection efforts have been exhausted.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P92_S1	At March 31, 2015 the allowance for doubtful accounts totaled $2,155,000.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P93_S0	Impairment of depreciable and amortizable long-lived assets .
1005229_15_ITEM7_P93_S1	Property, plant and equipment and certain intangibles are depreciated or amortized over their assigned lives.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P94_S0	We test long-lived assets for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of those assets may not be recoverable and exceed their fair market value.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P94_S1	The following summarizes the value of long-lived assets subject to impairment testing when events or circumstances indicate potential impairment (amounts in millions):
1005229_15_ITEM7_P95_S0	Impairment may exist if the carrying amount of the asset in question exceeds the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P95_S1	The impairment loss, if any, would be measured as the amount by which the carrying amount of a long-lived asset exceeds its fair market value as determined by appropriate valuation techniques.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P96_S0	On a quarterly basis, we review our marketable securities for declines in market value that may be considered other than temporary.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P96_S1	We generally consider market value declines to be other than temporary if there are declines for a period longer than six months and in excess of 20% of original cost.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P96_S2	We also consider the nature of the underlying investments and other market conditions or when other evidence indicates impairment.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P97_S0	Deferred Tax Asset Valuation Allowance .
1005229_15_ITEM7_P98_S0	In fiscal year 2013 income taxes as a percentage of income before income taxes was not reflective of U.S. statutory rates.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P98_S1	The Company had a valuation allowance of $53,325,000 at March 31, 2012 due to the uncertainty of whether U.S. federal and certain foreign net operating loss carryforwards ("NOLs") and deferred tax assets might ultimately be realized.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P98_S2	In fiscal year 2013, we utilized the remaining U.S. federal NOLs thereby, reducing the valuation allowance by $5,107,000.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P99_S0	As a result of our increased operating performance over the past several years, we reevaluated the certainty as to whether our remaining NOLs and other deferred tax assets may ultimately be realized.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P99_S1	Management concluded that it is more likely than not that almost all of the remaining deferred tax assets will be realized; therefore, $49,161,000 of the remaining U.S. valuation allowance was reversed as of March 31, 2013.

1005229_15_ITEM7_P104_S0	ASU 2014-12 requires that a performance target that affects vesting, and that could be achieved after the requisite service period, be treated as a performance condition.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P104_S1	As such, the performance target should not be reflected in estimating the grant date fair value of the award.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P104_S2	This update further clarifies that compensation cost should be recognized in the period in which it becomes probable that the performance target will be achieved and should represent the compensation cost attributable to the period(s) for which the requisite service has already been rendered.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P104_S3	This ASU is effective prospectively for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2015.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P104_S4	The Company does not anticipate that the adoption of this standard will have a material impact on its consolidated financial statements.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P105_S0	ASU 2014-11 changes the accounting for repurchase-to-maturity transactions and linked repurchase financings to secured borrowing accounting, which is consistent with the accounting for other repurchase agreements.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P105_S1	ASU 2014-11 also requires new disclosures about transfers that are accounted for as sales in transactions that are economically similar to repurchase agreements and increased transparency about the types of collateral pledged in repurchase agreements and similar transactions accounted for as secured borrowings.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P105_S2	This ASU is effective for the first interim or annual period beginning after December 15, 2014.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P105_S3	The Company does not expect the adoption of this standard to have a material impact on its consolidated financial statements.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P106_S0	ASU 2014-09 outlines a new, single comprehensive model for entities to use in accounting for revenue arising from contracts with customers and supersedes most current revenue recognition guidance, including industry-specific guidance.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P106_S1	This new revenue recognition model provides a five-step analysis in determining when and how revenue is recognized.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P106_S2	The new model will require revenue recognition to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration a company expects to receive in exchange for those goods or services.
1005229_15_ITEM7_P106_S3	This ASU is effective prospectively for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2016.

1005229_15_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market rates and prices, such as interest rates.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P0_S1	We are exposed to various market risks, including commodity prices for raw materials, foreign currency exchange rates and changes in interest rates.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P0_S2	We may enter into financial instrument transactions, which attempt to manage and reduce the impact of such changes.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P0_S3	We do not enter into derivatives or other financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Our primary commodity risk is related to changes in the price of steel.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P1_S1	We control this risk through negotiating purchase contracts on a consolidated basis and by attempting to build changes in raw material costs into the selling prices of or surcharges on our products.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P1_S2	We have not entered into financial instrument transactions related to raw material costs.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P2_S0	In fiscal 2015, 42% of our net sales were from manufacturing plants and sales offices in foreign jurisdictions.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P2_S1	We manufacture our products in the United States, China, Germany, United Kingdom, Hungary, Mexico and France and sell our products in approximately 50 countries.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Our results of operations could be affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency rates or weak economic conditions in foreign markets.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Our operating results are exposed to fluctuations between the U.S. dollar and the Canadian dollar, European currencies, the South African Rand, the Mexican peso, the Brazilian real, and the Chinese yuan.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P2_S4	For example, when the U.S. dollar weakens against the Euro, the value of our net sales and net income denominated in Euros increases when translated into U.S. dollars for inclusion in our consolidated results.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P3_S0	We are also exposed to foreign currency fluctuations in relation to purchases denominated in foreign currencies.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P3_S1	Our foreign currency risk is mitigated since the majority of our foreign operations net sales and the related expense transactions are denominated in the same currency so therefore a significant change in foreign exchange rates would likely have a very minor impact on net income.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P3_S2	For example, a 10% change in the value of the U.S. dollar in relation to our most significant foreign currency exposures would have had an impact of approximately $900,000 on our income from operations.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P3_S3	In addition, the majority of our export sale transactions are denominated in U.S. dollars.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The Company has a foreign currency forward agreement in place to offset changes in the value of an intercompany loan to a foreign subsidiary due to changes in foreign exchange rates.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P4_S1	The notional amount of this derivative is $590,000 and the contract matures on April 15, 2016.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P4_S2	This contract is marked to market each balance sheet date and is not designated as a hedge.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The Company has foreign currency forward agreements in place to hedge changes in the value of recorded foreign currency assets and liabilities due to changes in foreign exchange rates at the settlement date.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The notional amount of those derivatives is $672,000 and all contracts mature within twelve months of March 31, 2015 .
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P5_S2	These contracts are marked to market each balance sheet date and are not designated as hedges.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P6_S0	The Company has foreign currency forward agreements that are designated as cash flow hedges to hedge a portion of forecasted inventory purchases denominated in a foreign currency.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P6_S1	The notional amount of those derivatives is $8,624,000 and all contracts mature within twelve months of March 31, 2015 .
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P6_S2	From its March 31, 2015 balance of accumulated other comprehensive loss, the Company expects to reclassify approximately $54,000 out of accumulated other comprehensive loss during the next 12 months based on the underlying transaction of the sale of the goods purchased.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P7_S0	We control risk related to changes in interest rates by structuring our debt instruments with a combination of fixed and variable interest rates and by evaluating the need to enter into financial instrument transactions as appropriate.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P8_S0	On February 19, 2015, the Company entered into a Term Loan, which has a variable interest rate.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P8_S1	The Company's desired capital structure, is comprised of 50-70% of fixed rate long-term debt and 30-50% of variable rate long-term debt.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P8_S2	As such, the Company entered into an interest rate swap agreement that is designated as a cash flow hedge to hedge changes in interest expense due to changes in the interest rate of the senior secured term loan.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P8_S3	The amortizing interest rate swap matures on February 19, 2020 and has a notional amount of $86,250,000 as of March 31, 2015.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P8_S4	The effective portion of the change in fair value of the interest rate swap is reported in AOCL and will be reclassified to interest expense over the life of the underlying debt obligation.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P8_S5	The ineffective portion was not material and was recognized in the current period interest expense.
1005229_15_ITEM7A_P8_S6	From its March 31, 2015 balance of accumulated other comprehensive loss, the Company expects to reclassify approximately $1,026,000 out of accumulated other comprehensive loss during the next 12 months.

1005229_15_ITEM8_P13_S0	Goodwill is not amortized but is tested for impairment at least annually, or more frequently if indicators of impairment exist, in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 350-20-35-1.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P13_S1	Goodwill impairment is deemed to exist if the net book value of a reporting unit exceeds its estimated fair value.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P13_S2	The fair value of a reporting unit is determined using a discounted cash flow methodology.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P13_S3	The Company s reporting units are determined based upon whether discrete financial information is available and reviewed regularly, whether those units constitute a business, and the extent of economic similarities between those reporting units for purposes of aggregation.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P13_S4	The Company s reporting units identified under ASC Topic 350-20-35-33 are at the component level, or one level below the reporting segment level as defined under ASC Topic 280-10-50-10 Segment Reporting Disclosure.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P14_S0	The Company s one segment is subdivided into four reporting units.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P15_S0	When the Company evaluates the potential for goodwill impairment, it assesses a range of qualitative factors including, but not limited to, macroeconomic conditions, industry conditions, the competitive environment, changes in the market for its products and services, regulatory and political developments, entity specific factors such as strategy and changes in key personnel and overall financial performance.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P15_S1	If, after completing this assessment, it is determined that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value, the Company proceeds to a two-step impairment test.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P16_S0	To perform the two-step impairment test, the Company uses the discounted cash flow method to estimate the fair value of the reporting units.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P16_S1	The discounted cash flow method incorporates various assumptions, the most significant being projected revenue growth rates, operating profit margins and cash flows, the terminal growth rate and the discount rate.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P17_S0	The Company projects revenue growth rates, operating margins and cash flows based on each reporting unit s current business, expected developments and operational strategies over a five-year period.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P17_S1	In estimating the terminal growth rate, the Company considers its historical and projected results, as well as the economic environment in which its reporting units operate.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P17_S2	The discount rates utilized for each reporting unit reflect the Company s assumptions of marketplace participants cost of capital and risk assumptions, both specific to the reporting unit and overall in the economy.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P18_S0	The Company performed its qualitative assessment as of February 28, 2015 and determined that it was not more likely than not that the fair value of each of its reporting units other than Rest of Products was less than that its applicable carrying value.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P18_S1	Accordingly, the Company did not perform the two-step goodwill impairment test for any of its reporting units other than the Rest of Products reporting unit.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P19_S0	The Company performed step one of the two-step impairment test for the Rest of Products reporting unit.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P19_S1	Based on the results of the impairment test, the Company determined that the Rest of Products reporting unit's fair value was not less than its applicable carrying value.

1005229_15_ITEM8_P20_S0	The Company assesses impairment of its long-lived assets in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 360 Property, Plant, and Equipment.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P20_S1	This statement requires long-lived assets, such as property and equipment and purchased intangibles subject to amortization to be reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset group may not be recoverable.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P21_S0	Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of an asset group to estimated undiscounted future cash flows expected to be generated by the asset group.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P21_S1	If the carrying amount of an asset group exceeds its estimated future cash flows, an impairment charge is recognized equal to the amount by which the carrying amount of the asset group exceeds the fair value of the asset group.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P22_S0	In assessing long-lived assets for an impairment loss, assets are grouped with other assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other assets and liabilities.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P22_S1	Asset grouping requires a significant amount of judgment.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P22_S2	Accordingly, facts and circumstances will influence how asset groups are determined for impairment testing.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P23_S0	In assessing long-lived assets for impairment, management considered the Company s product line portfolio, customers and related commercial agreements, labor agreements and other factors in grouping assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are independent.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P23_S1	The Company considers projected future undiscounted cash flows, trends and other factors in its assessment of whether impairment conditions exist.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P23_S2	While the Company believes that its estimates of future cash flows are reasonable, different assumptions regarding such factors as future production volumes, customer pricing, economics and productivity and cost initiatives, could significantly affect its estimates.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P24_S0	In determining fair value of long-lived assets, management uses management estimates, discounted cash flow calculations, and appraisals where necessary.

1005229_15_ITEM8_P67_S0	ASC Topic 820 Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures establishes the standards for reporting financial assets and liabilities and nonfinancial assets and liabilities that are recognized or disclosed at fair value on a recurring basis (at least annually).
1005229_15_ITEM8_P67_S1	Under these standards, fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability (i.e. the "exit price") in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P68_S0	ASC Topic 820-10-35-37 establishes a hierarchy for inputs used in measuring fair value that maximizes the use of observable inputs and minimizes the use of unobservable inputs by requiring that the most observable inputs be used when available.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P69_S0	Observable inputs are inputs that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability developed based on market data obtained from sources independent of the Company.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P69_S1	Unobservable inputs are inputs that reflect the Company's assumptions about the valuation techniques that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability developed based on the best information available in the circumstances.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P69_S2	The hierarchy is separated into three levels based on the reliability of inputs as follows:
1005229_15_ITEM8_P70_S0	Level 1 - Valuations based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the Company has the ability to access.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P70_S1	Since valuations are based on quoted prices that are readily and regularly available in an active market, valuation of these products does not entail a significant degree of judgment.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P71_S0	Level 2 - Valuations based on quoted prices in markets that are not active or for which all significant inputs are observable, either directly or indirectly, involving some degree of judgment.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P72_S0	Level 3 - Valuations based on inputs that are unobservable and significant to the overall fair value measurement.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P72_S1	The degree of judgment exercised in determining fair value is greatest for instruments categorized in Level 3.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P73_S0	The availability of observable inputs can vary and is affected by a wide variety of factors, including the type of asset/liability, whether the asset/liability is established in the marketplace, and other characteristics particular to the transaction.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P74_S0	To the extent that valuation is based on models or inputs that are less observable or unobservable in the market, the determination of fair value requires more judgment.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P75_S0	In certain cases, the inputs used to measure fair value may fall into different levels of the fair value hierarchy.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P75_S1	In such cases, for disclosure purposes the level in the fair value hierarchy within which the fair value measurement in its entirety falls is determined based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P76_S0	Fair value is a market-based measure considered from the perspective of a market participant rather than an entity-specific measure.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P76_S1	Therefore, even when market assumptions are not readily available, assumptions are required to reflect those that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability at the measurement date.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P77_S0	In fiscal 2014, the fair market value of unearned ESOP shares was determined based on the quoted market value of the Company s stock and consequently, the fair value was based on Level 1 inputs.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P78_S0	The Company primarily uses readily observable market data in conjunction with internally developed discounted cash flow valuation models when valuing its derivative portfolio and, consequently, the fair value of the Company s derivatives is based on Level 2 inputs.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P78_S1	The carrying value of the Company s Term Loan and senior debt approximate fair value based on current market interest rates for debt instruments of similar credit standing and, consequently, their fair values are based on Level 2 inputs.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P78_S2	In fiscal 2014, the Company used quoted prices in an inactive market when valuing its Subordinated Debt, represented by the 7 7/8% Notes due 2019, registered under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (unregistered 7 7/8% Notes) and, consequently, the fair value was based on Level 2 inputs.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P79_S0	The following table provides information regarding financial assets and liabilities measured or disclosed at fair value on a recurring basis:
1005229_15_ITEM8_P80_S0	The Company did not have any nonfinancial assets and liabilities that are recognized at fair value on a recurring basis.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P81_S0	At March 31, 2015, the term loan and senior debt have been recorded at carrying value which approximates fair value.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P82_S0	Interest and dividend income on marketable securities are recorded in investment (income) loss.

1005229_15_ITEM8_P83_S0	Interest and dividend income on marketable securities are measured based upon amounts earned on their respective declaration dates.

1005229_15_ITEM8_P84_S1	The long term debt of STB was measured at fair value and subsequently repaid prior to March 31, 2015.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P85_S0	The estimated fair values allocated to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed relied upon fair value measurements based primarily on Level 3 inputs.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P85_S1	The valuation techniques used to allocate fair values to working capital items; property, plant, and equipment; and identifiable intangible assets included the cost approach, market approach, and other income approaches.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P85_S2	The valuation techniques relied on a number of inputs which included the cost and condition of property, plant, and equipment and forecasted net sales and income.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P85_S3	For STB significant valuation inputs included an attrition rate of 10.0% for customer relationships, a royalty rate of 1.0% for trademarks and domain names.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P85_S4	For Unified, significant valuation inputs included an attrition rate of 8.0% for customer relationships, an engineering cost per hour of $57.20 for the engineered drawings, and a royalty rate of 1.5% for trademark and trade names.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P85_S5	For Hebetechnik, significant valuation inputs included a weighted average cost of capital of 12.3% .
1005229_15_ITEM8_P86_S0	Additional assets and liabilities that were measured on a non-recurring basis during fiscal 2015 and 2014 include the net assets of the Company s Rest of Products and Duff-Norton reporting unit, respectively.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P86_S1	These measurements have been used to test goodwill for impairment on an annual basis under the provisions of ASC Topic 350-20-35-1 Intangibles, Goodwill and Other Goodwill Subsequent Measurement.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P87_S0	During fiscal 2015, Step 1 of the goodwill impairment test consisted of determining a fair value of the Company s Rest of Products reporting unit.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P87_S1	The fair value for the Company s Rest of Products reporting unit cannot be determined using readily available quoted Level 1 inputs or Level 2 inputs that are observable in active markets.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P87_S2	Therefore, the Company used a blended discounted cash flow and market-based valuation model to estimate the fair value of its Rest of Products reporting unit, using Level 3 inputs.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P88_S0	To estimate the fair value of the Rest of Products reporting unit, the Company used significant estimates and judgmental factors.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P88_S1	The key estimates and factors used in the discounted cash flow valuation include revenue growth rates and profit margins based on internal forecasts, terminal value, and the weighted-average cost of capital used to discount future cash flows.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P88_S2	The compound annual growth rate for revenue during the first six years of the projections was approximately 3.8% .
1005229_15_ITEM8_P88_S3	The terminal value was calculated assuming a projected growth rate of 3.0% after six years.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P88_S4	The estimated weighted-average cost of capital for the reporting units was determined to be 10.1% based upon an analysis of similar companies and their debt to equity mix, their related volatility and the size of their market capitalization.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P89_S0	Similarly during fiscal 2014, the Company performed Step 1 of the goodwill impairment test for it s Duff-Norton reporting unit.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P89_S1	The Company used a blended discounted cash flow and market-based valuation model to estimate the fair value of its Duff-Norton reporting unit, using Level 3 inputs.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P89_S2	The key estimates and factors used in the discounted cash flow valuation include revenue growth rates and profit margins based on internal forecasts, terminal value, and the weighted-average cost of capital used to discount future cash flows.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P89_S3	The compound annual growth rate for revenue during the first five years of the projections was approximately 5% .
1005229_15_ITEM8_P89_S4	The terminal value was calculated assuming a projected growth rate of 4.5% after five years.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P89_S5	The estimated weighted-average cost of capital for the reporting units was determined to be 12.8% based upon an analysis of similar companies and their debt to equity mix, their related volatility and the size of their market capitalization.

1005229_15_ITEM8_P97_S1	The Company generally considers market value declines to be other-than-temporary if they are declines for a period longer than six months and in excess of 20% of original cost, or when other evidence indicates impairment.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P97_S2	We also consider the nature of the underlying investments, our intent and ability to hold the investments until their market values recover, and other market conditions in making this assessment.
1005229_15_ITEM8_P97_S3	Based on this assessment, no other-than-temporary impairment charge has been recorded during fiscal 2015, 2014, or 2013.
