1005229_16_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Columbus McKinnon is subject to a number of risk factors that could negatively affect our results from business operations or cause actual results to differ materially from those projected or indicated in any forward looking statement.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Such factors include, but are not limited to, the following:
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Adverse changes in global economic conditions may negatively affect our industry, business and results of operations.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P2_S0	During the last five years, financial markets in the United States, Europe and Asia have experienced substantial disruption including, among other things, extreme volatility in security prices, severely diminished liquidity and credit availability, rating downgrades of certain investments and declining valuations of others.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Governments have taken unprecedented actions intended to address these market conditions and the extent to which such government actions may prove effective remains unclear.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P2_S2	The future economic environment may worsen.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Our industry is affected by changes in economic conditions outside our control, which can result in a general decrease in product demand from our customers.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Such economic developments may affect our business in a number of ways.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Reduced demand may drive us and our competitors to offer products at promotional prices, which would have a negative impact on our profitability.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P3_S3	In addition, the tightening of credit in financial markets may adversely affect the ability of our customers and suppliers to obtain financing for significant purchases and operations and could result in a decrease in, or cancellation of, orders for our products.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P3_S4	If demand for our products slows down or decreases, we will not be able to maintain our revenues and we may run the risk of failing to satisfy the financial and other restrictive covenants to which we are subject under our existing indebtedness.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Reduced revenues as a result of decreased demand may also reduce our planned growth and otherwise hinder our ability to improve our performance in connection with our long term strategy.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Our business is cyclical and is affected by industrial economic conditions.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Many of the end-users of our products are in highly cyclical industries, such as manufacturing, power generation and distribution, commercial construction, oil and gas exploration and refining, transportation, agriculture, logging, and mining that are sensitive to changes in general economic conditions.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Their demand for our products, and thus our results of operations, is directly related to the level of production in their facilities, which changes as a result of changes in general economic conditions and other factors beyond our control.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P5_S2	If there is deterioration in the general economy or in the industries we serve, our business, results of operations and financial condition could be materially adversely affected.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P5_S3	In addition, the cyclical nature of our business could at times also adversely affect our liquidity and ability to borrow under our revolving credit facility.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our business is highly competitive and subject to consolidation of competitors.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Increased competition could reduce our sales, earnings, and profitability.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The principal markets that we serve within the material handling industry are fragmented and highly competitive.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Competition is based primarily on customer service and support as well as product availability, performance, functionality, brand reputation, reliability and price.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Our competition in the markets in which we participate comes from companies of various sizes, some of which have greater financial and other resources than we do.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P7_S3	Increased competition could force us to lower our prices or to offer additional services at a higher cost to us, which could reduce our gross margins and net income.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The greater financial resources or the lower amount of debt of certain of our competitors may enable them to commit larger amounts of capital in response to changing market conditions.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Certain competitors may also have the ability to develop product or service innovations that could put us at a disadvantage.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P8_S2	In addition, through consolidation, some of our competitors have achieved substantially more market penetration in certain of the markets in which we operate.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P8_S3	If we are unable to compete successfully against other manufacturers of material handling equipment, we could lose customers and our revenues may decline.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P8_S4	There can also be no assurance that customers will continue to regard our products favorably, that we will be able to develop new products that appeal to customers, that we will be able to improve or maintain our profit margins on sales to our customers or that we will be able to continue to compete successfully in our core markets.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our operations outside the U.S. pose certain risks that may adversely impact sales and earnings.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We have operations and assets located outside of the United States, primarily in China, Mexico, Germany, the United Kingdom, France, and Hungary.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P10_S1	In addition, we import a portion of our hoist product line from Asia, and sell our products to distributors located in approximately 50 countries.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P10_S2	In our fiscal year ended March 31, 2016, approximately 37% of our net sales were derived from non-U.S. markets.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P10_S3	These non-U.S. operations are subject to a number of special risks, in addition to the risks of our U.S. business, differing protections of intellectual property, trade barriers, labor unrest, exchange controls, regional economic uncertainty, differing (and possibly more stringent) labor regulation, risk of governmental expropriation, U.S. and foreign customs and tariffs, current and changing regulatory environments, difficulty in obtaining distribution support, difficulty in staffing and managing widespread operations, differences in the availability and terms of financing, political instability and risks of increases in taxes.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P10_S4	Also, in some foreign jurisdictions we may be subject to laws limiting the right and ability of entities organized or operating therein to pay dividends or remit earnings to affiliated companies unless specified conditions are met.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P10_S5	These factors may adversely affect our future profits.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Part of our strategy is to expand our worldwide market share and reduce costs by strengthening our international distribution capabilities and sourcing components in lower cost countries, in particular in China, Mexico, and Hungary.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Implementation of this strategy may increase the impact of the risks described above, and we cannot assure you that such risks will not have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Our strategy depends on successful integration of acquisitions.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Acquisitions are a key part of our growth strategy.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Our historical growth has depended, and our future growth is likely to depend on our ability to successfully implement our acquisition strategy, and the successful integration of acquired businesses into our existing business.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P13_S2	We intend to continue to seek additional acquisition opportunities in accordance with our acquisition strategy, both to expand into new markets and to enhance our position in existing markets throughout the world.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P13_S3	If we are unable to successfully integrate acquired businesses into our existing business or expand into new markets, our sales and earnings growth could be reduced.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Our products involve risks of personal injury and property damage, which exposes us to potential liability.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Our business exposes us to possible claims for personal injury or death and property damage resulting from the products that we sell.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P15_S1	We maintain insurance through a combination of self-insurance retentions and excess insurance coverage.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P15_S2	We monitor claims and potential claims of which we become aware and establish accrued liability reserves for the self-insurance amounts based on our liability estimates for such claims.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P15_S3	We cannot give any assurance that existing or future claims will not exceed our estimates for self-insurance or the amount of our excess insurance coverage.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P15_S4	In addition, we cannot give any assurance that insurance will continue to be available to us on economically reasonable terms or that our insurers would not require us to increase our self-insurance amounts.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P15_S5	Claims brought against us that are not covered by insurance or that are in excess of insurance coverage could have a material adverse effect on our results, financial condition, or liquidity.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P16_S0	In addition, like many industrial manufacturers, we are also involved in asbestos-related litigation.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P16_S1	In continually evaluating costs relating to our estimated asbestos-related liability, we review, among other things, the incidence of past and recent claims, the historical case dismissal rate, the mix of the claimed illnesses and occupations of the plaintiffs, our recent and historical resolution of the cases, the number of cases pending against us, the status and results of broad-based settlement discussions, and the number of years such activity might continue.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P16_S2	Based on this review, we estimate our share of liability to defend and resolve probable asbestos related personal injury claims.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P16_S3	This estimate is highly uncertain due to the limitations of the available data and the difficulty of forecasting with any certainty the numerous variables that can affect the range of the liability.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P16_S4	We continue to study the variables in light of additional information in order to identify trends that may become evident and to assess their impact on the range of liability that is probable and estimable.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P17_S0	We believe that the potential additional costs for claims will not have a material effect on the financial condition of the Company or its liquidity, although the effect of any future liabilities recorded could be material to earnings in a future period.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P17_S1	See Note 15 to our March 31, 2016 consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this form 10K.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P18_S0	As indicated above, our self-insurance coverage is effected through our captive insurance subsidiary.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P18_S1	The reserves of our captive insurance subsidiary are subject to periodic adjustments based upon actuarial evaluations, which adjustments impact our overall results of operations.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P18_S2	These periodic adjustments can be favorable or unfavorable.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We are subject to currency fluctuations from our sales outside the U.S.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Our products are sold in many countries around the world.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Thus, a portion of our revenues (approximately $223,314,000 in our fiscal year ended March 31, 2016) are generated in foreign currencies, including principally the Euro, the British Pound, the Canadian Dollar, the South African Rand, and the Brazilian Real, and while much of the costs incurred to generate those revenues are incurred in the same currency, a portion is incurred in other currencies.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Since our financial statements are denominated in U.S. dollars, changes in currency exchange rates between the U.S. dollar and other currencies have had, and will continue to have, a currency translation impact on our earnings.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Currency fluctuations may impact our financial performance in the future.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Our future operating results may be affected by fluctuations in steel or other material prices.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P22_S1	We may not be able to pass on increases in raw material costs to our customers.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P23_S0	The principal raw material used in our chain, forging and crane building operations is steel.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P23_S1	The steel industry as a whole is highly cyclical, and at times pricing and availability can be volatile due to a number of factors beyond our control, including general economic conditions, labor costs, competition, import duties, tariffs and currency exchange rates.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P23_S2	This volatility can significantly affect our raw material costs.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P23_S3	In an environment of increasing raw material prices, competitive conditions will determine how much of the steel price increases we can pass on to our customers.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P23_S4	During historical rising cost periods, we were generally successful in adding and maintaining a surcharge to the prices of our high steel content products or incorporating them into price increases, with a goal of margin neutrality.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P23_S5	In the future, to the extent we are unable to pass on any steel price increases to our customers, our profitability could be adversely affected.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P24_S0	We rely in large part on independent distributors for sales of our products.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P25_S0	For the most part, we depend on independent distributors to sell our products and provide service and aftermarket support to our end-user customers.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Distributors play a significant role in determining which of our products are stocked at their locations, and hence are most readily accessible to aftermarket buyers, and the price at which these products are sold.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Almost all of the distributors with whom we transact business offer competitive products and services to our end-user customers.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P25_S3	For the most part, we do not have written agreements with our distributors.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P25_S4	The loss of a substantial number of these distributors or an increase in the distributors' sales of our competitors' products to our ultimate customers could materially reduce our sales and profits.

1005229_16_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Our operations and facilities are subject to various federal, state, local and foreign requirements relating to the protection of the environment, including those governing the discharges of pollutants in the air and water, the generation, management and disposal of hazardous substances and wastes and the cleanup of contaminated sites.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P27_S1	We have made, and will continue to make, expenditures to comply with such requirements.

1005229_16_ITEM1A_P36_S1	If these systems are damaged, cease to function properly, or are subject to cyber-security attacks, such as those involving unauthorized access, malicious software and/or other intrusions, we could experience production downtimes, operational delays, other detrimental impacts on our operations or ability to provide products and services to our customers, the compromising of confidential or otherwise protected information, destruction or corruption of data, security breaches, other manipulation or improper use of our systems or networks, financial losses from remedial actions, loss of business or potential liability, and/or damage to our reputation.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P36_S2	While we attempt to mitigate these risks by employing a number of measures, including employee training, technical security controls, and maintenance of backup and protective systems, our systems, networks, products and services remain potentially vulnerable to known or unknown threats, any of which could have a material adverse affect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P37_S0	We depend on our senior management team and the loss of any member could adversely affect our operations.

1005229_16_ITEM1A_P41_S0	We have not completed an assessment of Magnetek's internal controls over financial reporting and therefore, significant deficiencies or material weaknesses may exist.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Under current SEC guidelines, the period in which management may omit an assessment of an acquired business's internal control over financial reporting from its assessment of the registrant's internal control may not extend beyond one year from the date of acquisition, nor may such assessment be omitted from more than one annual management report on internal control over financial reporting.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Pursuant to this guidance, we have excluded Magnetek, which was acquired on September 2, 2015, from the scope of management s assessment of the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of March 31, 2016.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P43_S1	However, we will be required to include Magnetek in the scope of our assessment beginning in fiscal 2017.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P43_S2	In connection with our fiscal 2017 assessment, significant deficiencies or material weaknesses in Magnetek s internal control over financial reporting may be detected.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P43_S3	To the extent that such deficiencies are identified, we may incur costs associated with our efforts to address these deficiencies that could negatively affect our financial condition and operating results.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P43_S4	Furthermore, if we are unable to correct such deficiencies in a timely manner, our ability to record, process, summarize and report financial data may be adversely affected, which may result in a material misstatement in our financial statements.
1005229_16_ITEM1A_P43_S5	Such failure could materially and adversely impact our business and subject us to potential investigations, liability, and penalties.

1005229_16_ITEM2_P1_S0	In addition, we have a total of 47 sales offices, distribution centers and warehouses.

1005229_16_ITEM3_P0_S0	From time to time, we are named a defendant in legal actions arising out of the normal course of business.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P0_S1	We are not a party to any pending legal proceeding other than ordinary, routine litigation incidental to our business.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P0_S2	We do not believe that any of our pending litigation will have a material impact on our business.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P0_S3	We maintain comprehensive general product liability insurance against risks arising out of the use of our products sold to customers through our wholly-owned New York State captive insurance subsidiary of which we are the sole policy holder.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P0_S4	The per occurrence limits on the self-insurance for general and product liability coverage were $2,000,000 from inception through fiscal 2003 and $3,000,000 for fiscal 2004 and thereafter.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P0_S5	In addition to the per occurrence limits, our coverage is also subject to an annual aggregate limit, applicable to losses only.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P0_S6	These limits range from $2,000,000 to $6,000,000 for each policy year from inception through fiscal 2016.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P0_S7	We obtain additional insurance coverage from independent insurers to cover potential losses in excess of these limits.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P1_S0	Like many industrial manufacturers, we are also involved in asbestos-related litigation.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P1_S1	In continually evaluating costs relating to our estimated asbestos-related liability, we review, among other things, the incidence of past and recent claims, the historical case dismissal rate, the mix of the claimed illnesses and occupations of the plaintiffs, our recent and historical resolution of the cases, the number of cases pending against us, the status and results of broad-based settlement discussions, and the number of years such activity might continue.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P1_S2	Because this liability is likely to extend over many years, management believes that the potential additional costs for claims will not have a material effect on the financial condition of the Company or its liquidity, although the effect of any future liabilities recorded could be material to earnings in a future period.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P2_S0	The Company believes that a share of its previously incurred asbestos-related expenses and future asbestos-related expenses are covered by pre-existing insurance policies.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P2_S1	The Company has engaged in a legal action against the insurance carriers for those policies to recover these expenses and future costs incurred.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P2_S2	When the Company resolves this legal action, it is expected that a gain will be recorded for previously expensed cost that is recovered.
1005229_16_ITEM3_P3_S0	See Note 15 to our March 31, 2016 consolidated financial statements for more information on our asbestos claims.

1005229_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	This section should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this annual report.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P0_S1	Comments on the results of operations and financial condition below refer to our continuing operations, except in the section entitled Discontinued Operations.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	We are a leading worldwide designer, manufacturer and marketer of material handling products, systems and services which efficiently and safely move, lift, position and secure materials and people.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P1_S1	In September, we significantly expanded our product offering with the acquisition of Magnetek.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P1_S2	Key products include hoists, actuators, cranes, rigging tools, and digital power control systems.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company is focused on serving commercial and industrial applications that require the safety and quality provided by the Company s superior design and engineering know-how.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	Founded in 1875, we have grown to our current size and leadership position through organic growth and acquisitions.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P3_S1	We developed our leading market position over our 141 -year history by emphasizing technological innovation, manufacturing excellence and superior after-sale service.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P3_S2	In addition, acquisitions significantly broadened our product lines and services and expanded our geographic reach, end-user markets and customer base.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P3_S3	Ongoing initiatives include growing revenue by increasing our penetration of the Asian, Latin American and European marketplaces, pursuing new products and targeted vertical markets, and by improving our productivity.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P3_S4	In accordance with our strategy, we have been investing in our sales and marketing activities, new product development and Lean efforts across the Company.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P3_S5	Shareholder value will be enhanced through continued emphasis on market expansion, customer satisfaction, new product development, manufacturing efficiency, cost containment, and efficient capital investment.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	Our revenue base is geographically diverse with approximately 37% derived from customers outside the U.S. for the year ended March 31, 2016.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	We believe this will help balance the impact of changes that will occur in local economies, as well as, benefit the Company from growth in emerging markets.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	As in the past, we monitor both U.S. and Eurozone Industrial Capacity Utilization statistics as indicators of anticipated demand for our products.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P5_S1	Since their June 2009 trough, these statistics have improved and have remained stable over the past year.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P5_S2	In addition, we continue to monitor the potential impact of other global and U.S. trends including industrial production, energy costs, steel price fluctuations, interest rates, foreign currency exchange rates and activity of end-user markets around the globe.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	From a strategic perspective, we are investing in global markets and new products as we focus on our greatest opportunities for growth.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P6_S1	We maintain a strong North American market share with significant leading market positions in hoists, lifting and sling chain, forged attachments, actuators, and digital power and motion control systems for the material handling industry.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P6_S2	We seek to maintain and enhance our market share by focusing our sales and marketing activities toward select North American and global market sectors including energy, automotive, heavy OEM, entertainment, and construction and infrastructure.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	Regardless of the economic climate and point in the economic cycle, we constantly explore ways to increase our operating margins as well as further improve our productivity and competitiveness.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P7_S1	We have specific initiatives related to improved customer satisfaction, reduced defects, shortened lead times, improved inventory turns and on-time deliveries, reduced warranty costs, and improved working capital utilization.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P7_S2	The initiatives are being driven by the continued implementation of our Lean efforts which are fundamentally changing our manufacturing and business processes to be more responsive to customer demand and improving on-time delivery and productivity.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P7_S3	In addition to Lean, we are working to achieve these strategic initiatives through product simplification, the creation of centers of excellence, and improved supply chain management.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P7_S4	We are also aggressively pursuing cost reduction opportunities to enhance future margins.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	We continuously monitor market prices of steel.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P8_S1	We purchase approximately $30,000,000 to $40,000,000 of steel annually in a variety of forms including rod, wire, bar, structural and others.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	Generally, as we experience fluctuations in our costs, we reflect them as price increases or surcharges to our customers with the goal of being margin neutral.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	We are also looking for opportunities for growth via strategic acquisitions or joint ventures.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P10_S1	The focus of our acquisition strategy centers on product line expansion in alignment with our existing core product offering and opportunities for non-U.S. market penetration.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	We operate in a highly competitive and global business environment.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P11_S1	We face a variety of opportunities in those markets and geographies, including trends toward increased utilization of the global labor force and the expansion of market opportunities in Asia and other emerging markets.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P11_S2	While we continue to execute our long-term growth strategy, we are supported by our solid capital structure, including our cash position and flexible debt structure.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	Fiscal 2016 sales were $597,103,000 , an increase of 3.0% , or $17,460,000 compared with fiscal 2015 sales of $579,643,000 .
1005229_16_ITEM7_P12_S1	Sales for the year were positively impacted by $74,267,000 due to acquisitions and $5,605,000 by price increases.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P12_S2	Sales for the year were negatively impacted $33,082,000 due to a decrease in sales volume.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P12_S3	The decline in sales volume was due to industrial recessions caused by weakness in oil gas, mining, heavy OEM, and commercial construction markets affecting our North American Hoist and Rigging and Latin American operations.

1005229_16_ITEM7_P47_S0	The terms of the New Credit Agreement include the following:
1005229_16_ITEM7_P48_S0	An aggregate $125,000,000 secured term loan facility which requires quarterly principal amortization of 2.5% with the remaining principal due at maturity date.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P49_S0	An aggregate $150,000,000 secured revolving credit facility which includes sublimits for the issuance of standby letters of credit, swingline loans and multi-currency borrowings in certain specified foreign currencies.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P50_S0	Fees and Interest Rates: Commitment fees and interest rates are determined on the basis of either a Eurocurrency rate or a Base rate plus an applicable margin based upon the Company's Total Leverage Ratio (as defined in the New Credit Agreement).
1005229_16_ITEM7_P51_S0	Prepayments: Provisions permitting a Borrower to voluntarily prepay either the Term Loan or New Revolving Credit Facility in whole or in part at any time, and provisions requiring certain mandatory prepayments of the Term Loan or New Revolving Credit Facility on the occurrence of certain events which will permanently reduce the commitments under the New Credit Agreement, each without premium or penalty.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P52_S0	A Borrower may irrevocably cancel, in whole or in part, the unutilized portion of the commitments under the New Credit Agreement in excess of any outstanding loans, the stated amount of all outstanding letters of credit and all unreimbursed amounts drawn under any letters of credit.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P53_S0	Covenants: Provisions containing covenants required of the Company and its subsidiaries including various affirmative and negative financial and operational covenants.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P53_S1	Key financial covenants include a minimum fixed charge coverage ratio of 1.25x; a maximum total leverage ratio, net of cash, of 3.50x (which may be temporarily increased following a material acquisition, which may be elected two times over the course of the New Credit Agreement, (i) if financed by secured debt the total leverage rate as at the end of the fiscal quarter in which such material acquisition occurs and the three fiscal quarters immediately thereafter, shall not be greater than 4.00:1.00 and as at the end of any fiscal quarter thereafter, the total leverage ratio shall not be greater than 3.50:1.00, and (ii) if financed with unsecured or subordinated indebtedness, the total leverage ratio at the end of the fiscal quarter in which such material acquisition occurs and at the end of any fiscal quarter thereafter, shall not be greater than 4.50:1.00, and permit the secured leverage ratio, to be greater than 3.25:1.00), and maximum capital expenditures of $30 million per fiscal year ($40 million following a material acquisition) with the ability to transfer any unused portion of expenditure to the immediately following fiscal year.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P53_S2	Our actual fixed charges coverage ratio and total leverage ratio, as calculated per the terms of our New Revolving Credit Facility, were 3.20x and 2.90x, respectively, at March 31, 2016.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P54_S0	The New Revolving Credit Facility is secured by all U.S. inventory, receivables, equipment, real property, subsidiary stock (limited to 65% of non-U.S. subsidiaries) and intellectual property.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P54_S1	The New Credit Agreement allows, but limits our ability to pay dividends.

1005229_16_ITEM7_P64_S0	Our costs are affected by inflation in the U.S. economy and, to a lesser extent, in non-U.S. economies including those of Europe, Canada, Mexico, South America and Asia-Pacific.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P64_S1	We do not believe that general inflation has had a material effect on our results of operations over the periods presented primarily due to overall low inflation levels over such periods and our ability to generally pass on rising costs through annual price increases and surcharges.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P64_S2	However, increases in U.S. employee benefits costs such as health insurance and workers compensation insurance have exceeded general inflation levels.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P64_S3	In the future, we may be further affected by inflation that we may not be able to pass on as price increases.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P64_S4	With changes in worldwide demand for steel and fluctuating scrap steel prices over the past several years, we experienced fluctuations in our costs that we have reflected as price increases and surcharges to our customers.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P64_S5	We believe we have been successful in instituting surcharges and price increases to pass on these material cost increases.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P64_S6	We will continue to monitor our costs and reevaluate our pricing policies.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P65_S0	Our quarterly results may be materially affected by the timing of large customer orders, periods of high vacation and holiday concentrations, restructuring charges and other costs attributable to plan closures as well as divestitures and acquisitions.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P65_S1	Therefore, our operating results for any particular fiscal quarter are not necessarily indicative of results for any subsequent fiscal quarter or for the full fiscal year.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P66_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in our consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P66_S1	We continually evaluate the estimates and their underlying assumptions, which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying value of our assets and liabilities.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P66_S2	Actual results inevitably will differ from those estimates.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P66_S3	If interpreted differently under different conditions or circumstances, changes in our estimates could result in material changes to our reported results.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P67_S0	We have identified below the accounting policies involving estimates that are critical to our financial statements.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P67_S1	Other accounting policies are more fully described in Note 2 of our consolidated financial statements.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P68_S0	Sales are recorded when title passes to the customer which is generally at the time of shipment to the customer.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P68_S1	The Company performs ongoing credit evaluations of its customers financial condition, but generally does not require collateral to support customer receivables.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P68_S2	The credit risk is controlled through credit approvals, limits and monitoring procedures.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P68_S3	Accounts receivable are reported at net realizable value and do not accrue interest.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P68_S4	Sales tax is excluded from revenue.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P69_S0	Pension and Other Postretirement Benefits .
1005229_16_ITEM7_P70_S0	The determination of the obligations and expense for pension and postretirement benefits is dependent on our selection of certain assumptions that are used by actuaries in calculating such amounts.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P70_S1	Those assumptions are disclosed in Note 12 to our fiscal 2016 consolidated financial statements and include the discount rates, expected long-term rate of return on plan assets and rates of future increases in compensation and healthcare costs.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P70_S2	Changes in these assumptions can result in the calculation of different plan expense and liability amounts.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P70_S3	Further, actual experience can differ from the assumptions and these differences are typically accounted for as actuarial gains or losses that are amortized over future periods.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P71_S0	The weighted average pension discount rate assumptions of 4.03% , 3.83%, and 4.60%, as of March 31, 2016 , 2015 , and 2014 , respectively, are based on long-term AA rated corporate and municipal bond rates.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P71_S1	At September 2, 2015, the Company used a discount rate assumption of 4.30% in valuing the pension plan obligation acquired in the Magnetek acquisition.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P71_S2	The change in the discount rate at March 31, 2016 did not result in a significant change in the total projected benefit obligation.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P72_S0	The Company adopted updated mortality tables in calculating its U.S. pension obligation.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P72_S1	The change in mortality tables resulted in a $5,700,000 increase in the projected benefit obligation.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P73_S0	The rate of return on plan assets assumptions of 7.22% for the year ended March 31, 2016, and 7.50% for the years ended March 31, 2015 and 2014 is based on the targeted plan asset allocation (approximately 65% equities and 35% fixed income) and their long-term historical returns.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P73_S1	Our under-funded status for all pension plans as of March 31, 2016 and 2015 was $103,279,000 and $57,339,000, or 24.5% and 21.9% of the projected benefit obligation, respectively.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P73_S2	Our pension contributions during fiscal 2016 and 2015 were approximately $5,936,000 and $11,013,000, respectively.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P73_S3	The under-funded status may result in future pension expense increases.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P73_S4	Pension benefit for the March 31, 2017 fiscal year is expected to approximate $983,000, comparable to the fiscal 2016 benefit of $1,208,000 .
1005229_16_ITEM7_P73_S5	Pension funding contributions for the March 31, 2017 fiscal year are expected to approximate $5,961,000 .
1005229_16_ITEM7_P73_S6	The weighted-average compensation increase assumption of 0.44% as of March 31, 2016 and 2.30% and 2.00% as of March 31, 2015 and 2014 , respectively is based on expected wage trends and historical patterns.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P74_S0	The healthcare costs inflation assumptions of 6.8% for fiscal 2016 and 7.0% for fiscal 2015 and 2014 , respectively, are based on anticipated trends.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P74_S1	While the healthcare inflation rate assumptions have been decreasing, healthcare costs continue to outpace inflation in the U.S.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P75_S0	Our accrued general and product liability reserves as described in Note 15 to consolidated financial statements involve actuarial techniques including the methods selected to estimate ultimate claims, and assumptions including emergence patterns, payment patterns, initial expected losses and increased limit factors.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P75_S1	These actuarial estimates are subject to a high degree of uncertainty due to a variety of factors, including extended lag time in the reporting and resolution of claims, trends or changes in claim settlement patterns, insurance industry practices, and legal interpretations.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P75_S2	Changes to these estimates could result in material changes to the amount of expense and liabilities recorded in our financial statements.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P75_S3	Further, actual costs could differ significantly from the estimated amounts.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P76_S0	Adjustments to estimated reserves are recorded in the period in which the change in estimate occurs.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P76_S1	Other insurance reserves such as workers compensation and group health insurance are based on actual historical and current claim data provided by third party administrators or internally maintained.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P77_S0	Our goodwill balance of $170,716,000 as of March 31, 2016 is subject to impairment testing.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P77_S1	We test goodwill for impairment at least annually, as of the end of February, and more frequently whenever events occur or circumstances change that indicate there may be impairment.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P77_S2	These events or circumstances could include a significant long-term adverse change in the business climate, poor indicators of operating performance, or a sale or disposition of a significant portion of a reporting unit.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P78_S0	We test goodwill at the reporting unit level, which is one level below our operating segment.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P78_S1	We identify our reporting units by assessing whether the components of our operating segment constitute businesses for which discrete financial information is available and segment management regularly reviews the operating results of those components.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P78_S2	We also aggregate components that have similar economic characteristics into single reporting units (for example, similar products and / or services, similar long-term financial results, product processes, classes of customers, or in circumstances where the components share assets or other resources and have other economic interdependencies).
1005229_16_ITEM7_P78_S3	We have four reporting units, only two of which have goodwill.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P78_S4	Duff-Norton and Rest of Products reporting units have goodwill totaling $9,627,000 , and $161,089,000 , respectively, at March 31, 2016 .
1005229_16_ITEM7_P79_S0	When we evaluate the potential for goodwill impairment, we assess a range of qualitative factors including, but not limited to, macroeconomic conditions, industry conditions, the competitive environment, changes in the market for our products and services, regulatory and political developments, entity specific factors such as strategy and changes in key personnel and overall financial performance.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P79_S1	If, after completing this assessment, it is determined that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value, we proceed to a two-step impairment test.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P79_S2	We also proceed to the two-step model when economic or other business factors indicate that the fair value of our reporting units may have declined since our last quantitative test.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P79_S3	We performed the qualitative assessment as of February 29, 2016 and determined that the two-step goodwill impairment test should be performed for both the Rest of Products reporting unit and the Duff-Norton reporting unit due to the decline in our stock price during fiscal 2016.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P80_S0	In order to perform the two-step impairment test, we use the discounted cash flow method and comparable market method to estimate fair value.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P81_S0	The discounted cash flow method incorporates various assumptions, the most significant being projected revenue growth rates, operating profit margins and cash flows, the terminal growth rate and the discount rate.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P82_S0	Management projects revenue growth rates, operating margins and cash flows based on each reporting unit s current business, expected developments and operational strategies over a five-year period.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P83_S0	In estimating the terminal growth rate, we consider our historical and projected results, as well as the economic environment in which the reporting unit operates.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P83_S1	The discount rates utilized for each reporting unit reflect management s assumptions of marketplace participants cost of capital and risk assumptions, both specific to the reporting unit and overall in the economy.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P84_S0	The comparable market method estimates fair value based on prices obtained in actual transactions.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P84_S1	The method consists of examining selling prices for comparable assets.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P84_S2	After studying the selling prices, value adjustments are made for any dissimilarities.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P85_S0	We performed step one of the two-step impairment test for the Rest of Products and Duff Norton reporting units.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P85_S1	Testing goodwill for impairment under the two-step method requires us to estimate fair values of reporting units using significant estimates and judgmental factors.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P85_S2	The key estimates and factors used in our discounted cash flow valuation include revenue growth rates and profit margins based on internal forecasts, terminal value, and the weighted-average cost of capital used to discount future cash flows.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P85_S3	The compound annual growth rate for revenue during the first five years of our projections was approximately 4.6% for the Rest of Products reporting unit and 4.0% for the Duff-Norton reporting unit.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P85_S4	The terminal value was calculated assuming a projected growth rate of 3.0% after five years for both reporting units.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P85_S5	These rates reflect our estimate of long-term growth into perpetuity and approximate the long-term gross domestic product growth expected on a global basis as well as our normal annual price increases.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P85_S6	The estimated weighted-average cost of capital for the reporting units was determined to be 9.9% and 10.0% for the Rest of Products and Duff-Norton reporting units, respectively based upon an analysis of similar companies and their debt to equity mix, their related volatility and the size of their market capitalization.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P85_S7	We also consider any additional risk of the Duff-Norton and Rest of Product reporting units achieving their forecast, and adjust the weighted-average cost of capital applied when determining the reporting unit s estimated fair value.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P85_S8	Future changes in these estimates and assumptions could materially affect the results of our goodwill impairment tests.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P85_S9	For example, a decline in the terminal growth rate by 50 basis points would decrease fair market value by $10,210,000 and $1,775,000 and an increase in the weighted-average cost of capital by 100 basis points would result in a decrease in fair market value by $32,840,000 and $4,543,000 for the Rest of Products and Duff-Norton reporting units, respectively.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P85_S10	Even with such changes the fair value of the reporting units would be greater than their net book values as of February 29, 2016, necessitating no Step 2 calculations.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P86_S0	Purchase Price Allocations for Business Combinations.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P86_S1	During the fiscal year ended March 31, 2016, we completed a business combination for a total purchase price of $190,672,000 .
1005229_16_ITEM7_P87_S0	Under purchase accounting, we recorded assets and liabilities at fair value as of the acquisition dates.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P87_S1	We identified and assigned value to trademarks and trade names, customer relationships, non-compete agreements, backlog, and patents.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P87_S2	We estimated the useful lives over which these intangible assets would be amortized.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P87_S3	Valuations of these assets were performed largely using discounted cash flow models and estimates of replacement cost.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P87_S4	These valuations support the conclusion that identifiable intangible assets had a value of $105,998,000 .
1005229_16_ITEM7_P87_S5	The resulting goodwill was $49,204,000 .
1005229_16_ITEM7_P88_S0	Assigning value to intangible assets requires estimates used in projecting relevant future cash flows and estimates of replacement costs, in addition to estimating useful lives of such assets.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P89_S0	Allowances for doubtful accounts and credit memo reserves are also judgmentally determined based on formulas applied to historical bad debt write-offs and credit memos issued, assessing potentially uncollectible customer accounts and analyzing the accounts receivable aging.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P90_S0	Accounts receivable are charged against the allowance for doubtful accounts once all collection efforts have been exhausted.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P90_S1	At March 31, 2016 the allowance for doubtful accounts totaled $2,177,000 .
1005229_16_ITEM7_P91_S0	Impairment of depreciable and amortizable long-lived assets .
1005229_16_ITEM7_P91_S1	Property, plant and equipment and certain intangibles are depreciated or amortized over their assigned lives.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P92_S0	We test long-lived assets for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of those assets may not be recoverable and exceed their fair market value.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P92_S1	The following summarizes the value of long-lived assets subject to impairment testing when events or circumstances indicate potential impairment (amounts in millions):
1005229_16_ITEM7_P93_S0	Impairment may exist if the carrying amount of the asset in question exceeds the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P93_S1	The impairment loss, if any, would be measured as the amount by which the carrying amount of a long-lived asset exceeds its fair market value as determined by appropriate valuation techniques.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P94_S0	On a quarterly basis, we review our marketable securities for declines in market value that may be considered other than temporary.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P94_S1	We generally consider market value declines to be other than temporary if there are declines for a period longer than six months and in excess of 20% of original cost.
1005229_16_ITEM7_P94_S2	We also consider the nature of the underlying investments and other market conditions or when other evidence indicates impairment.

1005229_16_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market rates and prices, such as interest rates.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P0_S1	We are exposed to various market risks, including commodity prices for raw materials, foreign currency exchange rates and changes in interest rates.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P0_S2	We may enter into financial instrument transactions, which attempt to manage and reduce the impact of such changes.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P0_S3	We do not enter into derivatives or other financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Our primary commodity risk is related to changes in the price of steel.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P1_S1	We control this risk through negotiating purchase contracts on a consolidated basis and by attempting to build changes in raw material costs into the selling prices of or surcharges on our products.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P1_S2	We have not entered into financial instrument transactions related to raw material costs.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P2_S0	In fiscal 2016, 37% of our net sales were from manufacturing plants and sales offices in foreign jurisdictions.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P2_S1	We manufacture our products in the United States, China, Germany, United Kingdom, Hungary, Mexico and France and sell our products in approximately 50 countries.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Our results of operations could be affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency rates or weak economic conditions in foreign markets.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Our operating results are exposed to fluctuations between the U.S. Dollar and the Canadian Dollar, European currencies, the South African Rand, the Mexican Peso, the Brazilian Real, and the Chinese Yuan.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P2_S4	For example, when the U.S. dollar weakens against the Euro, the value of our net sales and net income denominated in Euros increases when translated into U.S. dollars for inclusion in our consolidated results.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P3_S0	We are also exposed to foreign currency fluctuations in relation to purchases denominated in foreign currencies.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P3_S1	Our foreign currency risk is mitigated since the majority of our foreign operations net sales and the related expense transactions are denominated in the same currency so therefore a significant change in foreign exchange rates would likely have a very minor impact on net income.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P3_S2	For example, a 10% change in the value of the U.S. dollar in relation to our most significant foreign currency exposures would have had an impact of approximately $800,000 on our income from operations.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P3_S3	In addition, the majority of our export sale transactions are denominated in U.S. dollars.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The Company has foreign currency forward agreements in place to offset changes in the value of intercompany loans to foreign subsidiaries due to changes in foreign exchange rates.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P4_S1	The notional amount of these derivatives is $2,118,000 and all of the contracts mature by June 30, 2016.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P5_S0	These contracts are marked to market each balance sheet date and are not designated as hedges.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P6_S0	The Company has foreign currency forward agreements that are designated as cash flow hedges to hedge a portion of forecasted inventory purchases denominated in foreign currencies.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P6_S1	The notional amount of those derivatives is $14,585,000 and all contracts mature within twelve months of March 31, 2016.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P6_S2	From its March 31, 2016 balance of AOCL, the Company expects to reclassify approximately $207,000 out of AOCL during the next 12 months based on the underlying transactions of the sales of the goods purchased.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P7_S0	The Company's policy is to maintain a capital structure that is comprised of 50-70% of fixed rate long-term debt and 30-50% of variable rate long-term debt.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P8_S0	The Company entered into two interest rate swap agreements in which the Company receives interest at a variable rate and pays interest at a fixed rate.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P8_S1	These interest rate swap agreements are designated as cash flow hedges to hedge changes in interest expense due to changes in the variable interest rate of the senior secured term loan.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P8_S2	The amortizing interest rate swaps mature on February 19, 2020 and have a total notional amount of $161,000,000 as of March 31, 2016.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P8_S3	The effective portion of the changes in fair values of the interest rate swaps is reported in AOCL and will be reclassified to interest expense over the life of the swap agreements.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P8_S4	The ineffective portion was not material and was recognized in the current period interest expense.
1005229_16_ITEM7A_P8_S5	From its March 31, 2016 balance of AOCL, the Company expects to reclassify approximately $700,000 out of AOCL, and into interest expense, during the next 12 months.

1005229_16_ITEM8_P7_S0	Columbus McKinnon Corporation (the Company) is a leading global designer, manufacturer and marketer of hoists, actuators, cranes, rigging tools, digital power control systems, and other material handling products, which efficiently and safely move, lift, position, and secure materials and people.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P7_S1	Key products include hoists, rigging tools, cranes, actuators, digital power control and delivery systems, and elevator application drive systems.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P7_S2	On September 2, 2015, the Company acquired 100% of the shares of Magnetek, Inc. ( Magnetek ), which is a global provider of digital power control systems that are used to control motion and power primarily in material handling, elevator, and mining applications.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P8_S0	The Company s material handling products are sold globally, principally to third party distributors through diverse distribution channels, and to a lesser extent directly to end-users.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P8_S1	During fiscal 2016 , approximately 63% of sales were to customers in the United States.

1005229_16_ITEM8_P11_S1	None of the collective bargaining agreements expire within 12 months .

1005229_16_ITEM8_P13_S0	The Company translates foreign currency financial statements as described in Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) Topic 830, Foreign Currency Matters.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P13_S1	Under this method, all items of income and expense are translated to U.S. dollars at average exchange rates during the year.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P13_S2	All assets and liabilities are translated to U.S. dollars at the year-end exchange rate.

1005229_16_ITEM8_P15_S0	Goodwill is not amortized but is tested for impairment at least annually, or more frequently if indicators of impairment exist, in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 350-20-35-1.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P15_S1	Goodwill impairment is deemed to exist if the net book value of a reporting unit exceeds its estimated fair value.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P15_S2	The fair value of a reporting unit is determined using a discounted cash flow methodology.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P15_S3	The Company s reporting units are determined based upon whether discrete financial information is available and reviewed regularly, whether those units constitute a business, and the extent of economic similarities and interdependencies between those reporting units for purposes of aggregation.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P15_S4	The Company s reporting units identified under ASC Topic 350-20-35-33 are at the component level, or one level below the reporting segment level as defined under ASC Topic 280-10-50-10 Segment Reporting Disclosure.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P16_S0	The Company s one segment is subdivided into four reporting units.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P17_S0	When the Company evaluates the potential for goodwill impairment, it assesses a range of qualitative factors including, but not limited to, macroeconomic conditions, industry conditions, the competitive environment, changes in the market for its products and services, regulatory and political developments, entity specific factors such as strategy and changes in key personnel and overall financial performance.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P17_S1	If, after completing this assessment, it is determined that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value or if economic or other business factors indicate that the fair value of our reporting units may have declined since our last quantitative test, the Company proceeds to a two-step impairment test.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P18_S0	To perform the two-step impairment test, the Company uses the discounted cash flow method to estimate the fair value of the reporting units.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P18_S1	The discounted cash flow method incorporates various assumptions, the most significant being projected revenue growth rates, operating profit margins and cash flows, the terminal growth rate and the discount rate.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P19_S0	The Company projects revenue growth rates, operating margins and cash flows based on each reporting unit s current business, expected developments and operational strategies over a five-year period.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P19_S1	In estimating the terminal growth rate, the Company considers its historical and projected results, as well as the economic environment in which its reporting units operate.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P19_S2	The discount rates utilized for each reporting unit reflect the Company s assumptions of marketplace participants cost of capital and risk assumptions, both specific to the reporting unit and overall in the economy.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P20_S0	The Company performed its qualitative assessment as of February 29, 2016 and determined that the two-step goodwill impairment test should be performed for both the Rest of Products reporting unit and the Duff-Norton reporting unit.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P20_S1	Based on the results of step one of the two-step impairment test, the Company determined that the Rest of Products and Duff Norton reporting units' fair value was not less than its applicable carrying value.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P20_S2	See Note 8 for further discussion of goodwill and intangible assets.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P21_S0	The Company assesses impairment of its long-lived assets in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 360 Property, Plant, and Equipment.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P21_S1	This statement requires long-lived assets, such as property and equipment and purchased intangibles subject to amortization to be reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset group may not be recoverable.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P22_S0	Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of an asset group to estimated undiscounted future cash flows expected to be generated by the asset group over its remaining useful life.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P22_S1	If the carrying amount of an asset group exceeds its estimated future cash flows, an impairment charge is recognized equal to the amount by which the carrying amount of the asset group exceeds the fair value of the asset group.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P22_S2	The fair values are determined in accordance with ASC 820.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P23_S0	In assessing long-lived assets for an impairment loss, assets are grouped with other assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other assets and liabilities.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P23_S1	Asset grouping requires a significant amount of judgment.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P23_S2	Accordingly, facts and circumstances will influence how asset groups are determined for impairment testing.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P24_S0	In assessing long-lived assets for impairment, management considered the Company s product line portfolio, customers and related commercial agreements, labor agreements and other factors in grouping assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are independent.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P24_S1	The Company considers projected future undiscounted cash flows, trends and other factors in its assessment of whether impairment conditions exist.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P24_S2	While the Company believes that its estimates of future cash flows are reasonable, different assumptions regarding such factors as future production volumes, customer pricing, economics and productivity and cost initiatives, could significantly affect its estimates.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P25_S0	In determining fair value of long-lived assets, management uses management estimates, discounted cash flow calculations, and appraisals where necessary.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P26_S0	At acquisition, the Company estimates and records the fair value of purchased intangible assets which primarily consist of trade names, customer relationships and technology.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P26_S1	The fair values are estimated based on management s assessment as well as independent third party appraisals.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P26_S2	Such valuations may include a discounted cash flow of anticipated revenues resulting from the acquired intangible asset.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P27_S0	Amortization of intangible assets with finite lives is recognized over their estimated useful lives using an amortization method that reflects the pattern in which the economic benefits of the intangible assets are consumed or otherwise realized.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P28_S0	The straight line method is used for customer relationships.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P28_S1	As a result of the negligible attrition rate in our customer base, the difference between the straight line method and attrition method is not considered significant.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P29_S0	The estimated useful lives for our intangible assets range from 2 to 25 years.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P30_S0	Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P30_S1	Cost of approximately 34% and 35% of inventories at March 31, 2016 and March 31, 2015, respectively, have been determined using the LIFO (last-in, first-out) method.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P30_S2	Costs of other inventories have been determined using the FIFO (first-in, first-out) or average cost method.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P31_S0	Costs in inventory include components for direct labor and overhead costs.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P31_S1	The decrease in the percentage of LIFO inventory is due to the acquisition of Magnetek which determines the cost of its inventory using the FIFO method.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P32_S0	All of the Company s marketable securities, which consist of equity securities, have been classified as available-for-sale securities and are therefore recorded at their fair values with the unrealized gains and losses, net of tax, reported in accumulated other comprehensive loss in the shareholders equity section of the consolidated balance sheet unless unrealized losses are deemed to be other than temporary.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P32_S1	In such instance, the unrealized losses are reported in the consolidated statements of operations within investment income.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P33_S0	Estimated fair value is based on published trading values at the balance sheet dates.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P33_S1	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.

1005229_16_ITEM8_P65_S0	ASC Topic 820 Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures establishes the standards for reporting financial assets and liabilities and nonfinancial assets and liabilities that are recognized or disclosed at fair value on a recurring basis (at least annually).
1005229_16_ITEM8_P65_S1	Under these standards, fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability (i.e. the "exit price") in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P66_S0	ASC Topic 820-10-35-37 establishes a hierarchy for inputs used in measuring fair value that maximizes the use of observable inputs and minimizes the use of unobservable inputs by requiring that the most observable inputs be used when available.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P67_S0	Observable inputs are inputs that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability developed based on market data obtained from sources independent of the Company.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P67_S1	Unobservable inputs are inputs that reflect the Company's assumptions about the valuation techniques that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability developed based on the best information available in the circumstances.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P67_S2	The hierarchy is separated into three levels based on the reliability of inputs as follows:
1005229_16_ITEM8_P68_S0	Level 1 - Valuations based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the Company has the ability to access.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P68_S1	Since valuations are based on quoted prices that are readily and regularly available in an active market, valuation of these products does not entail a significant degree of judgment.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P69_S0	Level 2 - Valuations based on quoted prices in markets that are not active or for which all significant inputs are observable, either directly or indirectly, involving some degree of judgment.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P70_S0	Level 3 - Valuations based on inputs that are unobservable and significant to the overall fair value measurement.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P70_S1	The degree of judgment exercised in determining fair value is greatest for instruments categorized in Level 3.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P71_S0	The availability of observable inputs can vary and is affected by a wide variety of factors, including the type of asset/liability, whether the asset/liability is established in the marketplace, and other characteristics particular to the transaction.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P72_S0	To the extent that valuation is based on models or inputs that are less observable or unobservable in the market, the determination of fair value requires more judgment.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P73_S0	In certain cases, the inputs used to measure fair value may fall into different levels of the fair value hierarchy.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P73_S1	In such cases, for disclosure purposes the level in the fair value hierarchy within which the fair value measurement in its entirety falls is determined based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P74_S0	Fair value is a market-based measure considered from the perspective of a market participant rather than an entity-specific measure.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P74_S1	Therefore, even when market assumptions are not readily available, assumptions are required to reflect those that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability at the measurement date.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P75_S0	The Company primarily uses readily observable market data in conjunction with internally developed discounted cash flow valuation models when valuing its derivative portfolio and, consequently, the fair value of the Company s derivatives is based on Level 2 inputs.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P75_S1	The carrying amount of the Company's annuity contract acquired in connection with the acquisition of Magnetek is recorded at net asset value of the contract and, consequently, it's fair value is based on Level 2 inputs and is included in other assets on the Company's consolidated balance sheet.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P75_S2	The carrying value of the Company s term loan, revolving credit facility, and senior debt approximate fair value based on current market interest rates for debt instruments of similar credit standing and, consequently, their fair values are based on Level 2 inputs.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P76_S0	The following table provides information regarding financial assets and liabilities measured or disclosed at fair value on a recurring basis:
1005229_16_ITEM8_P77_S0	The Company did not have any non-financial assets and liabilities that are recognized at fair value on a recurring basis.

1005229_16_ITEM8_P79_S1	Changes in the fair value of derivatives are recorded in foreign currency exchange (gain) loss or other comprehensive income (loss), to the extent that the derivative qualifies as a hedge under the provisions of ASC Topic 815.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P80_S0	Interest and dividend income on marketable securities are measured based upon amounts earned on their respective declaration dates.

1005229_16_ITEM8_P114_S0	As discussed in Note 2, goodwill is not amortized but is tested for impairment at least annually, in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 350-20-35-1.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P114_S1	Goodwill impairment is deemed to exist if the net book value of a reporting unit exceeds its estimated fair value.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P114_S2	The fair value of a reporting unit is determined using a discounted cash flow methodology.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P114_S3	The Company s reporting units are determined based upon whether discrete financial information is available and reviewed regularly, whether those units constitute a business, and the extent of economic similarities and interdependencies between those reporting units for purposes of aggregation.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P114_S4	The Company s reporting units identified under ASC Topic 350-20-35-33 are at the component level, or one level below the operating segment level as defined under ASC Topic 280-10-50-10 Segment Reporting Disclosure.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P114_S5	The Company has four reporting units as of March 31, 2016 and 2015.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P114_S6	Only two of the four reporting units carried goodwill at March 31, 2016 and only two of the four reporting units carried goodwill at March 31, 2015 .
1005229_16_ITEM8_P114_S7	The Duff-Norton reporting unit (which designs, manufactures and sources mechanical and electromechanical actuators and rotary unions) had goodwill of $9,627,000 and $9,563,000 at March 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively, and the Rest of Products reporting unit (representing the hoist, chain, and forgings design, manufacturing, digital power control systems, and distribution businesses) had goodwill of $161,089,000 and $111,898,000 at March 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P114_S8	Both STB and Magnetek have been determined to be part of the Rest of Products reporting unit.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P115_S0	When we evaluate the potential for goodwill impairment, we assess a range of qualitative factors including, but not limited to, macroeconomic conditions, industry conditions, the competitive environment, changes in the market for our products and services, regulatory and political developments, entity specific factors such as strategy and changes in key personnel and overall financial performance.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P115_S1	If, after completing this assessment, it is determined that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value or if economic or other business factors indicate that the fair value of our reporting units may have declined since our last quantitative test, we proceed to a two-step impairment test.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P115_S2	The Company performed its qualitative assessment as of February 29, 2016 and determined that the two-step goodwill impairment test should be performed for both the Rest of Products reporting unit and the Duff-Norton reporting unit.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P116_S0	In accordance with ASC Topic 350-20-35-3, the measurement of impairment of goodwill consists of two steps.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P117_S0	In the first step, the Company compares the fair value of each reporting unit to its carrying value.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P117_S1	As part of the impairment analysis, the Company determines the fair value of each of its reporting units with goodwill using the income approach and market approach.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P118_S0	The income approach uses a discounted cash flow methodology to determine fair value.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P118_S1	This methodology recognizes value based on the expected receipt of future economic benefits.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P118_S2	Key assumptions in the income approach include a free cash flow projection, an estimated discount rate, a long-term growth rate and a terminal value.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P118_S3	These assumptions are based upon the Company s historical experience, current market trends and future expectations.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P119_S0	The Company performed step one of the two-step impairment test for the Rest of Products and Duff-Norton reporting units as of February 29, 2016.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P119_S1	Based on the results of the two-step impairment test, the Company determined that the Rest of Products and Duff-Norton reporting units' fair values were not less than their applicable carrying values.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P120_S0	Future impairment indicators, such as declines in forecasted cash flows, may cause additional significant impairment charges.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P120_S1	Impairment charges could be based on such factors as the Company s stock price, forecasted cash flows, assumptions used, control premiums or other variables.

1005229_16_ITEM8_P149_S0	An aggregate $125,000,000 secured term loan facility which requires quarterly principal amortization of 2.5% with the remaining principal due at maturity date.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P150_S0	An aggregate $150,000,000 secured revolving credit facility which includes sublimits for the issuance of standby letters of credit, swingline loans and multi-currency borrowings in certain specified foreign currencies.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P151_S0	Fees and Interest Rates: Commitment fees and interest rates are determined on the basis of either a Eurocurrency rate or a Base rate plus an applicable margin based upon the Company's Total Leverage Ratio (as defined in the New Credit Agreement).
1005229_16_ITEM8_P152_S0	Accordion Feature: Provisions permitting a Borrower from time to time to increase the aggregate amount of the credit facility by up to $75,000,000 , with a minimum increase of $20,000,000 and with additional commitments from the Lenders, as they may agree, or new commitments from financial institutions acceptable to the Administrative Agent and the Company.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P153_S0	Prepayments: Provisions permitting a Borrower to voluntarily prepay either the Term Loan or New Revolving Credit Facility in whole or in part at any time, and provisions requiring certain mandatory prepayments of the Term Loan or New Revolving Credit Facility on the occurrence of certain events which will permanently reduce the commitments under the New Credit Agreement, each without premium or penalty, subject to reimbursement of certain costs of the Lenders.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P154_S0	A Borrower may irrevocably cancel, in whole or in part, the unutilized portion of the commitments under the New Credit Agreement in excess of any outstanding loans, the stated amount of all outstanding letters of credit and all unreimbursed amounts drawn under any letters of credit.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P155_S0	Covenants: Provisions containing covenants required of the Company and its subsidiaries including various affirmative and negative financial and operational covenants.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P155_S1	Key financial covenants include a minimum fixed charge coverage ratio of 1.25 x; a maximum total leverage ratio, net of cash, of 3.50 x (which may be temporarily increased following a material acquisition, which may be elected two times over the course of the New Credit Agreement, (i) if financed by secured debt the total leverage rate as at the end of the fiscal quarter in which such material acquisition occurs and the three fiscal quarters immediately thereafter, shall not be greater than 4.00:1.00 and as at the end of any fiscal quarter thereafter, the total leverage ratio shall not be greater than 3.50:1.00, and (ii) if financed with unsecured or subordinated indebtedness, the total leverage ratio at the end of the fiscal quarter in which such material acquisition occurs and at the end of any fiscal quarter thereafter, shall not be greater than 4.50:1.00, and permit the secured leverage ratio, to be greater than 3.25:1.00), and maximum capital expenditures of $30 million per fiscal year ($40 million following a material acquisition) with the ability to transfer any unused portion of expenditure to the immediately following fiscal year.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P156_S0	The New Revolving Credit Facility is secured by all U.S. inventory, receivables, equipment, real property, subsidiary stock (limited to 65% of non-U.S. subsidiaries) and intellectual property.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P156_S1	The New Credit Agreement allows, but limits our ability to pay dividends.

1005229_16_ITEM8_P200_S0	The guidance in ASC Topic 718 "Compensation - Stock Compensation" and covered in sub-topic 718-40 "Employee Stock Ownership Plans" requires that compensation expense for ESOP shares be measured based on the fair value of those shares when committed to be released to employees, rather than based on their original cost.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P200_S1	Also, dividends on those ESOP shares that have not been allocated or committed to be released to ESOP participants are not reflected as a reduction of retained earnings.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P200_S2	Rather, since those dividends are used for debt service, a charge to compensation expense is recorded.
1005229_16_ITEM8_P200_S3	Furthermore, ESOP shares that have not been allocated or committed to be released are not considered outstanding for purposes of calculating earnings per share.
